column10:
Screw Cannibals. They won't let me make my abominations of flesh and metal in peace. 

But besides that great game, my only complaint is that the game is so good with giving the player freedom that I keep getting bored playing other games. 

I hate Cannibals/10

Tl;dr It's a bad 3D rimworld that honestly tested my patience in colony management/RPG type games. This game's bad, don't let all the fanboys who can't admit they wasted years waiting for this terrible game gaslight you into playing something that looks like runescape and has more bugs than gameplay

Bad: 
-Unreasonably difficult combat execution without xp boosts, mechanics are cool, but the execution just falls flat on its face as you watch your group of 10 guys stand in the middle of a group of 5 and all die. Instead of maybe, surrounding them? or flanking them? Or doing literally anything at all that isn't charging headfirst at the nearest enemy and slamming heads until one dies?

-Convoluted and confusing UI to accommodate screens and buttons that you will never use

-LONG XP grind for every skill (2-3x xp mod is mandatory imo)

-No real story (unless you count "quests" given to you by clans/guilds, which are more vauge goals)

-Mining and selling bandit stuff is the only 2 things you can do to make early-game money, and they are both SLOW

--On top of that, there's no real way to make any serious money (outside of end-game power to fight bounties, hash is the only thing in the ENTIRE game that has more than a 150%~ markup, and that's only in SOME cities)

-Bad economy mechanics, actually there's no economy mechanics at all. This town will pay you 500% markup on hash. Why? Who knows. Do they have a DEMAND for hash in this town? What about an ample supply? Doesn't matter, 500% until the entire town runs out of money; Then you wait 24 hours and do it all over again because it's STILL 500%

-Bad AI and even worse pathfinding; The insanely difficult fights (minimum 8 people parties you will ALWAYS be fighting against, no one is ever solo)
Seriously, you will give move orders, and it's very common to just find them stopped randomly somewhere waiting because the pathfinding decided it was impossible to move around the boulder in the road


Good: 

-The world is interesting, how the apocalypse happened, all the stuff you can see. None of it gets elaborated on because of point 3 on the bad, there's no real story

Summary: My curiosity got the better of me, and I wasted 25 hours on a game I could have returned. Don't be like me, play games that are actually fun with good AI, mechanics, and gameplay; not 1/3

This game is an absolute gem. The only other time I've seen a game like this was Terraria. I've been gaming for 34 years and have no idea how this got past me until a few weeks ago. For sure my new all time favorite. There is a lot that could make it better and I hope they realize the full potential with this concept in Kenshi 2!!

My gripes have to do with the setting not the gameplay or the couple of bugs I ran into. I just couldn't get into the lore, all the strange little creatures, and the post-apocalyptic steampunk-ish dark and toxic world. It's unique for sure. I'm not holding it against it, I'm just disappointed that no one else has used the game mechanics elsewhere. 

I love the squad-base RPG stuff and love the base building. It's not an easy game. There is a learning curve, but that's not a bad thing. There are different points in the game that involve time grinds. That's not necessarily a bad thing either. It adds to the overall value of the game. It's overwhelmingly positive for a reason. Do try if you have not.

Waiting for a sequal or redux ;)

I had my eye on this game for years before I actually ended up buying it because it looked so inaccessible and punishing that I wasn't sure if I would be able to enjoy it, but I am so glad I did. I fell in love with the game instantly when I realized how well it embodied the "fail forward" design philosophy. When you start this game, even a single one of the weakest enemies in the game will likely kick your ass straight into the dirt, but the twist here is that getting beaten in combat is usually not a death sentence. Most enemies are content to loot your stuff and move on rather than outright killing you, so  what would usually be a game-ending failure state in other games is instead a learning experience for you as the player, and literal toughness training for your character. Getting beaten up makes you stronger and more able to withstand future punishment. Every situation that does not end in death for your character can be considered a small victory because they improve themselves with every action they take. Running away from enemies trains your athletics which makes you even faster. Fighting them trains your combat skills which make you better at dealing and withstanding damage. Eventually you will save up enough money from scavenging for resources and selling them in nearby settlements that you might be able to afford to hire a companion to join you on your journeys. Now that you've got a wingman to watch your back you are in an even better position to take risks in the game because if one of you is incapacitated the other one might be able to drag them back to safety. Eventually you might grow your band of companions into a group large enough to start thinking about creating your own settlement where you can start to grow your own food or produce weapons and armor to equip yourselves or sell to other settlements for a profit. As your community continues to train and improve their skills and equipment you can start to explore more dangerous areas of the world in the hopes of scavenging some ancient technology that can be researched or repurposed for your own ends. Eventually your band of once-starving wanderers will be able to thrive, and with enough training and the right equipment they may become a force able to exert influence upon the world or explore the ruins of ancient civilizations in the hopes of learning more about the forgotten history of the moon called Kenshi.

One of the Best games ever made, at least in concept. It is certainly my favorite game to play. I rank it 7/10 in general lore, 10/10 in the design of Skeletons, specifically the concept of Robots who broke free from slavery, but didn't cause an "AI Uprising" and who aren't "So OP humans struggle to fight them." giving them a humanizing aspect that makes them great. 10/10 Hivers are the most pleasant to look at and bad ass silly and cool bugman race I've played as in a video game without being over designed.

The game has flaws. Flaws Mods cannot fix. But yet it is still a treasure. It is endlessly replayable. It's not afraid to ruin your plans, it's not afraid to let you break it. A Triple A studio could never dream of recreating this amazing game without softening it up, or overcommiting to the "difficulty." It provides a curve of experience that happens both IRL and In game. You AND your character get stronger together with new game knowledge, and new Toughness XP.

It's Grimdark done right. It's a Sandbox done masterfully. It's only true flaws are the bugs, or shoddily implemented systems due to the Ogre Engine. But if you let yourself get immersed. Push past the bugs, the reloading because you got bodied at toughness level 1, and the relatively slow grind, you will find a game you will truly love.

Skin bandits are assholes who put me in a peeler machine. Become a drug dealer or a slaver! The  choices are endless.



Edit: The game can be broken and janky, but a couple mods fixes it. It can randomly crash at times. Overall still awesome.

Bounced off this one hard when I realized a majority of this game's mechanics were dedicated to Fallout 4 settlement building.
Definitely more in the "story generator" vein where you have to make your own fun, but much more clunky than something like DF or Rimworld because of the character perspective rather than the "god in the sky" perspective you take on in those games.
EDIT 2.21.24
Most of Kenshi's mechanics ARE in its settlement building, but the game is so so so so much more than than that. If you go into Kenshi with an imaginative mindset (and liberal use of the wiki and workshop) you will find a living breathing world unlike anything I've seen in gaming. A breathtaking atmosphere full of hidden lore and fun secrets.
 It's built-in modding tool is quite intimidating at first, but very easy to learn with a friendly community on discord willing to answer any questions the wiki can't. Then once you have a grasp on the Forgotten Construction Set, you are free to play around in Kenshi's guts as you please. Make your own factions with their own worldview and unique characters. Create a game start with an absolutely OP squad and conquer the world without having to mine copper for 30 hours first. Kenshi is very, very special and I'm glad I came around on it.

Have you ever come across a game and felt like it was built specifically for you, perfectly fits your interests and such? Well that was Kenshi for me. This game is like 9 games in one, stat based rpg, base building sim, base defence, trading sim, farming sim, boss fights, Faction conquest. I love the absolute shit out of it. There's so many different  starts and playstyles, wanna be a beefy martial arts god soloing everything, you can! How about you get a million goats and destroy an evil slaver empire, its got that too. Hell even the early game when youre weak is really enjoyable, they somehow managed to make being a slave into interesting gameplay. I cannot reccomend this game enough for the gameplay alone.

And then the story and setting. The atmosphere and unique cities and zones is absolutely mindblowing for how simple the graphics are. Some zones are dark and bushy and annoyingly hard to see in, namely the swamp, but most are awesome and have unique features. So much of the story is told simply through enviornment and then the rest of it is buried in item descriptions and unique dialouges from rareish characters. From a dark souls fan, I love the ambiguity of everthing youre told and knowing some characters may be lying. And once you start putting things together it gives a whole new meaning to many of the zones you visit, although you may have to go on the wiki once or twice to really understand things.

buy this game and then get kenshi 2 when it comes out.

kenshi
its very grindy and you will lose a lot but its a lot of fun great game
I loved all the possible things I could do with my play through! The replay-ability of this game is nearly limitless and with mods it exceeds the imagination.

PROS:
- being a random weak dude, getting beat up and slowly getting back at the people who beat you up is a major factor in this game. In other words, stat building (str/dexterity/weapon skills etc.) really hooked me up. But i will also mention this in the CONS section as its a double edged blade.

- world is large. Kinda empty, but large. It drives you to go out there and look for the ancient books and items that can help you research new techs. New techs open up new defenses, improve your production etc. 

- combat feels increasingly good up to a point. (if you have a uber character as i had, it gets boring super fast because you won't be able to watch the action, it will be over in 2-5 seconds most). Animations are between ok and good. Some weapons like katana or unarmed combat have better animations than - say polearms. Too bad katanas suck at endgame since you will be fighting armored opponents all the time.

- blood / bleeding effects. just damn. seeing your enemies actually bleed out on the floor is just satisfying. But its also kinda "shocking" if it happens to you.

- endgame is what you set it to be. you can go after abnormally strong NPCs, or faction leaders. If you kill an emperor, his city will crumble.


CONS:

- stat building really feels like a grind at some point. It already made a bad habit on me to train every single one to become a compotent fighter but it really is not fun while doing it. I suggest you to get a mod for training and restrain yourself not to exploit the game to enjoy it.

- world is TOO large. you can go anywhere you like, but there is nothing there that catches your atttention after you get to a certain tech level and have good weapons. Because you don't have an incentive to look for anything.

- there are supposedly "world state" events that happen when you kill a certain important NPC of a faction. But its so minor gameplay-wise (some buildings of that city get destoryed and a few set cities in border zone -not all- switch town guards to the opposing faction) that i felt disappointed. You can't really destroy a faction completely by eliminating their leadership, they just  keep "sandboxing on".

- combat feels like a minor annoyance after you get 70+ stat chars (i had 10 characters as a hit squad all with high level weapons and armor and could take down anything). It's not fun to watch people jumping all over the screen for 5 seconds. Although money is hard to come by at the beginning, you wont even bother looting your enemies at the midgame.

- i know game advertises itself as "become a warlord", but you can't actually. Sure you can have an outpost full with people doing labour/farm work, training etc. but your actions won't get recognised by the factions. You can be allied to a faction and thats it. You can't really rule anything in this world since there is no real interactions with the npcs (or factions). 

CONCLUSION:
I like the game. It made me play over 200 hours which is already self-proving. But it lacks replay value for me because of the mentioned cons.
Recommended!

Born from the minds of two and the labors of one, this game is one of the most unique and fun experiences I have ever played. Kenshi laughs in the face of mediocre AAA titles with it's one-of-a-kind story line, systems, and gameplay loops. Forget the labels, there is no other game like this. The story is not spelled out for you. You are not the main character. The world of Kenshi is HUGE. Your victories are earned and your knowledge is gained through your will to seek it. Yes, the graphics aren't the best and there are some glitches, but the vast lore and compelling combat systems unfolding before you make it all worthwhile. The integrated Steam workshop and constant updates have the potential to fix most/if not all issues you may have, plus it's always fun to have something new to suck you back into another play through. 

Speaking of which replay-ability is extremely high. Want to become a lone Bounty Hunter Assassin? Do it. Become an illegal drug kingpin? Slave liberator? Slave Master? Business tycoon? Band of warriors? Band of b--witches? Yes to all! Perhaps do it all in one go. Do whatever you want. The world of Kenshi is harsh at first, but once you figure out how to survive and thrive, thriving can look like whatever you want it to be. If you like open-world styled play with a little bit of survival and base building mixed in, give it a try, it's probably cheaper than that OTHER game you like. 

WARNING: if you're the type that needs training wheels or guard rails up when you're gaming, this one's not for you. If you like popping wheelies and ripping those rails off to create support beams for your next ramp -- get this game and have fun breaking it!

Good luck! Beep!

This game is great. Actually, let me edit this review: this game has been on the steam store page since 2012 apparently, as an early access. It hit full release 2018. Why? It had a single developer. Not a single developer, as in one company, as in ONE DUDE and his sister writing a lot of the dialogue. This was a passion project. No, it IS a passion project, and one successful enough and projecting enough potential to build a SMALL STUDIO and a second game off of. This game is a hidden gem, and an inspiration to any whom manage to find it on their  own, myself included. If you're here, I hope it is because this has happened, or perhaps a friend recommended this game to you. Now if you'll excuse me, I must go back to slaving away at my glorious mod lists.

OG REVIEW:

Kenshi is a game that you must give time in order to fully enjoy. And don't watch any tutorials or stuff, just explore the game yourself. It is hard and unforgiving, but once you get the hang of it it becomes extremely addicting.

There is no goal so you must make your own, I suggest you just play the game as is without mods and any help first. This way when you discover the game world yourself you will fall in love with the game. You will make your own memories and find interesting things you will love to return to in other playthroughs.

If you are new to the mods, I suggest better minimap mod, squad size increase and recruit prisoners. This way you wil be able to do literally anything in the game.

Kenshi is a squad based sandbox rpg where there is no story beyond what you decide to make of it.   Despite having no defined story or quests to take on, the game has a staggering amount of lore to uncover as you realize that you are living in an age long after the rise and fall of two separate empires, and most organized civilization is only looking out for themselves.

No need to save scum when things go poorly.   Lost battles make you tougher, lost limbs can be replaced with mechanical prosthetics (and are usually superior to meat-based appendages anyway...) and recruits that get eaten alive by the fogmen can be backfilled with drifters you find in bars.  Got caught stealing and thrown into prison, or maybe you made the mistake of pissing off the Holy Nation and find yourself a shaved-head and shackled slave on one of their farms? Thank the game for giving you free toughness and labor skills and break yourself free when the opportunity arises.

Enjoy gearing and skilling up your team and automating jobs back at your base, as you venture out to explore and survive more of the weird moon of Kenshi.

Phenomenal game, honestly if any other game was this janky it would be a negative review, but there are no game breaking bugs that I have ever come across, only minor ones that can always be fixed by a simple reload or just ignored since 99% of bugs are just mild cosmetic one. 

THE GAMEPLAY makes it worth ANY price, the freedom given to the player is unmatched, the landscape is absolutely stunning, the graphics are mediocre but something about the design has you awestruck, I've been using a mod that reduces the texture detail for faster load times and yet the game retains its unmatched in the emotions it stirs in me.

I don't know the word to describe the aesthetic but I absolutely love it, it's a kind of imposing desolation that throws endless questions and intrigue your way, the entire world is this giant puzzle for you to explore and ponder to your hearts content. 

The mechanics are awesome, there's enough room in the combat system to sacrifice going full meta and allows you to stylise your armour and weapons, but also still a challenge that is always pushing you to improve. Every time you venture out a little farther the world just begs to be explored, usually I just enjoy being a trader in games but ended up just getting addicted to venturing out into the world. 

I cannot recommend this game enough, the freedom it gives you allows you to chose your own playstyle is just unmatched.

At first graphics may seem horrible like Old Runescape, but the game play, game mechanics and universe is unique, amazing, tonnes of character. 

You can choose exactly how many characters you want, play RPG solo, or a few more, or a whole army RTS style. Many ways to play the game, be a drug smuggler, steal with stealth or by fighting, bounty hunt, smithing, farming, base building(it is possible to play with no base).

Extremely in depth & amazing progression & combat that is very satisfying, hard to explain everything, but you will quickly understand when you play. Many ways to down or kill, Health bars for every limb, blood meter, you can down people by hitting their limbs or using sharp weapons to drain their blood, etc. To outright kill people you will have to be pretty strong and have high combat stats.

The different weapons are amazing, each weapon & martial arts(fighting unarmed) can all be used to train different stats and all benefit from different stats and each weapon has strengths and weaknesses. Some weapons and Martial Arts can deal massive damage but require multiple stats, full body training to use well. While some weapons like Katanas need only few stats to use and low level characters can use effectively.

There is no artificial requirement lock that needs you to be a certain level or have enough stats to use it, heavy weapons need high strength, you can use the best weapon in the game, Falling Sun(heavy weapon), highest quality version will be the heaviest, on a new char but he will hardly be able to swing and will have slow movement from being overburdened.

Too many good things to mention, just play it.

I have played Kenshi for roughly ~150 hours, I really like the game and the play style.  It feels like a more mobile RIMWORLD.  My only issue with Kenshi is that it crashed, a lot.  The game saves every five minutes which is great, My game crashes about every two hours.  My computer is a four year old Alienware Area 51, 17-inch laptop, maybe my computer is too slow for the game?

"Kenshi" is like the lovechild of a mad scientist's RPG experiment and a post-apocalyptic sandbox on steroids. It's a game where you can start as a one-armed, half-starved nobody in the middle of nowhere and end up... well, probably still a one-armed nobody, but with a slightly better hat!

Picture this: you're wandering through a desolate wasteland, avoiding deadly robots, and trying not to get eaten by giant bugs while carrying a dude who lost his legs in a tragic mishap with a giant hamster wheel. And you know what? It's freaking awesome.

Sure, the graphics might not be cutting-edge, but who needs photorealism when you can build a fortress out of cacti and watch your ragtag band of misfits fend off hordes of cannibals? Plus, the soundtrack? Let's just say it's the kind of music that makes you want to lead a band of warriors into battle... or maybe just go to the grocery store, whatever floats your boat.

In "Kenshi," the world is your oyster, and by "oyster," I mean a hostile, unforgiving wasteland where everything wants to kill you. But hey, where's the fun in playing it safe? So, grab your rusty sword, kiss your social life goodbye, and prepare for a rollercoaster ride through the weirdest, wildest, and most wonderfully messed-up game you'll ever play. Trust me, Kenshi is like the gift that keeps on giving... as long as you're okay with the occasional limb loss and existential crisis.

I enjoyed that this game had a unique premise: you suck, and you're nothing special (not until you strive for it, at least). You start as a character with no skills, and you must grind to improve every stat you want to utilize to experience your journey through Kenshi. 

As a result, the base game is a bit bland in terms of role playing. There's a ton of fun world building, but there isn't much in the way of questing or missions. There are bounties that you can turn in for money, and there are alliances you can make. You can build a base. You can recruit people to your party. Some of them have personalities and a backstory, but for the most part, there is no story in Kenshi other than what you decide upon. 

Kenshi takes place on a moon that has undergone an apocalyptic event. The setting is post apocalyptic, and people have described it as sword punk. Do you want to open up a market and sell goods? Firstly, good luck. Secondly, you can do that with a lot of hard work. Would you like to be a mercenary or a bounty hunter? Again, good luck. But you can do that. Would you like to attempt to start your own township? Good luck. But you can do that. Would you like to form a crew of runners to smuggle drugs out of the swamps? Good luck. (Yes, you can also do that). Would you like to enslave people and just be a general, all-around piece of garbage to others? Yep, you guessed it. You can do that (good luck).

Here's an example of one of my journeys - I spawned into a section of the map ruled by United Cities (forgetting the name of the empire, only now returning to the game after a year, and I'm writing this review before starting up the game - SUPER EXCITED). Anyway, I spawn in, and my character doesn't have anything. I travel around the desert for a bit until I find a small community. Surely I can steal a few supplies, because I'm hungry and malnourished. I'm losing weight quickly, and I'm practically nude. I approach the village, and unfortunately it's a small settlement owned by slavers. They spot me stealing, chase me down, and then lock me up in a cage. 

Now, I know this is crazy, but I refused to quit. I was trapped in those slavers' cages for 78 in-game days. Every day I would practice picking the locks until one day my lockpicking was good enough to free myself. Unfortunately, the cages were high up in a tower right in the middle of town. I would have to sneak my way out of the tower and through the small settlement. I needed to train my sneaking skill. So I did. I'd hide in my cage during the day, and I'd hop out and practice "sneaking" until I got my skill up a bit. Then, I decided to make my break one evening.

I sneaked out of the tower, but I found myself face to face with an evening patrol. Bam. They sent me right back to the cage. Again, I picked locks. Again, I did some sneaking. Again, I was caught. And right back to the cage. There were other prisoners in the cages alongside me, and we were all wasting away as potential slaves. Who knew what these slavers were going to do with us. They barely even interacted with us. Maybe they planned to use us as meat during a famine. Or would sell us to one of the empires.

But then it hit me - I can unlock these prisoners' cages too. So I did. I waited until evening on the 78th day. I unlocked two prisoners' cages, and they bolted down the stairs of the tower and out into the settlement. There were only a few guards watching over the town, and they gave chase. Now was my chance to sneak out, and I did. But it wasn't over yet. I had to make it somewhere safe, and I had no food, weapons, or clothes. Just a set of rags they were kind enough to give me. 

I unlocked my shackles, so my slave status wouldn't draw attention, and I made it to the nearest town. I was fortunate that these people were treasure hunters (or engineers? they're looking for lost technology, I forget). Anyway, they didn't care who I was, and I was able to find a bed to rest. Stole a little food to eat, and I recovered. 

That was just the beginning, though. And for whatever reason, I was hooked.

Anyway, here are my pros and cons, for simpler digestion:

PROS:

Unique premise
Really enjoy the world building
Really enjoy the setting 
Really enjoy the potential stories and mysteries that can abound
Really enjoy the aesthetic 
Enjoy the difficulty, but (see CONS)
There's a dedicated mod community, and many of the mods are amazing
Strangely addicting

CONS:

Poorly optimized 
No story, really
Difficulty is definitely a hindrance
Reliant upon mods to flesh it out into something greater


I really wish there was more, but there's something special about Kenshi. I put 400+ hours in, and I want to go back to experiment with different starting scenarios or making my own stories.

Anyway, I hope this review was legible. I didn't edit much, as I'm excited to hop into the game, but I felt like sharing my excitement in the form or a review. If any part of this interests you, you should give Kenshi a shot. Especially since a prequel is in development. I'm excited to see where this series goes.

Kenshi is a truly unique game I have found myself enjoying for a long period of time. After my initial difficulty in understanding how to interact with the game and figuring out the best ways to stat train, exploring the world and plundering ruins became the normal way to play the game for me. At some point I created a faction for going from zero to hero and waged a war of attrition on all of the various factions. Several of the leaders of factions found themselves ruined by an all powerful cyber beep. Stylistically the game is completely unique and manages to blend the gritty feeling of the wild west with samurais and robots. Despite the time it takes to understand the game and grind character stats, I highly recommend Kenshi to anyone looking for a solid gaming experience.

Second run after getting beaten, arrested and dying on attempting to escape from prison in the first run:
> Start in crappy run down town
> Mine copper for profit
> Decide I will be a miner and sell my ores for profit
> Farm copper and iron
> Make fat stacks
> Hire companion to bodyguard and help mine copper
> Make tons of money
> Decide to buy cow to help carry more copper
> Search in a wasteland for an hour to find someone who sells a cow
> Finally find farmstead in a holy land and buy a cow
> On the way back to my mining camp
> Like 8 bandits sprinting at me on the horizon
> Realize cow is high value target
> Send cow to run away
> Prepare my men to fight
> Accidentally select cow when pressing attack
> Almost scream out loud, scared of losing my nine thousand dollar investment 
> Cow immediately plows through like 4 bandits, tearing off a leg and an arm and leaving a massive pool of blood
> Other guys fight off bandits as cow absolutely destroys the bandits trying to escape
> Cow is insane
> Travel with band of mercenaries and nomads until we reach some town
> Pack of wolves attacks and breaks one of my guys legs
> Guards come from town, a few die to the wolves
> Try to take opportunity to get some sweet guard armor
> Immediately get caught because guy I tried to loot was bleeding out not dead
> Guards attack stealing guy, broken leg guy tries to attack guards and defend teammate, immediately gets rocked
> Both in jail
> Broken leg is super good at lock picking and stealing guy has super high athleticism meaning he can run super fast
> Broken leg unlocks cage and breaks fast guy out
> Fast guy sprints out screaming obscenities, bringing the cow with him
> All guards in town immediately go after him
> Broken leg guy slips out of cage during all the commotion
> Regroup and head back to camp to lay low
> Finally make it back to mining camp
> Start mining
> Group of bandits sneak up and knock my guys out, breaking another leg on the same guy as before in the process
> Bandits immediately devour cow 
> Slavers pull up to see my guys bleeding out on the street with a half eaten cow
> Slavers pick up guy with no broken bones and start to pick up guy with broken leg
> Pack of wolves come out of nowhere and attack slavers
> Slavers barely survive and leave, forgetting my guy with a broken bone on the ground
> Broken bone guy stops playing dead and slowly crawls to nearby town
> Broken bone guy starts healing while enslaved guy plots escape
> While travelling to camp slavers get distracted by giant ostrich beast
> Sprint away with my enslaved athletics 40 guy who runs at 20km/h
> Regroup and lay low until slavers stop looking for escaped slave
> Have existential crisis after realizing all the ore farming I was doing was essentially the same as what they would have me do as a slave
> Cope by rescuing random slave girl who wants to be a fighter
> Train her up by having her carry backpacks of iron
> Adopt a dog while this is going on

> Find cool robot explorer

All of this happened in about 13 hours of gameplay, with no story, no quests, just me playing, with my own goals, in a massive world, meeting random characters. I should say that this game is an amalgam of things I dislike: I don't like slower stat based rpgs, I don't like real time strategy, I don't like survival games, and I find apocalypse games such as fallout to have extremely drab and ugly environments. Yet despite being all these things and more rolled into a giant meat taco, kenshi has me utterly captivated in its gameplay. Everything happens in a fairly non scripted open world/sandbox environment where a lot of the fun is simply experiencing and living in the world. 

No game has ever had me so connected to my character (And ironically, there is no given story to your character) as the only way for your character to improve in something is to experience it for themselves, want to get better at fighting? Go fight then. Want to get tougher? Get beat up more and survive. Want to do anything? Keep failing until you get it right. Whatever doesn't kill you will make you stronger and that is how you progress in this game, the high difficulty comes not from the actual enemies in the world (though they are quite tough) but instead knowing what fights you can and cannot take, all of those stat points mean nothing if your character is dead in the wasteland, and this raw feeling of survival gives you such a will to live and a want to grow to be the strongest, no other game has ever come as close to the feeling of intensity for me as kenshi has. 

Steam says I've only played about 13 hours of this game so far but those 13 hours were so special I felt the uncontrollable urge to post a review. While reading the reviews for this game I was highly skeptical of the freedom it claimed to have as I am used to having controlled freedom such as in a bethesda or rockstar open world game; in games like that there is a huge, lush open world to explore but the story or side quests are only happening in one little dot on the map. This is not that, this is a true open world experience with unbridled freedom where you make your own story, interactions and personal experiences. Not that there is no dialogue, there is some written for interactions in towns that are often deadbeat ironic statements that I find extremely hilarious, and depending on the race/gender of characters in your party they have special things to say to each other about places they visit and things they do in passing that can be an informative or comedic reprieve from the desolate and violent wasteland that surrounds them. 

Despite the world of kenshi being very run down and barren from an outside view, the game still feels full of life and action, even though all that surrounds you is an ancient, utterly destroyed world. While I dislike drab environments with little in them where simply walking around makes me want to throw up, kenshis world is so captivating and deeply atmospheric that I've actually come to like the visuals for the most part. About 99% of the music is also amazing. There is one track (Or maybe its some sort of sound effect) that I find incredibly irritating and loud, but other than that outlier; the simple, haunting melodies which sound like exploring a ghost town perfectly match the atmosphere of wandering and surviving a wasteland alien world. I've only spent a few hours in the world of kenshi so far, but its left more of an impression on me than most games I've put a hundred hours into have. I look forward to exploring more of this world in its vastness; until then, see you space cowboy.

Edit: I've played 30 more hours since this review, my opinion has not changed on this game overall, but there is so much more I could say as I've gotten into it. I would buy this game again on a different account just to review it again

Edit 2: I'm closing in on 300 hours as of right now, I've had many playthroughs, I've died, lost limbs, starved, been enslaved. But I've also been rich, been a master smith, destroyed empires, raided towns, waged war, and been the best in the world. It's up to you.

I've only played this for 2 days, but it MAY be one of the best games my 43 year old self has ever played. I've been complaining since the late 90's about how games are losing their flavor & are too similar. It's all hack & slash or first person shooter. Same controls. Same goals. Same look. Same feel. No soul. 

Why can't they make a 4x game where you micromanage all your cities to the point that even the economy & peasants matter (Crusader Kings 2), but you ACTUALLY have to mine the materials AND farm the land AND trade for resources - ALL while building your structures with wood, stone, copper, etc. Not just a 1 click battle/build? Why can't this game also make a battle simulator where you need to fight your armies with flanking moves, battlefield commanders that you need to train, veteran units that level up, need gear purchased for them, & tactics like false retreats & pincer movements?

Why can't they make a Diablo 2 game where you add the elements of an entire party, & train & skill up more than a basic tree? Throw in Runescape like training but without the boring tedium of just sitting there watching an axe chop a tree for 598232721 hours? Make the training mean something like when I'm carrying my firewood back to base I'm getting stronger? Ya know.... LOGIC? The shopkeeper KNOWS me because we do good business together? I live in that town. I pay my taxes, etc. 

I've often dreamed of this kind of game. Kenshi isn't EVERYTHING I've ever hoped for but it's damn close. It has most of these elements & more devs need to look at this & make a bigger, more detailed, smoother style version of this game (mods probably help some), so that you actually have a fully immersed real world experience where every action matters & every character you come into contact with lives & dies along with you - remembering your every interaction on a tribal, local, regional, factional, & national scale. Play the political game, go solo, make alliances, become the most hated man alive, take over a town, be a simple farmer, or merchant, whatever it is Kenshi allows you to mostly do that. 

Like I said - it's not perfect - but it's the FIRST game that is similar to a game I would have made myself if I COULD make a game. I hope we make 100 more of these instead of League of Legends, Call of Duty, Halo, Fortnite, Palworld, & other trash.  Gamers born from 1960 to 1995 UNITE!!! WE CAN DO THIS!!! WE STARTED THIS REVOLUTION!!! WE CAN START ANOTHER ONE!!! LETS SHOW THESE KIDS WHAT TRUE GAMING IS!! 

FREEEEEEEEEDDDDDOOOOMMMMMMMMM!!!!!!

You just get lost and lose all track of time. Starting with nothing and growing, seeing your first hirelings grow and develop into warriors, farmers, builders or a mix of whatever you want.  It's a total sandbox, so if you want to build a thriving community or a rampaging war band, go for it...

Do you like to suffer? Do you like to starve? Do you like to have your liver eaten by giraffe birds? If you answered yes to any of these questions, Kenshi is the game for you! Be warned, however, that Kenshi is completely unforgiving and unfair. You will die, you will TPK, and you most definitely will suffer. However, because Kenshi was designed by one man on an outdated game engine, it is exploitable. Exploit the game to gain uber stats, to buy all the engineering research you could possibly need, and to reset shop inventories when you inevitably decide to sell bricks of pure THC in order to fuel your crippling addiction to forcing people to read engineering research for hours on end.

Most importantly, however, ignore everyone who says you're playing the game "wrong" or that exploiting fifteen year old bugs is "not playing the game properly." Kenshi is an RPG, yes, but like Rimworld it is also a story generator. Every playthrough will be different despite several guaranteed characters being placed in the world, as combat and theft all work on RNG.

Also skeletons are broken, play all skeletons if you want it to take hours to recruit new people. Or just use mods that allow more random skeleton characters to spawn. Or use the recruit prisoners mod to reprogram a certain skeleton army that is just waiting for another skeleton to find them. Or use both. I don't care. Having a company of hardened robot badasses is far more entertaining than being a squishy human and starving because you grew your faction too big too quickly. Martial artist skeletons are doubly broken. If you need an example, just go attack Tinfist and watch as he completely wipes your twenty strong party in seconds.

Kenshi is one of the most open ended RPGs you will ever play, being given the choice to play however you want within the confines of what the game does limit you to.

Want to become a humble trader? Go right for it. Want to join one of the three major factions and help take down their enemies? Absolutely can. Want to be a solo wanderer, building your own legend and fighting powerful, mythical figures? You can, but you'll struggle to build your strength to start. Want to be a warmongering ruler that brings all to their knees, peeling the skin from their flesh, feeding the corpses of your enemies to the bone dogs and burning their cities to the ground? Go for it.

On top of all of that, there's a large amount of history built into the world. Wondrous sights, eerie locations and chilling sights. It wont be handed onto you on a silver plate though, you'll have to find it for yourself by exploring every inch of the world, digging through ancient ruins. Maybe that skeleton companion you recruited will have a unique insight to a location?

All of that to say that if you're desiring a game that lets you run free within the world that was made for you to play in, absolutely pick it up. At any price. It's a wholly unique experience that you'll be hard pressed to find even among the indie game space, let alone more mainstream titles.

If you are interested in this game I have to warn you going in - you will have a very rough time in the beginning. You will be hunted. You will be enslaved. You will have limbs chopped off. You will be chased across the map by robots screaming "POLICE!" as they cut down anything and anyone in their way. You will lead those robots into the Fishpeople capital, and watch as they butcher the town leaving behind plenty of loot. You will watch the carnage too long, not yet realising that the robots now have one singular goal - to kill you. Eventually you will lead the robots through enough cities and innocent bystanders that they are no longer a threat. You will find crab people that refuse to sell you anything as you are one of the disparaged "crabless". Best you purchase a pet crab first then. You will look up from the screen and it is now 4am. That's ok, you need to get started on building a base to start a wheat farm, so you can grow enough wheat to brew Grog, which will sell in the United Cities for a pretty penny. Its a shame you settled in the swamps though, some curious folks live there and they are just thrilled to find a soft target to loot. Guess its time to hire protection, train some soldiers and build some crossbow turrets. Before you know it, you have spent the last 24 hours getting your face beat in so you can make beer for a bunch of shitty nobles and slavers. And it was worth every second.

I knew nothing much about this game when I bought it on sale. I can now safely say it is epic! It's not in a perfect state, but it has thousands of hours of amazing playtime to offer if you can overlook some blemishes. I've only explored about 5-10% of the world so far (my Steam playtime is a lie as I've spent about twice as long again playing offline). I have just hit day 100 in-game.

What I've found is that when anything buggy happens with path finding, hit Ctrl+Shift+F11. If that doesn't fix it, save and reload. If one of your squad gets stuck, you can save and load then check the "Reset squad positions" checkbox to move everyone to the selected characters position.

To ensure I got the most out of the game, I spent a day just researching mods I might like for my first play-through and came up with this (mod order matters and I think I got this right, please reply if not)...

[olist]
    [*]Unofficial Kenshi Patch
    [*]Compressed Textures Project
    [*]Reduced Weather Effects
    [*]Dark UI
    [*]Nice Map [Tpg + Zones + Zone names + Roads]
    [*]Fixing Clipping Issues
    [*]More Names!
    [*]Little Better Farm Fences
    [*]Martial Arts Fast Dodger: Revised
    [*]Attack Slots x3
    [*]256 Recruitment Limit
    [*]Bounties Galore!
    [*]Leisure Objects and Furniture
    [*]Slopeless (Nexus version)
    [*]SCAR's pathfinding fix (Nexus version)
    [*]SCAR's Better ai for NPCes (Nexus version)
    [*]New Weapons Dissemination Mod
    [*]Let's Talk
    [*]Recruitable Prisoners - with dialogue (pls read description)
    [*]Reactive World
    [*]RP & RW Compatibility Patch
    [*]Profitable Slavery
[/olist]

I was aiming for an actual post-apocalyptic experience, hence for instance "Attack Slots x3". I don't see why starving thugs should wait to fight you one-by-one.

In terms of caveats from this selection of mods, I guess you could Zerg Rush through the game if you built a huge squad as soon as you work out how to recruit prisoners (assuming you could afford to feed them all). Just show restraint with recruitment, especially if you want to go for even more attack slots. More attack slots makes very early game much harder, but once you have enough dudes to vastly outnumber enemy squads, it makes it much easier.

I still haven't figured out how to sell slaves and I haven't needed to (perhaps Bounties Galore! is all you need).

Feedback about my selected Nice Map mod is that it's a bit spoliery seeing region names first play-through. I didn't really pay that much attention to the region names on the map to be honest, but having the roads was very useful. Perhaps disable the map mod until you feel the need for it.

I feel like "Let's Talk" made it easier for me to recruit prisoners by ensuring the dialog was always available, but that may have been because I didn't understand how the prisoner dialogue was triggered. The author has published a google sheets document which explains the technique to use on each faction to recruit them.

Newbie Advice: So after several attempts and three retries I figured out the best way to play is to roam first then build your base. Strengthen a small crew and build their stats, and choose your location wisely. Different areas offer different factions coming to your base and demanding something. The easiest starting location would be next to the hub and away from holy nation. So far only bandits come to my base which are easier to deal with. Next thing you want to do is to make sure you start farming asap, esp cactus and wheat, so you can make food. Food is such a huge constant in the game, even the bandits who come to your base try to steal it. Attack animals who roam to your base and take their meat. You can cook uncooked meat in a camp fire or cook station, camp fires cost nothing to build.

Other tidbits: Bugs aren't affected by acid rain or acid water but will be attacked on site by the holy nation if they roam close to their territory. Every race has some interesting flaws and perks. I honestly think the bugs are the best race as far as perks go. The slave route is the best way to get early and easy stats. Robots require no food, but they steadily lose health stats even after repair. You might have to replace limbs at some point if they get too weak.

Kenshi is the result of a passionate night of love between a single player survival game and Rimworld. And yes, it has the best of both parents.

Phenomenal experience.

Kenshi is a harsh and brutal world, and your characters are far from special. Hell, most of them start off so far below average that the first few hours involve a LOT of running from malnourished paraplegic bandits because they WILL mess you up.

It's not like Dark Souls in the sense that you can't lose. You can (and probably will) enjoy a lot of total party wipes at the start. But it is VERY Dark Souls in the sense that the only real way to lose is to give up. If you persevere, your characters can come back from almost any setback. And there are plenty of setbacks; Starving bandits, Cannibals, colossal monsters, unreasonably bloodthirsty goats, famine, loss of limb, slavers, fanatical religious bigots, lethal remnants of fallen empires and more are out there to find.

The world is huge and varied, although arid deserts do tend to dominate the continent. Finding a regular source of food that's also safe is a challenge, as the lush biomes are filled with dangerous creatures too. AAt the start you'll want to stick close to the big towns for protection, and you can make easy money scavenging the corpses of bandits that tried their luck against armed guards. Maybe buy and renovate house there, turn it into a little base, and you can upgrade it with research and crafting benches, beds to heal in, maybe a shop counter to sell loot.

At some point though the cities will become suffocating, and you'll want to establish your own. There is plenty of desolate unpopulated land out there, each biome with unique bounties and hazards. Build walls, mount defensive crossbows on the gates, expand your capabilities with advanced buildings, farmlands, refineries, even sophisticated electronics (some of those fallen empires were VERY advanced) Enjoy visiting traders selling you all kinds of cool stuff (and buying yours), repel attacks, fix up and imprison the survivors and tempt them to join your cause. Develop some of your people into master smiths and outfit your best fighters with weapons and armour you might never see on sale in the cities.

Your group can become a world-changing force, with patience and calculated risk. Maybe you'll topple all the factions that endorse slavery? Or finally break the cannibal hordes threatening all societies? Or become the ruling tyrant of your own fearsome empire? To say Kenshi is open-ended isn't really doing justice to the scale and breadths your ambitions can reach.

So yeah, extremely positive recommendation, with the caveats that it is difficult, unforgiving, and a bit janky. It's an astounding game and deserves your attention.

With full confidence, this is one of the best indie games ever made, and largely can be said to have predated the addictive, untethered gameplay of trendy survival games like PalWorld.
Kenshi to be straight, is no Palworld, its poorly optimized, laughably ugly, and full of odd holes in the lore and flavor of the game despite there barely being any to begin with.  Polished is not the word Id use when talking about Kenshi and the loading times and graphical issues in the game can be brutal. 

All that being said, my only recommendation to avoid Kenshi is if you value your time at all. Losing entire days to this game has been a bad habit I've been needing to break. So let's talk about all of the things Kenshi does superbly

- Very few to almost zero bad bugs, many hilarious good bugs.
This game works, in 90 hours almost nothing has broken my save despite an odd city failing to populate correctly like once, and this is easily fixed with a simple import. On the other hand, this game is notorious for its exploits, most of which the developer almost certainly has left in on purpose, such as rinsing stolen tags with an Item furnace, or the various nonsensical ways of power training most stats. Kenshi is one of the few games the average player exploits as if its a core gameplay feature and doesnt feel even a shred of guilt due to how grindy and difficult the game is otherwise.  I would go as far to say that I actually feel a sense of accomplishment after exploiting this game, because most exploits require a ton of setup to even pull off.

- Incredible world design, getting lost in the huge variety of the games zones, insanely conflicted in which region I want to develop my base in. The game has over 20 zones and I find myself wanting to build a base in all of them. Sure I could just build a base in the ideal places like Shem or the Border Zone, but Im oddly fond of building a base in places that no sane player would try to build.   The Swamp? Between the worst load times in the game and those absolutely diabolical, devilish, fiendish abominations known as Blood Spiders as well as the crop eating Swamp Raptors,  you have to have the patience of a saint to build your base here. But alas, The Swamp has not only access to some of the best Hemp farming in the game and a great base for a Hashish drug operation, but you have some of the most fun world interactions of any region with the "Gang Wars" setup of the Swamp and the fact that you can enlist the massive Hounds gang as your own secondary fighting force for your base to help defend against raids.   Verge? The sky shoots beams of fire at all your non skeleton characters, so naturally, an all Skeleton base it is! The upshoot? Literally no raids will ever attack you in Verge because no bandits are insane enough to go there.

I could yammer on more for hours, but ultimately this is one of the most truly unique and wonderful experiences Ive had as a gamer of 25 years, and I can't wait for the 2nd edition with a bigger budget.

Fun and immersive sandbox RPG / colony sim with a huge world to explore and mess with. You will need an SSD and a decent PC to really enjoy this game in my opinion since not having draw distance and NPC render distance cranked to max messes with AI and world generation rules badly. 

The game is unforgiving of mistakes so if you stay true to an ironman style of play you will probably restart a lot unless you're following some sort of guide especially on your first play through. Those funny giraffes can be real trouble. 

I highly recommend Kenshi Genesis as a standalone and complete overhaul you can get for free on the workshop as well. I am having a great time with it.
Free to choose however you'd like to play in this open ended, lore rich, unforgiving environment.

After a whopping 450 hours into Kenshi, I can confidently say that it touched me in a unique way and i loved every minute of it. The game's vast open world and unforgiving nature make every decision matter. The freedom to shape your own group of nobodies, that get eaten on the first playthrough, from building a massive outpost to leading a band of busty shek lady warriors, is fantastic. 

Kenshi's depth lies in its complexity – the learning curve is steep, but once you figure out the crafting and bounties system everything clicks into place! The dynamic world, filled with diverse factions and ever-evolving events, keeps each playthrough feeling fresh and unpredictable.

While the graphics may not be cutting-edge in the vanilla Kenshi, mods and ReShades fixes up the limitations OGRE engine.  AND THE ATMOSPHERE.....omg.. The game's soundtrack complements the desolate beauty of the landscapes, enhancing the overall experience.

Combat is both brutal and tactical, requiring thinking.. The constant threat of roaming bands of Reavers and Crabs and so on will leave you on the edge of the seat, and never leave your squad travelling on 3x speed unattended. The sense of accomplishment in overcoming challenges is very satisfying.

Kenshi isn't for everyone, especially those seeking hand-holding or a linear narrative, because Kenshi doesn't have a story, the story is yours to make. And if the idea of carving your own path in a harsh, post-apocalyptic world sound like your jam, go for it.. 

Kenshi stands as a testament to the potential of indie game development and dreams of Chris Hunt. It's not just a game, it's an adventure that leaves a lasting impression long after the 450-hour mark.

Picked this up during the winter Sale.  I am using an ARC 750 Limited GPU, so the issues that I am about to describe may not apply to all.   

I have issues with CTD with Kenshi.  Sometimes I can barely get the game to run, others it will be solid for hours.  Mods or no mods it makes no difference.  I stay on current drivers for the ARC drivers seem to have issues with DX11.

Two biggest of the fixes have been to enable virtual memory for the drive that has Kenshi installed.  It shouldn't matter, but it seems to.  It also slowed load times. :( Relocating the install folder to a SSD helped with the load times.  The other is to find the steam article on Kenshi mod load order and follow it.

Even with all of the issues that I have had, I have still racked up nearly 250 hours, of play time, in a month. I'm not sure that I could fully tell you why though.  I enjoy the relative freedom, the early game struggle, and the ability to automate some of the more onerous tasks. 

I would like to see it still being improved or supported, but  I can appreciate the community spotlights done to highlight mods that are available in the workshop, or on Nexus if you are so inclined.  Also, the developer is supposedly working on Kenshi 2.
Just as addictive as Rimworld with a more dynamic world. It can be buggy at times but mods and a thriving helpful community make everything better. A must for for lovers of the genre.

The experience is something I find hard to describe. It's been a while since I have played, but sometimes I still think back to this strange world. A ruined continent on some forgotten dustball spinning around a distant star. The shattered remnants of an ancient empire imploded by its own transgression of all technological and ethical bounds. Bizarre alien beasts and sentient hiveminds sharing this hostile landscape with who can only be described as descendants of human colonists as well as certain species which share uncanny resemblance to earthling fauna, though perhaps altered long ago by twists of natural selection or mad science. It is eerily beautiful. Or is it beautifully eerie?

The gameplay is distinct as well. There are several unique starting positions for a new 'campaign.' You can play as any of the sentient races of this world, with several clans or classes within each to choose from, each with their own inherent strengths and weaknesses. You can begin as a naked one-armed beggar or as a magical-sword-wielding warrior hunted by cultist zealots. You can be an immortal robot, or an exiled hive drone. You can control a group of characters of different races. It is an exploration-survival game. Your character(s) can get hungry, they need to rest or repair when they get injured. You can get melted by acid rain, eaten alive by bloodsucking spiders, or robbed and left for dead by ninjas. You can even lose your limbs, cursed to crawl the dunes on your belly, or wield only one-handed weapons, but perseverance in spelunking some sunken ruins can reward you with cybernetic legs that will carry you faster than any enemy, or arms that will enable you to wield the most powerful weapons without impediment.

Yet there are still pockets of civilization. Villages, towns and cities you can crawl back to if you can stop the bleeding and keep from starving, where you can purchase cheap prosthetics and a loaf of bread. The locals will pay for a job well done, and the soldiers will remember your face if you help them in battle, or get caught doing wrong. Most of these societies practice some form of caste system and/or legal slavery. Some of them strongly dislike outsiders, to the point where the locals will insult or harass you or your party, and in extreme cases their soldiers will attack on sight, beating you unconscious and enslaving you, or just outright killing you. In the most 'liberal' cities, the soldiers will arrest and enslave you if you don't have enough money to prove that you are not a beggar. To reach the free towns where no tyrant dare send his minions, you must outrun deadly beasts and death machines, fend off slaver gangs and cannibal hordes, climb lonely peaks and seek hidden valleys. Yet even among these far-flung outposts, a name carries weight. Offend a faction badly enough, and they will hunt you forever.

You will meet many potential friends along your journey, who may at first appear as fiends or foes, to recruit for your own party. You can roam from town to town as a mercenary band, or you can settle down and establish a base of operations. You can even build your own village out in the wastes and set dozens of characters to work. Become self-sufficient and venture out across the jagged plains, the acid swamps, and the ashen wastes to uncover pieces of powerful technology lost over thousands of years of environmental chaos and civil war.

Tame a pack of wild dogs and maybe a herd of goats. Smuggle drugs and bootleg liquor. Free the slaves and befriend the insane. Assemble a robot army, or raise a band of warrior priests. Murder everyone, burn every village, and stamp out the light of civilization. If it pleases you. Can't honestly say that I've seen any other game quite like this one.

Kenshi stands tall as a testament to the essence of true open-world gaming. With hundreds of hours invested, I find myself continually drawn back into its vast, unforgiving landscape, and the allure of the unknown never ceases to captivate me.

One of Kenshi's crowning achievements lies in its unparalleled depth and complexity. In a gaming industry saturated with generic titles, Kenshi emerges as a breath of fresh air with its unique and original concept. The game seamlessly blends elements of survival, strategy, and RPG, offering a gaming experience that is both challenging and immensely rewarding.

What truly sets Kenshi apart is the absolute freedom it grants to players. In this expansive sandbox, the choices are yours to make, and the consequences are yours to bear. Whether you choose the path of a trader, a slaver, a hunter, or something entirely different, Kenshi accommodates your ambitions. The open-ended nature of the game allows for boundless creativity, turning each playthrough into a personal saga of triumphs and tribulations.

The world of Kenshi is not just a backdrop; it's a character in itself. The harsh, post-apocalyptic landscape is rife with danger and opportunity. The ever-present threat of hostile factions, the diverse array of wildlife, and the dynamic weather system contribute to an immersive experience that keeps you on your toes. The depth of lore and the intricacies of the game world add layers of intrigue, making every discovery a moment to savor.


In conclusion, Kenshi is not merely a game; it's a masterpiece of player agency, offering a canvas for your unique story to unfold. If you seek a game that challenges your strategic prowess, rewards creativity, and immerses you in a world where every decision matters, Kenshi is an absolute must-play. Embrace the freedom, chart your own destiny, and discover why Kenshi remains a paragon of open-world excellence.

A brutally unfair, janky and rather old-looking sandbox RPG with base-building and trading elements. Instead of holding your hand Kenshi slaps it away, stabs you with a rusty wakizashi and throws you to the wolves - or sometimes to cannibals. Yet despite all the clunkiness, my all-time favourite game with incomparable emergent storytelling, screenshot-worthy sceneries and some of the best gameplay I have ever experienced (for newcomers, [F1] shows gameplay tips!). The modding community has done an amazing job expanding the gameplay and lore - and sometimes just joking around. 

Starting options are widely customizable (+mods) but usually you begin as just a weak nobody who gets thrashed by a single starved thug or a random baby goat. Beaten by slavers and spending the rest of your days labouring in chains may even be preferable to getting literally ripped to pieces and eaten by the more horrifying local fauna. Not that the game cares, sandbox world just keeps going even when all that is left of you and your potential friends is a pair of sandals, slowly buried into the sand. 

Kenshi's philosophy is that doing something will make you better at it. Obviously crafting, sneaking and such work this way but also taking punches only improves by getting hit, bonus EXP if you are already coughing blood and missing an arm. Learning to fight efficiently is a constant struggle of seeking battles you can win just barely - and then survive long enough to recover and try again. As long as you live, limbs can be replaced in an inventory screen much like other equipment and every battle will make you stronger, but it truly is pitiful for a mighty warrior to collapse in acidic rain out of hunger or bloodloss, having spent all the food and bandages despite hauling a backpack full of lost technology valuable enough to buy a city. Quicksave is a lifesaver, especially when your characters get stuck in terrain. 

[b]Story[/b] is a vague concept as the world is vast and there is no main quest. Explore at your own risk, talk to people (also at your own risk) and always stay alert. There is an immense amount of interactions, dialogue and quests but they all need to be found - and sometimes even getting near them is simply too dangerous before training just for that purpose. Find or buy some muscle, though you may need to train and equip them as well. [i]"Go on new recruit, get your legs torn off by that little spider so I can slap these faster robot legs on you!".[/i] Many wondrous sights await and I will not spoil them, just be ready to run away when needed. 

[b]Combat[/b] is kind of turn-based and in vanilla game, only one entity can melee attack another at one time leading to either a hit, a miss or a blocked attack. But the time windows before another entity can attack are short indeed and outnumbered side needs serious skill superiority to win. This formula is skewed by hitting someone "by accident" as even fists have enough range to hit even three targets at once, where your intended target may defend itself but the two accidentals can't - though they may also have attacks queued at you. This creates some incredibly frustrating situations when a big enemy bodies 5 of your best warriors due to poor positioning. And sometimes your last man standing manages to swing an absolute homerun and chop multiple enemies down by sending their legs flying, saving your entire party. And then there are rather overpowered crossbows that don't care about your silly attack rules and just headshot you in the middle of a duel. Hilariously becoming better at not hitting your friends in the back gets easier only when shooting them by "accident". Luckily/unfortunately it is completely random what body part each attack hits. 

[b]Base-building[/b] is at minimum a campfire and a bedroll, at most a completely self-sufficient farm/factory fortress capable of creating the best meals, armour and machinery known to the continent. Also awesome weapons, though you can never surpass the legendary Meitous made by Cross and scattered across the factions. Starting a permanent base of your own is bound to get noticed, so be ready for a fight or serious bribery. Some weirdos even attack you just to have a good scrap. 

[b]Visuals[/b] are both ugly and beautiful: Animations look clunky but sometimes sync wonderfully, and the weapons hitting hard really feel like they hurt (my personal record is scattering 6 limbs high into the air in one swing of a plank). Textures are definitely dated and unsightly. But the scenery and especially night skybox are often so gorgerous my wandering party has a lunch break while I am busy taking screenshots. And then I take more screenshots as they do everything they can to survive another unfair mess I just got them into.

Unique post-apocalyptic world where everyone uses swords and crossbows to fight across beautifully-designed lands. You can adventure solo, recruit a small army of playable characters, be a stealthy assassin or a heavily-armored samurai, build your own small city or be always on the move. You can take on hordes of cannibals, go bounty hunting or just rob people in the street, get captured into slavery and find a way out,  and depopulate entire cities if you are strong enough. Be a human, robot or a stick-alien person. There is no magic or skill system besides basic stats that affect stealing, blacksmithing rate and quality, farming, cooking, strength, speed, toughness and so on.

The game has deep steamy jungles, sand dune deserts, rocky wastelands, outlaw swamp cities, ninja fortresses, high-tech bunkers, beautiful temperate landscapes and so much to see. The game "doesn't care about you" and you are not the chosen one. You can easily get beaten by starving bandits and left bleeding on the side of the road for days to either die slowly or become a slave. You'll have to choose battles wisely and you may want to hire a sidekick early on to hide nearby and carry your broken body to safety. On the flipside your character gets tougher by just getting beaten, so if you can deal with being crushed into the dust a few times, you'll eventually be a force to be reckoned with.

There is some tedium in the game if you have a lot of characters at once, it is not fun to build a camp and make sure each person rests to recover the health after a bloody battle. The recovery is very slow and tedious to manage one by one. The experience also goes up very slowly. If you don't have much time to play, you can get mods that increase healing rate and experience rate which makes the game more fun. Also it helps to have a smaller gang to alleviate the tedium of managing beds and orders.

The base building is fairly involved and you'll need to get research books, build defenses, build a power source, mine resources and farm. You can assign in job priorities so people automatically work, including having them opportunistically get meat and skins from animals your guards have killed.

There's a lot to explore and do, but you have to make your own fun in a way. It's somewhat of a sandbox type of game that feels a little empty if you're used to games telling you what to do all the time.

Overall a fun game that is worth the price.

Set up a steel plate production chain to have a character smith a million weapons to become a master sword smith, then equip a party with high grade weapons he crafts and send them out to explore to find new research materials to improve and automate your production. It does have a bunch of quality of life and technical issues, but if this sounds like your kind of game you'll almost certainly get your money's worth out of it.

This game is not perfectly polished. There are plenty of bugs. Sometimes the AI (for the characters I'm in control of) frustrates me beyond belief. Sometimes pathing is unpredictable. Some things are frustrating due to design flaws.

The basic concept of the game is that it's the best f****** I've ever f****** played. It's beautifully combined top down strategy themes like resource farming and city building with RPG elements that make you feel your character is a real person with a real effect on the world. I mean it's just absolutely incredible. You can just train a few people in your party and become almost anything you want. You can run a base out of a city in one of the many amazingly written NPC factions, or you can build your own settlement and run your own resources and defense.

Everything has its consequences. If you build within the safe borders of a great nation, they may come make you pay taxes or ask for food tribute. But if you build in the wastes then bandits may come get you. There aren't just universal bandits either. Every place has its own factions with their own incredibly well written interests. You feel like you're in a genuinely living world when you play Kenshi. You can change the political landscape, or discover storylines that feel absolutely ancient. The lore and history make you feel like this is a real place, and you're a real person living within it. The living world affects you, and you affect it.

I mean seriously, my f****** god it's the most incredible game I've ever seen. It's literally a kind of game I've been fantasizing about for YEARS. So many games tried, but Kenshi actually did it. It's like open world, fully completely open world, but once you get a feel for it there are also storylines you can get involved in. Unlike bethesda games (which I love), it doesn't feel like anything you do is a meaningless story. It's not like you go help some inkeeper kill the biggest rat that respawns later. You go capture the leader of the region's bandits, and then less of those bandits spawn. You take down the leader of a major faction, and the other factions take over those cities.

I could go on forever. But get Kenshi. You'll be frustrated by some of the unpolished stuff. It can also be super hard, but if that puts you off look up some walkthrough stuff. If you like city builders, resource management, and/or RPGs and character stats, you will love it.

[b]Update (2024-01-14):[/b]
I've now compiled a 99-mod collection that I thoroughly enjoy playing. With the help of a Kenshi mod manager tool created by members of the Kenshi modding community, fans of the world of Kenshi can safely configure their mod list order fairly confidently now. Plus, with the use of the Re-Shade software, can have an amazing graphics experience within game.

I love the challenge of surviving in the world of Kenshi, where I choose how I survive and what my goals are in this huge, challenging open world. Danger is my constant companion that I must overcome to survive.

There is so much to like about this game. The concept is very engaging and satisfying. There is so much to do and experience and the leveling of skills is thru actual usage of them.  

There is a learning curve, which is mostly learning how to not starve to deathat the start and how to avoid death that is around every corner.  Once you get the hang of the game it becomes more easier to keep alive.  Got to love a game that rewards getting beat up by thimngs in the world as leveling your toughness,  where losing limbs gives you a chance to add an upgrade for the limb.   Nothing like throwing your pack animal on your shoulder and running across the desert,  being chase by bandits to level your toughness and strength, where you can feign death, to avoid further damage, just make sure they aren't carnivorous animals or canibals though.

Kenshi is the best open world games I have ever placed. Extremely under rated for what this game provides. There are two thing holding this game back.

The game engine:  Pop in, load screens, slow down due to too much on screen, I think there is some memory leak for long play sessions. Save often, and reload the game time to time to fix issues. I also found exported characters into a new game closing out and loading an old save seem to fix minor issues.

The play style you must except: Some of you most important skills come from running from battles and getting knocked out over and over again. if you keep that in mind you will enjoy the game. 

Also don't even think of building a base for a long time. Buy a house in town and use that as a home base till late game.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Well over 1000 hours into Kenshi and I feel I have barely scratched the surface of what this world has to offer. This isn't Skyrim, you will not be given a list of "quests" complete with a compass and map markers. Create your own story, whether that is taking over the world or tying yourself up and waiting to be feasted upon. I like getting my shit pushed by everything from wildlife (that may also eat me afterwards, which is a bonus) to bandits (who will rob me and leave me mangled for the afore mentioned wildlife)... Even the weather and environment is out to get you.
