This is the first game I bought since I built my PC and I can say I am super happy with this game. Even though this game is pretty old it is still super addictive and fun. There seems to be always something to do weather it's fighting other factions, building up your squad(s), or navigating and exploring the world, the possibilities are endless. Now there are things I would like to see in the sequel that would make the game in my opinion better. (This only concerning base game, I am not talking about any mods that can be added to the game)

THINGS I WOULD ADD/CHANGE
1. the ability to dual wield weapons
  - Now this is a minute detail but I think it is weird that I am able to equip a character with two weapons as their primary weapon but they don't duel wield. I would suggest that if a stat like martial art or something is high enough you should be able to dual wield.

2. Giving us the ability to name buildings/have signs
  - When I walk in town in the world of Kenshi I see that different buildings are labeled bars, armory, general shop, and police stations. However us as the player are not able to do that(as far as I know), which I feel we should be able to be able to. We are able to label our town / city why not buildings too. this would make organizing a lot easier and we would be able to distinguish what building is for what like having a building to just make weapons, another for Armour, robotics, a general shop just to sell things.

3. A better way to sell goods
  - I love how in this game we are able to sell goods, but I see it is not a reliable source of income to me. Now it could just be how I am playing the game but people don't really buy things consistently. the only thing that consistently sells it's grog, but thing like Armour, weapons, robotics barely sell. I think it would be good Idea to get a list of who roams your city and what they are looking for to maximize profits
4. AI cores easier to find
  - Now don't get me wrong I am not trying to make this game to easy but I feel like there should more reliable/guaranteed places for these things to spawn. I hate going to a ruin and seeing that it's empty and basically wasting my time. I get not making to obvious but there should some sort of pattern or scheme. (Maybe there is but I haven't realized it yet)
5. Easier way to ally with factions or turn in bounties.
  - for this one I just suggest a quest system or once you find some one of not they tell you where to turn them in. I think the way bounties work now in Kenshi is kind of confusing and hard to find the these people.
6. More hairstyles please.
  -I get this game was put out a long time ago but for the next game new hair styles would be dope. can we at least get the generic Afro lol.
7. dog/goat back packs. 
  - I just find it dumb that they have back pack slots but can't give them back packs. (I know there is a mod for this but would like in the main game)
Overall this is a great game and definitely worth the money. glad that this was the game to truly start my PC experience.

This game is definitely interesting. If you've read other reviews and you're excited, do yourself a favor and try it; you'll probably like it or at least have a memorable experience. However, if you're on the fence, here's some reasons why you might want to play something else:

- It seems like the most effective way to make money in the game is to get aggro from one of the bandit/slaver factions, then lead them to a town and have the guards beat them up so you can loot the bodies. This is both not that fun and also not that realistic.
- While being able to survive a fight is cute at first, in practice it means there's often not any consequence for losing a fight. Either you die / get enslaved and load an old save file or you take a bunch of damage and then wait a while for your people to heal.
- There's a lot of waiting in the game. Waiting to heal. Waiting to walk to your destination. Waiting for your crops to grow.
- There are some pretty bad bugs in the game. I one time walked into a town and it was completely empty of NPCs. I've also had land ownership carry over between save files of completely different characters. 
- There's very little in the way of unique dialogue like a classic CRPG and it makes the world feel very robotic.
- If you do try base building, prepare for an onslaught of raids constantly interrupting what you are doing and forcing you to wait several minutes as your only engineer recovers in bed.

If you're looking for an open ended RPG with several distinct regions and cultures and an emphasis on survival and looting, try Outward instead.
If you're looking for a base building game where you have to fend off enemy raids and avoid starvation, consider Rimworld instead.

This game is incredible, but very difficult.

Started my journey as nobody with rags. Looted ruins for some money doing many runs to and from to sell scraps for money. I stole from shops and accumulated a squad.

We made a small farming outpost and we're doing well selling our produce while I sent a thief to towns stealing (often getting caught at the start). Unfortunately, the holy nation didn't like the amount of women and other nationalities at our outpost and declared war on us. We barely made it out, but had accumulated some wealth at the outpost.

We moved into the swamp and built a fortress with six mounted turrets. We have been defending against three waves of raptors every harvest cycle. Waves of spiders and bandit attacks. 

We have missing limbs, walls that need to be repaired, and we are all dying of starvation. 43hrs well spent struggling to find a home and survive.

This game is very difficult. Will play again!

Kenshi is a game about a philosophy of growth. What really makes this game great is that it can give you a feeling of real progression. Learning a skill in real life can take years, even decades. Kenshi's appeal, at least for me, is that it can provide the experience of learning a skill in just a few hours. If you like the feeling of getting better at something, and want a challenge to work towards, pick this one up!

"Kenshi for PC is an incredible game that throws you into a post-apocalyptic world filled with endless possibilities. You can explore ruins, build empires, and forge your path in a way that's entirely your own.

The mods for Kenshi are a blast, adding tons of fun and new elements to the game. But I'll admit, finding and managing mods can be a bit of a hassle. The community's creativity is awesome, but the organization of mods could use some improvement.

Despite that, Kenshi is a must-play. Its freedom and depth, combined with the modding scene's offerings, create an unforgettable gaming experience that'll keep you hooked for hours."

Possibly one of my favourite games of all time. I looked at it initially years ago and thought that it looked like an MMO, never bothering to properly check what the game was - rather just assuming I wouldn't like it. Bought it on sale at half price and WOW I was so surprised at what the game actually offered. 

It's one of the few games out there where every mechanic you see in the world can be replicated. Cities that are established can be taken over by you but not in the way where 'hur dur I do 5 quests and the city is mine' but in the sense of you have to have manually recruited and trained up an army large enough to do it. The training aspect? You have to get beaten to near death to increase strength, it is phemomemal lmao. Highly recommend watching a playthrough just to see the levels of mechanics and systems involved because there's a reason it's compared to Dark Souls levels of unfair and its so addictive.

It's the most raw 'do what you want but you aren't special' type of game that I've ever played. You're not the dragonborn, you've been afforded nothing. You start from zero and that aspect of the game made me enjoy it massively because its Skyrim's magic of exploring a Souls-like world with that level of difficulty involved without having ANYTHING handed to you because 'you're the chosen one' - you are no one. The game is what you make of it and it is just class.

I have played a modest amount of Kenshi to the point that I know enough about the mechanics and feel of the game to know that this game is one that appeals to me, and I can recommend for fans of the genre(s).

Other games have covered many of the core gameplay mechanics, but never quite in this combination, or with this kind of execution. The roaming nutjobs that will chase you and scream nonsense at you remind me of borderlands. The nuclear wasteland / cyberpunk vibe is reminiscent of the fallout games. The combat resembles the top down dungeon crawlers such as diablo or torchlight, albeit without any instancing or map changing (though there are frequent loading bars as the game will pull assets as you travel). The variance in skill and progression reminds me of the elder scrolls games - usage increases competency. But the way in which these systems and world building interact with each other makes this quite unique. 

Lo-Fi games nailed the tone - The world feels desolate. Starving bandits are skinny, and if you get knocked out they will steal food from you. Much of the world looks like it was cobbled together from trash out of necessity. Dangerous creatures look menacing and deadly. There are a variety of 'biomes' with different environmental effects that make me feel like I live on a planet which has suffered - and often morals go flying out of the window. I should feel sorry for the starving bandits,  but I don't. I'm too busy worrying about where my next meal will come from, or avoiding that group of cannibals to care about if they will collapse from starvation on my next town cycle. 

Levelling feels organic as difficulty ramps up and you take on more challenging foes, but will brutally punish you if you wander into a lethal area under-equipped or unprepared. That said, as long as you don't outright die then most situations can be recovered from - even the loss of a limb can be offset with robotics, and this can even be beneficial if you are able to acquire a masterwork limb and maintain it with the pricey repair kits. 

There is a tutorial (of sorts) that will explain the UI, menus and some basic mechanics to get you started, but this game will not do any hand-holding for you. While the learning curve is fairly steep (especially given the complexity of this game), and you will likely be incapacitated, incarcerated, mutilated and/or murdered working out what you can and can't do, you won't ever be pestered to go here or do that before you can make progress. This offers a great deal of freedom to get started -Want to be a trader? perfectly possible - get started with a bit of mining, sell to the local store, buy a pack mule and start your trading empire. Want to lead a squad of crack martial artists? hire some bodies in the local towns and pick off the bandits, work up to bounties, and crack some skulls. Want to start a homestead? build a base, put up walls and defensive turrets, and start manufacturing the things you will need to survive. Want to be night-prowler and rob the place blind? sneak around at night, and empty the shelves of all their goodies. Sneak to the next town over, and sell them at a profit. Oh, then steal back the thing you originally stole, for good measure.

I managed to solve basics of Kenshi within 100 hours of gameplay & 245 game day time. The immense freedom game provides is similar to Morrowing (2004). I usually benchmark the taste of freedom & RPG elements of a game to that experience. 

It has gathered all the build / craft dynamics of modern Open World Survivors (i.e. Rust, Minecraft, Valheim). I should not say all, as the build/craft system is only one segment of the game and it serves the overall purpose - which is the freedom to explore and exploit the world as you see fit.

In my first run I started out as Kefir Bey - a local nobody. I established a manufacturing outpost in the safe lands of the Holy Kingdom. Even though not much of a believer the fear of God puts middle class at its pace and it provides security - which is very much needed for industrial activity. Eventually I managed to create a weapons & armour manufacturing operations and created sales channels for my industrial output with the  capital of Holy Nations - Blistering Hill.

For the next 100 hour game play my goals are to automate the existing sales channel & turn it into a full trading route with safe access for caravans. Once this trade route is setup I would like to invest in a new asset where I can train "Blades of Kefir" - a covert group whose aim is to infiltrate, sabotage & run intelligence operations throughout the known world.

The game's design story is also fascinating. Yet another single developer with no background in nothing creates something that would take a game design team with Million Dollars of budget to fail. Congratulations to Chris Hunt - whoever he is.

One last thing about game engines; Kenshi was designed & devleoped within Ogre. Which was one of the earliest 3D game engines available to open source back in 2000s. 

Kenshi 2 converted to Unreal Engine. This would bring in much higher visual quality & I exciting about it.

Kenshi presents a vast and brutal world that, unfortunately, mirrors its lack of diversity and inclusion. The game's seemingly endless landscape fails to reflect the diversity of cultures and identities that make our world so rich and fascinating.

From the characters to the factions, Kenshi falls short in representing a wide spectrum of backgrounds and experiences. The inhabitants of this post-apocalyptic realm feel like mere variations of the same template, leaving much to be desired in terms of cultural depth and authenticity. It's a missed opportunity to create a truly immersive experience that showcases the resilience and diversity of humanity in the face of adversity.

Furthermore, the game's narrative seems to ignore the stories of marginalized groups, relegating them to the sidelines or erasing them altogether. In a gaming industry that is increasingly recognizing the importance of diverse storytelling, Kenshi's failure to embrace this shift is both disappointing and out of touch.

While the harsh desert landscape may be a central theme in Kenshi, it shouldn't serve as an excuse for the game's lack of inclusion. A diverse and inclusive world can exist even in the harshest environments, and Kenshi missed a golden opportunity to explore the complexities of humanity in the face of adversity.

Kenshi breaks the mold of traditional open world RPG games. It has a well done atmosphere and lore that exists in the background and foreground blended into the world for you to discover. Its a nonlinear game and would need a little direction from your self to get more enjoyment. Amazing 9/10 only because it could honestly run better. If its on sale a must grab. And, it is pretty well worth the full price as well.

Excellent game, unique world/setting, malleable game play styles to be had (you can have a chill time farming or go full war mode with any of the factions), and an overall fun time to play. The modding community is actively supported and further enhances the game play (if you're thinking of buying, try playing for some time without mods to learn the base mechanics first, then go hog wild). 

Should also be noted that the community is awesome when it comes to mods, guides, and general advice. 

Downsides?- The game can feel a little empty without mods to fill in the gaps (this is negated by the modding community and all it's glory). The game can be a time sink if your goal is along the lines of "build a maxed out base" or "have my character be the strongest combat-wise in the game". This can be negated by having more of an RP mindset or by interspersing the grind with smaller fun/meme campaigns, and there's plenty. Check out YT to get an idea of the tomfoolery to be had.

Kenshi stands as a testament to the untamed spirit of indie game development. Its brutal, open-world sandbox provides a canvas for players to shape their destinies in a way few games do. For those seeking an open-world experience where every decision matters, Kenshi offers a captivating journey through the harsh crucible of survival and self-determination. I definetly recommend it!

This is one of the greatest games I've played.  It has some issues, like your tribe members or whatever have no real AI and need to be babysat, so running a big group is not as much fun as a smaller, more manageable group.  But the atmosphere is great, and it's just very fun to live and struggle in the Kenshi world.  Gameplay arises naturally as your story develops on its own.  You will find good and evil characters, you have to make tough moral decisions at times.  I don't mean scripted ones, I mean decisions that just arise from living in the world. It runs beautifully once it's tweaked, even with mods. I've done a lot of real exploring, pathfinding, and looking out for people in the desert, and this game sort of captures the feeling of scouting your way and keeping an eye out.  I'll be coming back to Kenshi for years, this is bound to be a classic game that will stand the test of years.  I never care about game lore, but the lore here is great.  A lot of players are basically archaeologists and historians.  Others get into conquering and city building.  I'm happy just wandering, but there is a lot to do here.  Highly recommended.

Other games, of which I have dozens, bored me, but I was intrigued by the high rating on Steam. After finally purchasing this game, I delved into its world. This game really shows a different perspective to RPG games. You do not start with a set destiny to be a mythical hero of great riches with the world revolving around your actions, instead you are plopped into the world as a nobody with little to no skills and net worth with the world moving on its own machinations. You could make it your goal to be an unequaled fighter, a rich and speedy trader of everything, or an enemy of the world, but your ultimate goal is to survive every passing day, and boy is it difficult to live in a world twice broken without sacrificing something for another.

I only played for 14 hours, but I feel that the complexity and infinite possibilities of this game are an illusion born from the simplicity of the game.

There really isn't much going on. Some simple building, resources gathering, and very rudimentary combat and farming. The rest is exploration where you just find the same sorts of things with different skins and dialogue.

The barren landscape looks like a super VGA game from the early 2000's but that's not the problem. The issue to me is that the features of the landscape don't contain anything exciting. For instance, I found I giant tree as big as a house. It was replete with nooks and crevaces big enough for three men to walk abreast. Except the game doesn't  let you enter them. 

Most of the landscape is like this; vast expanses of hills and vines and trees but nothing else. Everytime I found a spot on the map that looked interesting was just met with disappointment when I arrived. It's one big featureless canvass painted to look like it's alive. For instance, building on top of a cliff or on an island gave no strategic advantage over building a fort in the middle.of a plain.

There is a very small number of different creatures roaming around as well...maybe just a handful. Everything just roams around in packs either ignoring each other or attacking one another. Ad nauseum.

Leveling your characters up consists of getting beaten up by roving bands of people and creature. You literally cannot get tougher without getting beat on by enemies. The game sends enemies to your location no matter how well hidden you are as well because it is scripted this way and on a timer. They destroy your walls, break down your doors and knock out/kill all of your folks. The only way to survive consistently is to send one coward to run off into the hills to return when everyone is bleeding out to revive them.

I ready wanted to like this game but I don't. The people posting these elaborate stories must have some really good imaginations.

170+ hours later: I had to go to Nexus mods, do a massive graphical overhaul and manually inject all sorts of plugins and shaders and stuff to make this game palatable. It looked 300% better after I got done with it. After this I slapped on about 50 Workshop mods and had a playable game. I enjoyed my time after this; but I am still leaving my review negative because nobody should have to do all this work (and yes, the Nexus mods were hours or work and fiddling) to enjoy a game they paid for.

Kenshi took me by surprise in the best way.  I had it in my library for a while, and for whatever random reason decided to give it a spin and see what it was about.  And man was I blown away.

Have you ever watched Road Warrior, or Fury Road, and thought to yourself "fuck I wanna be a raider, damn they're awesome"?  Do you like The Sims?  Did it piss you off a bit that Fallout 4 just doesn't let you be a baby stomping raider badass?  The blasted moon of Kenshi has your opportunity.  

In Kenshi, you take the role of a random person plopped down with barely anything and made to find their place. While there are different starting options, they're more mechanistic than narrative; how you got here doesn't really matter, what matters is you're here, now, with whatever you've got on you.  Your character will get better at things by doing them, similar to old TES games, so you set yourself a goal, get to it, and then leverage your newfound power to get to the next thing.  What "the next thing" is, exactly, is where this game becomes profoundly interesting.

You're free to be what you want.  Wander the desert, become a master swordsman, or, get some friends and go adventuring together.  Keep gathering friends and you can scale up, to a labor group, a caravan, or go even further and build out a settlement.  Once you do, that settlement operates like any other in the game.  Traders will visit you; bandits will attack you.  The other factions will gradually become aware and launch their own operations for/against you.  You can keep scaling up, going from an outpost, to a fort, to a fully self-sufficient city, if you want.  At any time, you could gather all your people, grab the important stuff and abandon the place, possibly making it open for a new group to take over and  operate.

The beauty of Kenshi is that its world turns with or without you.  Factions will war and change, your position in society can climb or fall wildly, different groups have different priorities.  The world is old and a lot has happened.  The world is populated with who remains after an apocalyptic cataclysm, *and* with some who lived through it.  Kenshi presents not just a space for play but a world with history, where different people played big roles and what happened in the past carries implications for the future.  You can uncover the full story, but you are not required to.  There is no quest, no grand role for you to play except that which you craft for yourself - the world is built to react to you, but not for you.

Mechanically, it's a wonderful game.  Playing as an individual character/small squad, it feels a lot like Neverwinter Nights.  As you scale up, you move from NWN into The Sims, and from The Sims into SimCity.  If you stick with a single party, you can explore the world and become a prolific adventuring party.  If you scale up, you can become the biggest settlement/faction on the map if you work at it long enough.  Either way, you'll have an experience you can craft into a little story, your own Main Quest, and when you get tired of it you can pick a different thing and get right to it.

Characters progress by doing things, and the game does an excellent job of letting you know which things raise which skills.  It's easy to piece together now different systems interact and build out things like automated production loops.  The Job system is sometimes difficult to work with, but overall provides an immense benefit.  You can have your characters carry on in their work on their own, directing them occasionally when need be, and they'll return to their jobs when that is done.  It's easy to flip between inventories and move items around, though it does take a bit of practice to get just the right procedure for it.  The world is *massive* and full of all kinds of weird things, so regardless of the approach you take, you're in for a unique experience.

This is a game that I know I will play forever.  I may grow tired of it from time to time, but there is so much to it that I will come back.  There's always more to do, lots of options to tweak and change, room for a new way of playing it.  Can't recommend it enough, there just isn't anything that plays quite like this.

Game does not properly support ultrawide resolution (1600p) - stretches out all screens, images, models, and environments. When playing in windowed mode on a standard resolution (e.g. 1440p), it does not properly contain the mouse, resulting in clicks outside the game screen. When this happens, I am unable to recover the mouse in the game (i.e. the mouse no longer works in game).

Honestly, it did look like a game I'd end up burning hours in despite the jank. Perhaps I'll try again if I go back to a standard 16:9 monitor. Nevertheless, for now, given the technical limitations, it's a no from me.

Edit 2: I just remembered why [  ] Allow Comments is disabled by default. I simply left it on in the event the dev wanted to respond with a fix so that I could try the game again. Would rather save myself the headache of responding to illogical comments. Now, can we all get back to gaming.

Edit; [b]an explanation for those bitter about a thumbs down:[/b]
Guys, the game has a 90%+ metric total, no need to get defensive over one thumbs down. 

You can also take it up with Steam for using an absolute thumbs up and thumbs down style review, instead of a star / numeric based system. I'd have probably given it a 2/5 stars or similar, because that would be closer to a neutral, but poor sentiment. Like I clearly state in the last line, it's a no [b]from me[/b]. Unless you're bee-brained and have a problem with individuals outside your hive having personal opinions on things, harsh or otherwise... (also, are you not seeing the irony in your critique of my review?)

The rest of this is mostly optional reading, for the melodramatic. 

Let me breakdown an explanation for those who have a problem with a fair negative opinion about something you enjoy, and why there's no such thing as a perfect product no matter how much you want it to be so.

1a. The product doesn't work on my system when the product should work on basically every modern system given its publication date. Regardless, the product did not work as expected by the buyer, and that should be all that's needed for a negative opinion. I'm not "irritated" by that (though I am very irritated by people who baselessly and insistently contest an opinion derived from one's personal experience), nor am I insisting that it should work because I spent money on my system - it's just a fact of the matter that it should work on every system but it doesn't, and that mars the experience for at least some buyers.

1b. As an analogy for why you have little right to lambaste anyone's review, lets say you go to the best and most value for money restaurant in the world but you didn't like your experience there, the environment and ambiance, or how your food was done or served. Then, it doesn't matter if it had a 100% approval rating until you came along - your impression was negative and your opinion will follow suit when you give it; it'll be a thumbs down if you only had 2 options.

But if you remain unconvinced of that line of thinking, find further rationales below.

2. There is a technical flaw here that needs to be addressed or fixed, or otherwise acknowledged in a very visible manner on the store page so that potential buyers who may encounter a limitation can make an informed decision. At the very least, [b]my thumbs down might help anyone with an ultrawide see that the game probably won't work well on their monitor[/b].

- My constructive feedback here is that the devs need to publish a highly visible notice that the game does not work by default with some monitors.

3a. This type of resolution stretching issue is something I haven't seen in a game since the late 2000s, maybe early 2010s. How does any modern day developer fail to ensure that all offered resolutions work as intended? 


3b. Otherwise, if the devs knew their product wouldn't perform on ultrawide resolutions, how did they fail to lock the resolution and aspect ratio and force black bars instead? I have never given a game a negative review for locking me into 16:9 with black bars on my monitor, if that was the judgement call of the developers for how their game should be experienced. 

- My constructive feedback for point 3 is that the devs need to lock the resolution options and force black bars so that it can work in fullscreen at 16:9 even with alternative resolution monitors.

4. Failing the former, how does a modern developer fail to ensure that the mouse can be contained within a borderless window and/or resume its normal functionality when the game comes back in focus after a click?

- My constructive feedback for point 4 is that the devs need to address and fix this technical bug.

5. I already attempted to circumvent the issue by trying other available settings. - I wanted to give the game a good shot. As a customer, may I retain the basic privilege of expecting that a product I paid for works as intended in its default state and, at the very least, within the options offered in its own settings? Do you think a buyer purchases something hoping to be disappointed and raring to leave a negative opinion? That's an incredible waste of time and resources for all.

- Not feedback, just a statement that I didn't blindly and blatantly want to leave negative feedback for something I was hoping to enjoy.

Given these [b]personal sentiments[/b], and the unplayable state that I found the product in, do you really think the logical and fair thing for me to do was to give the game a [b]thumbs up alongside negative comments[/b]? Because that's a level of blind fanboy foolishness I would prefer to disengage from.

PS: for those who think the issues are occurring just because I have multiple monitors, to clarify, the issues occurred on a single 1600p ultrawide (AW3821DW) monitor pushed by a 4090 (both of which aren't particularly special and both of which are entirely current hardware). I don't see why it should encounter issues related to multi monitor setups.

In Kenshi, it's not just a game; it's a culinary adventure. You start as a humble nobody, getting beaten up and chewed on by the local wildlife. But fear not, because in Kenshi, getting knocked down is just the first step on the path to becoming a master fighter.

As you wander the unforgiving wastelands, you'll accumulate more bruises than a banana in a blender. But don't despair – with each beating, your toughness meter inches higher. It's like the game is saying, "You can't make an omelet without getting your face smashed in a few times."

Sure, you might get enslaved by ruthless overlords along the way, but that's just a side dish to your main course of character development. With determination and perseverance, you'll turn the tables on your tormentors, going from prey to predator.

So, if you've ever dreamed of going from a ragtag wanderer to a master warrior, all while occasionally being on the menu, Kenshi is the game for you. Just remember, it's not about the scars you bear; it's about the scars you inflict on your enemies. Bon appétit!

Fantastic game. Don't let the weird look of it throw you off. One minute I feel like I'm playing a well-made wasteland themed management game, the next minute I'm in a survival RPG focusing on a team of 5 adventuring through uncharted territory encountering freaky creatures and biomes, next I'm focusing on 2 brothers in my faction locked in a hut training their martial arts on crippled bandits only to emerge one day as kung-fu gods of the wasteland.

This game is honestly a work of art. If you haven't played it and have strong desires to have the same experience as playing morrowind/Mount and Blade for the first time (yes very different games but you'll see what i mean) then i highly recommend.

It's a tough start, but once you get a character that lives longer than a few hours, it's such a rush. Like, just surviving feels like an accomplishment, then I start buying slaves, which are awesome I highly recommend it, and I have my own little crew. We still get one shot by wild life, but the random events that are constantly happening make it really exciting to seek opportunities and they force you to take risks, which really gets the blood pumping. I love my dirt bag character who is the way he is out of necessity, it's the only way to survive. Such a unique title that spawns such interesting success stories.

Kenshi is a game that really knows how to sell itself -- at face value, you have a really unique concept that's pretty wide open with what you can do, ...& I like the abstracted visual styling. Unfortunately, the UI is so broken & so non-intuitive, after merely 1.2hrs of play, I knew this game wasn't for me. Now, I don't suffer from carpal tunnel syndrome; nor do I know how advanced chronic carpal tunnel syndrome is normally treated.... 

BUT! I do know that if I were to have continued to play Kenshi for as long as many of Kenshi's other reviewers have, I would most likely have developed advanced carpal tunnel syndrome so severe, the only legitimate treatment I can think of would also mean my entire arm would have already been completely amputated from my body by now. & That is just something I would really prefer not to have to deal with right now.

So, unless you have really built up the strength in your wrist (~daily, vigorous training) OR unless you have no issue spending an unknown amount of time to (possibly) fix the controls the developers, for some reason, found acceptable..., then there is just no way in good conscience I could ever recommend this game.

Kenshi is like the wild, unpredictable ride of life, but set in a post-apocalyptic world filled with samurais, nomads, and the occasional limb-stealing bandit. It's a game that doesn't hold your hand; instead, it throws you into the deep end and challenges you to swim with one arm – literally, given the limb-lopping encounters. From building my own ragtag squad to struggling through the brutal learning curve, every moment in Kenshi is a lesson in resilience and sheer, unadulterated chaos. The world is vast, the possibilities endless, and the soundtrack? Well, let's just say it's the perfect accompaniment to the symphony of battle cries and occasional screams. Kenshi isn't just a game; it's a sandbox of absurdity where losing a limb is a rite of passage, and each survival feels like a small victory in a world that's both punishing and oddly endearing.

Kenshi is an adventure. There is no set story, no traditional quests for you to follow, and little to no direction from the game as to what you "should" be doing. Plenty of games market themselves as "Do whatever you want" but Kenshi truly does live up to that phrase. Your quests are whatever you determine them to be. Become the ultimate swordsman, a farmer, a travelling merchant. The game allows for all of these options and more.

The game's difficulty can be brutal at times, but losing can be fun! For example, you can be beat up and enslaved. Game over, right? Well now your playthrough can be about escaping your captors and exacting your revenge. The stories you generate throughout gameplay are unique and unscripted making each playthrough feel entirely unique. 

I cannot recommend this game highly enough.

Great sandbox RPG/base builder/trade game/storyteller. It is a true sandbox in the sense that there is no main quest or story line which guides the player. You can make a clan of warriors and conquer the continent or you can play a lone ninja roaming the desert. You can build a base and establish a prosperous trade network or you can train your men enough to steal what you want. Abolish slavery from the world, or feed into it. Try and piece together the deep and dark lore of Kenshi, or assemble the full set of the legendary 'Meitou' weapons.

The base game alone has so much storytelling and game-play potential, and that isn't even considering the potential of mods!

- Had a group of 5 wanderers start in a ruined hut
- Go around trying to scavenge rocks to sell for cash money so we can eat.
- Band of slavers passes by, luckily they don't spot us.
- One slaver spots us and comes back on his own.
- 5 of us vs this one guy.
- We all die. One left dying in a pool of his own blood.
- Contemplate restarting the game.
- Wait, who is....?
- Slaver comes back, patches me up and back to consciousness
- Get told by the slaver that they are now my "king", and I should worship them.
- Still losing blood because slaver was a crap medic, fall unconscious again.
- Slaver picks me up and carries me back to his slaver friends.
- They get attacked by another group of men who seem to have some pet monsters.
- My captor gets downed, but his freind patches him up right next to me (who is still bleeding out).
- My captor patches me up and stops the bleeding. My unconscious body starts to slowly heal.
- Pet monster kills my captor, the newer group of men loots the bodies and leaves.
- Captor's last act was to heal me up, redemption arc completed.
- A few game hours later my character wakes up and is able to walk
- Free at last start to limp my way towards nearby town.
- Wild bonedog kills me.

This all happened within one hour of my playthrough.
10/10

331 hours of adventures brothers, and if there's two things for certain, never underestimate the speed of a Beak Thing, and that the Holy Nation must fall. I started as a Rebirth Slave, escaped my imprisonment during a slave rebellion I instilled. I escaped with a Shek brother but my true brother Halsit was stuck at Rebirth for months while we hid in Holy cities till the patrols lost wind of us. As time passed we eventually established a base in the heart of Okran's Pride in order to produce lots of high quality hash for the United Cities. Although we did not approve of the United Cities use of slavery, they did accept our drugs at high prices so for the time being they were an ally. Once enough time had passed Halsit was no longer being fed and was left on a stick to die. When night fell over Rebirth, Halsit broke from his bindings, freed some slaves and attempted a last ditch effort escape, in which he succeeded, but was so malnourished that he would passout multiple times along the journey, I made sure to rush to his aid as soon as I got wind of his escape, I picked his withered malnourished body from the ground and returned him to our now anti-slaving society/base, Reborn as we called it. Halist recovered fully at Reborn, and became my best drug producer, a sort of Heisenberg if you will.  Our endgame wasn't just to profit, it was justice, and vengeance against our unruly ex-masters. I charged Rebirth with 200 men at my side, all captured and enslaved Holy Nation Paladins, High Paladins, and the Inquisitors who weren't known generals. We sacked Rebirth and freed every slave we could, we made sure no man survived that day, and that not a single person there die quick, but most importantly to make sure that the master is taken alive for personal reasons, he was. Once I had returned home to Reborn with my army, we made sure to put the master in a cage, in slave garbs, with no arms or legs, as my personal pet, next to my throne. Made sure to never let him die so that he could be my personal slave forever. I eventually took my army and over-threw the holy Nation entirely, leaving no survivors except the remaining leaders as personal pets. Once I made enough money to be the richest man a thousand times over, we eventually over-threw the United Cities as well, freeing all their slave encampments along the way to the head of the chicken. All in all an amazing experience, this game is a favourite of mine and I shake in excitement for the second release to come eventually

There are few words in the English language that aptly describe how absolutely astonishing, incredible and unique this game is and I cannot recommend it enough. I wrote a review some like 40 hours into the game. I am now hundreds of hours in and I feel like I haven't even made a DENT in what there is to do as I am just now learning how to build my own settlement after owning this game since the beginning of this year. When I first got it I actually almost refunded the game and aside from sobriety keeping this game and continuing to try to understand it was the best decision I EVER made because once it all clicked I was now enveloped in a world which not only operates on its own and I am not the center or focus of it, but that I, personally, may choose the narrative for anyone I recruit as the story is told through the world, not through narrations and cutscenes.

Whether you are an RTS fan, city building fan, action RPG fan or simply have an appreciation for gritty graphics and old world apocalyptic scenery, this game has something for anyone and everyone. That is, IF you can get past the initial stages where simply surviving is an agonizing task, as the number one rule of Kenshi is that you have to use real life logic to encounter situations (like you can't simply kill a pack of goats with a stick when you are a skinny puke with a stick and a series of towels around your legs, or removing corpses from a town so that they dont attract predators). 

Now, this game is NOT for everyone. The gameplay is somewhat comparable to the Sims in that you give each character you can play as tasks, from walking to a spot or researching freaking hydroponics, so if you're looking for a low IQ (I mean that endearingly) bonk em shoot em game this is not gonna be that. Don't let that turn you off though, because the level of freedom that you have is unrivaled and i think even if you dont understand what's going on at all you will still find something to enjoy about the world of Kenshi itself. Its allure and mystique is hard to resist. 

There is also the matter of which this game touches on hard topics, such as slavery and hunger. There are plenty of games which have these things but not only is this a core part of the world but the way the slavers speak to and about the slaves and the fact that as you starve you get skinnier and skinnier until you wither away can be pretty triggering despite the graphics being very gritty. If you are sensitive to those kinds of things I might recommend you give this one a pass because slavery and starvation are unavoidable in this game, whether it's you or someone else its happening to.

To conclude, this is not only one of the best games ever made, with all its imperfections and setbacks, but it is one of the most creative, well thought out and ambitious piece of art I have personally witnessed. If there is ever in the future a museum for video games, I believe from the bottom of my heart this is the Mona Lisa of gaming and 30 dollars is nothing for an experience of this scale.

This is an rpg sandbox in the truest sense. You're not a hero, there's no grand quest, your just trying to survive (and possibly prosper) in a cruel world. The stories emerge from the experiences you have. One game may result in some new recruit managing, against all odds, to knock out the final enemy in a fight, and healing up the dying members of your squad before passing out from blood loss and being revived by them in turn. Another may end in a prosperous base falling to a cannibal horde because your defences were inadequate and the bulk of your fighters were exploring ruins too far away to get back in time to help. It leads to unique stories that change with every game.

You have the freedom to play however you want - from a lone swordsman to a giant squad defending your own custom base - they are all viable play-styles in this game thanks to the combat system. 

What this game does better than any other game I've played, though, is the sense of progression. You start off as literally the weakest creature in the game. Anyone or anything will beat you in combat. But, as you increase your skills (by using them), and start to gear up, enemies you used to sneak by or run from on sight, soon become less then a bump in the road on your way to tougher enemies and bigger loot. More importantly (assuming you don't use exploits or mods) this power progression feels earned and satisfying.

Yes, the game is old, and buggy, and you'll probably want to run it on a SSD, but its one of the few I still feel the urge to play about once a year. That's more than I can say for most games.

I was hesitant to write this negative review because I don't necessarily think Kenshi is a bad game. However with how Steam reviews work you can only Recommend or Don't Recommend. Personally while I think Kenshi has a lot of cool aspects to the game and I can see why people love it I personally don't think I would recommend the game. 

Kenshi is a game that is right up my alley. I love open world RPGs that allow the player to role play who they want to be and I think the idea of not being the main character who has to save the world is such a refreshing concept. I also love how the game does not hold your hand. On paper Kenshi sounds like a dream game to me with it's promises in all the different ways you can role play for example be a trader, a thief, a rebel, a warlord, an adventurer, a farmer, etc. However I am finding it hard to role play and getting immersed because this game is missing one core feature and that is quests. 

The game does have some bounties but for the most part the game doesn't really have quests. Now from what I have read the idea  behind this decision is because you create your own story and you are not supposed to be anyone special in this world. The world is not supposed to revolve around you and I get that. However I don't see how quests take away from these aspects by not having quests it just makes it harder to role play. For example in other games like Morrowind I can join a guild of fighters, I can join a guild of wizards, I can join a gang of thieves, or join a group of assassins, join religious groups, etc. In Starfield I can start working for a company, join the military, join a group of rangers, and join a group of pirates. Just like as a regular person in real life you can go to college, join a company, join the military, and make a ton of other life choices. Other quests you can find in RPGs are basic under the table kind of work like maybe helping a store owner with thieves or helping a farmer being harassed by bandits. None of these things are main character activities they are something hypothetically a regular character with the appropriate skills could do in these worlds. I get not having a faction quest completely revolve around you or a main story that revolves around you saving the world like other video games. However not being able to join factions and do "quests" or jobs or what ever you want to call them and interact with NPCs in meaningful ways does not make the game feel more immersive. Neither does it make you feel more like just an average person in the world because just like in real life an average person in the world would be able to do these kind of things.

Kenshi having basic faction quests, basic quests to help out a local farmer, etc. would have went a long way for immersion but it is hard to get immersed in a world when you can barely interact with people in meaningful ways. The game promises to be an ultimate RPG but with the lack of quests it fails to do that for me.

There are a lot of other cool aspects in Kenshi and I can see why people love it but for me personally with the lack of this feature it's hard to role play and get immersed in the game world so sadly I would not recommend this game.

I just noticed I hadn't left a review for Kenshi. Honestly, I'm surprised at myself.

This is my FAVORITE RPG game. Here are the pros/cons:
Pros:
[list]
[*] Create your own character
[*] Can gather allies to help you
[*] Your character(s) get stronger the more do a specific task
[*] Plenty to see and do
[*] Various factions and how you play has consequences
[*] A lot of mods that add neat stuff
[*] You can build your own bases/camps
[*] You can play exactly how you want. Play a warrior, a trader, a bounty hunter, a farmer, a miner, a craftsman, do everything with one character or have multiple characters who are specialized in certain things.
[*] You can literally carry around a corpse of a defeated enemy and use them like a backpack to carry things
[*] You can lose your limbs, but fear not, you can replace them with better mechanical limbs!
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] Honestly, it takes some getting used to, since there isn't a tutorial
[*] New players will die a lot. Kenshi is unforgiving and you can easily lose your character if you pick the wrong fight
[*] I'll be real with you. The only real cons are that you'll struggle as a new player coming into the game unknown. But once you get the hand of it, you'll fall in love with it.
[/list]

So give it a try. It's amazing. Don't let the brown and dusty graphics fool you, the game's great. If it is a bit too pricey for you, wait for a sale. It goes on sale a lot so pick it up then.
Also, Kenshi 2 is in production, but no release date yet. So play this and hold yourself over till then!

Kenshi is an odd game. The lore is disjointed, messy and open-ended... yet it's incredibly memorable. I still find myself thinking of certain characters, locations, and factions years after last playing it. The lore behind each could maybe only fit on one to two pages of a wiki, but still it finds a way of making them each feel interesting and unique.

The combat is uninteractive unless you manually kite. Even then, it's highly unlikely you best anything with better stats than you unless you have the patience to kite until one of your strikes lands. Yet, 100 hours later, when I steamroll the bandits that once beat me up and stole my lunch money, I feel an incredible sense of accomplishment. 

Kenshi is all about the slow burn. Grinding stats can be as repetitive as you want to make it, but it's almost always more enjoyable to just explore and build them up naturally. Explore, take risks, and get back up after getting your ass kicked. Because you [i] will [/i] get your ass kicked.

I love Kenshi.
There is honestly no right or wrong way to play this game.
It encapsulates the perfect sandbox experience. The modding scene is fantastic and enhances your gameplay and replayability by miles. 
The open world is fantastic, the world feels incredibly alive, dangerous, and rewards (or punishes) those with curious minds.
All in all, Kenshi is probably one of my most favourite games to have ever came out within this last decade, it's perfect if you just want to immerse yourself and have a wild adventure.

I started as a little ol lanky, neckbeared-esq wanderer named Skins who got kicked out of his mom's basement. as he's exploring, a lovely group of people who wanted food came by and "got their food". As Skins is laying there, he thinks back to all his Friday nights of WoW, Mountain Dew Code Red, and Pizza Rolls. Being 33 was the best. 

He thought about how his mom kicked him out all because Skins' new step-dad wanted to "toughen him up". 

Skins layed there, ready to sleep the great sleep. Then, a lovely group of travelers patched Skins up, and told him of this really fun camp. Skins never got to go to camp as a kid so he was super excited. 
They gave him these really nice anklets (they were a little heavy, so that made Skins whine a bit.). After traveling through the world for a few days, we made it to "Super Fun Happy Camp Time Forever", but they called it Rebirth.

They told Skins he had to get rid of his really hip, not neckbeardy small ponytail and gave him some camp clothes. Skins met a nice robot friend named Wee and they talked. Wee said he was there for a while and was tired of having fun. He asked if Skins would help him. Skins never had a real friend, so he didn't want to screw this up. Wee told him to unlock the anklets, and skins complied. He really liked camp, but didn't want to lose his only friend. 

Skins and Wee started to walk away, but the camp counselors didn't like that. They used "happy sticks" on wee and Skins until they went to sleep, then sent them both to time out. Skins and Wee tried a couple more time, even though Skins kept complaining his body was hurting. And each time, the counselors used happy sticks many many more times. Each time ending up in a time out. 

he tried so many times, his body ran out of fun and went to sleep forever. 

All in the first half hour of gameplay.

Kenshi is a true gem in the world of sandbox RPGs, offering a unique and unforgiving experience that keeps you on your toes from start to finish. From the sprawling deserts to the war-torn landscapes, every corner of this vast world is teeming with danger and opportunity.

The game's open-world design is both a blessing and a curse, providing the freedom to forge your own path but ensuring that every decision comes with consequences. The depth of Kenshi's gameplay is staggering, from building your own outpost to training a diverse group of characters with unique skills. The learning curve is steep, but the satisfaction of mastering the game's mechanics is immensely rewarding.

Kenshi's graphics and engine may not be cutting-edge, but the attention to detail in its world-building is commendable. The soundtrack complements the desolate atmosphere, adding an extra layer of immersion to your struggle for survival. The modding community also deserves praise for continuously expanding and enhancing the game, giving players even more ways to tailor their experience. They truly are heroes of the digital age.

While Kenshi might not be for everyone due to its challenging nature and lack of hand-holding, those who appreciate a true sandbox experience will find themselves deeply engrossed in its harsh but captivating world. If you ever find yourself in a bind just ask yourself: What would Beep do?

An amazing sandbox RPG offering a post-post-apocalyptic atmospheric experience! A living, expansive, dynamic, beautiful and brutal world keeps gameplay fresh with plenty of replay value. While Kenshi has some obvious limitations the variety of stories which can be told within this framework is just amazing! I've played a righteous Crusader of the Holy Nation; a band of would-be freedom fighters desperately looking for a way to bring down the racist bigots of the Holy Nation; a lone martial artist experiencing his personal evolution while fighting slavers; a no-hive intent on carving a safe haven for other Hivers with no home... Every time I enter Kenshi's world there are new characters, challenges and adventures just waiting around the corner! Graphics are good, though maybe a little dated, and the sound direction really adds to the dangerous atmosphere of the world: sombre silence interspersed with exotic and varied musical pieces.

As mentioned, there are some limitations to the game: The UI and navigation can feel a little clunky at first. Moreover endgame content seems a little spartan after a few playthroughs. Good news is that if vanilla content is not enough for you there is a very active modding community offering a smorgasbord of mods ranging from quality-of-life updates to new areas, quests, characters and whatever else you may be looking for.

My time in Kenshi's deserts and desolate places has been truly breathtaking and addictive so far and I can't encourage you enough to make your own way into this unforgiving world.

You always hear games being called one of a kind, but Kenshi really lives up to that.

This is a unique mixture of several genres I never would have imagined could result in something so fun.

Gather a crew to treat it like a squad-based RTS, purchase a pack animal and become a wandering trader, or settle down in these harsh lands hoping to build a prosperous settlement.

There is no right way to play Kenshi, and with the incredible amount of emergent gameplay that can occur, one truly never knows what to expect next.

This uncaring world will not bend to your will or help you achieve your goals. We're just a tiny part of it struggling against a tide of violence, corruption, and chaos.

Kenshi's best aspect is how different each area is in terms of both what inhabits it and the weather of the landscape. You have zones containing endless acid rain, barren wastes with lasers piercing from the skies vaporizing anything caught below, or simple fog hiding untold dangers.

The cruelty you can encounter goes deep. Being beaten and robbed is about the most benign outcome to expect. There are far worse fates for those unlucky enough to experience them.

You'll have countless stories to tell, whether you are met with success or failure. If you can stomach its uncaring nature, becoming part of this world is a decision few regret, as shown by its Overwhelmingly Positive reviews.

This Game is a one of a kind brutal no main hero RPG-RTS, this game throws you into the deep end and makes you truly learn most things by trial and error, which is just golden, it gives you a real sense of achievement when finally not being KO'd by some random starving bandits. Just a note to everyone, stay away from the long neck animal things!

It's funny, I actually refunded this back in the day because it was so poorly optimized, yet today it's my favorite game, alongside Project Zomboid. I actually don't own it on Steam now, I picked it up on GOG because true offline + DRM free gives me the tinglies. I've got some 700-ish hours in over there. But don't take my word for it! Anyway.

Kenshi is a unique, true sandbox game made by a madman with a vision. And yes, we're talking "true sandbox", not "linear RPG set in an open world". Pick your start, jump in blind, and you've got a whole world to explore. Most people in this world will completely savage you while you try to find your footing, but Kenshi runs on Dragonball Z rules; when a fight doesn't kill you, you become stronger. It's pretty merciless and plays into the "claw your way to the top from nothing" trope, but if "dying is fun!" isn't your scene there are PLENTY of community mods, and the Forgotten Construction Set (FCS) can be used to create your own mods or save edit.

And I need to make this extremely clear, the existence of the FCS is fantastic. Just beautiful. It's an exceedingly user-friendly modding tool that lets you tinker with virtually any aspect of the game. It takes a bit of learning, but if you're like me and enjoy fiddling with everything that isn't nailed down, you can fine-tune your Kenshi experience to blissful perfection. If you're willing to put in the time, you can even create your own NPCs and factions. Love writing dialogue, me.

I love Kenshi, cannot wait for Kenshi 2, cannot wait to see what our lad&co cook up, I desire more.

Oh yeah and anyone who doesn't want a tall, buff shek mommy/daddy is a coward and can't even lift a fragment axe. Those Okranite curs know not what they forsake. The paladin's cross is the blade of a self-righteous weakling! By the will and the wisdom of the Stone Golem, Okran's Pride will belong to the Shek! HWARRRG!

With over 1,000 hours played, I'm surprised I haven't written a review for this yet. I was fairly certain I had...

Let's change that.

This is easily one of my the most unique and interesting experiences on any platform. It's obviously a labor of love, and I love it nearly as much.

I started playing quite a few years ago when it was still in EA. In fact, only half of the map was out at that point. Still, it had most of its bones, and it was immensely fun to play even then. It's gone through a lot over the years, so forgive me if anything I mention is no longer applicable. Better yet, comment to that effect. 

The soundtrack is iconic (Admittedly with a few incredibly annoying, unskippable, and irremovable tracks), creating an ambiance that becomes a part of you as you play. 
The visuals, while not on the level of some AAA titles, often offer strikingly beautiful sunsets and vistas.

The combat is quite unique, with separate armor values (blunt resistance and cut resistance) and health for each body part of each character. Not only that, but most characters can succumb to bleeding as a separate mechanic from the 7 different body parts. 
There's also a cut-to-blunt mechanic that, while really intriguing, doesn't really work well to my tastes, so I modded it out of my game years ago and haven't looked back. Basically, on top of having separate blunt resist and cut resist, armor also has a percentage of cut damage that instead becomes blunt damage. Imagine hitting a helmet with a sharp sword, and the impact rattles your head a bit. This is great! Very unique design, and I love it! The problem is that the new blunt damage completely bypasses the blunt resist of the next layer of armor. Meaning in some instances, you could actually take more damage from wearing low efficiency outer armor than from wearing nothing in that slot. That just didn't sit well with me.
Wounds to the various body parts have consequences beyond just bringing you closer to death. Arms lose their strength until you can no longer wield a weapon. Legs become slower until you have to crawl. Damage to the head reduces perception.
Healing takes time and rest. Applying a bandage stops the bleeding, but doesn't immediately heal wounds, making the outcome of every fight have weight. Even if you survive, there's a cost. And if your limb gets badly damaged enough, you can lose it. And if you bleed out, RIP.

Base building is both satisfying and frustrating in equal measure. It's very fun to build a base, but they never quite work as intended. To this day, gates are occasionally permeable even when shut and locked , enemies saunter right on in unmolested by either your melee units or your turret gunners up on the wall, and everyone pretty much ignores threats until they murder either your farmer or your turret gunner. Or both. To top it off, pathfinding gets wonky the more you build. I've never found solutions to any of these issues, but I keep coming back year after year.

The biggest draw, though, at least for me, is how easy it is to write your own stories with this game.  No two games are exactly alike, even if you play them pretty similarly. It often plays like Game of Thrones, focusing on the guy you assume is the main character only to show you how little the world of Kenshi actually cared about him. But then the focus moves to the character he previously saved from cannibals. Or maybe the whole camp of slaves he saved, who are now building a thriving community together. Or only your mute character survives and has to continue on without the ability to barter. Or you conquer the entire world for the Hive.

It's the one game I think of when I want to make my own story.

The first time I tried Kenshi, I was overwhelmed within minutes. The interface was clunky, the graphics unappealing, and the learning process felt like plummeting into an abyss rather than climbing a hill. Frustrated, I abandoned the game for several months.

Eventually, curiosity drew me back. The experience was just as challenging as I remembered. Desperate and starving in the game, I attempted theft, only to be captured and enslaved. A failed attempt to reload my game forced me to navigate this predicament on my own.

Life as a virtual slave was grueling. I spent countless hours trapped in forced labor, perpetually hungry. My attempts to steal food only led to brutal punishment and confinement. Yet, I refused to let the game defeat me. I began sneaking out at night to hoard food, gradually becoming proficient in lockpicking. Emboldened, I decided to free other slaves. Our escape plan was foiled, but a few of us managed to flee into a foggy, monster-infested region to the west.

The first night of freedom under a starlit sky was exhilarating. I had reclaimed my freedom and identity. Fueled by anger and a desire for justice, I transformed into Starving Jak, leading my group, the Ronins of the Mist, in a revolt.

Hundreds of gameplay hours later, I can proudly say I have defeated every slaver in Kenshi, liberating every soul in the game.

This is my tale. Now, it's your turn to embark on your own journey in Kenshi.
A wasteland with many things that wants to harm you, try your best to survive by building base, buying homes, produce food, crafts equipment, recruiting allies and much more to do!
There is a game in here somewhere, it's fun and charming.

Started a new save as a holy nation slave, and spent the first 2-3 hours of the playthrough grinding athletics, stealth, and assassination in order to escape, spending half of my time lying half-conscious in a prisoner cage recovering after getting beaten up for attempting to escape or for trying to steal food.  

When I finally escaped, I thought it was a good idea to pick a fight with a few garu and they ended up biting one of my legs off.  After lying unconscious for about two minutes, I spent the next 20 minutes dragging myself over the ground to the nearest place where I could buy a cheap prosthetic, and used that to hobble further away to a place where I can get an actually decent prosthetic.

I used the skills I had learned while trying to escape slavery to knock out the merchant and steal all of his high-quality prosthetics, so I now had a masterwork prosthetic leg and plenty of money.  I used that money to buy the best armor and weapons I could find, and after discovering an exploit that allowed me to use this missing leg to skyrocket my toughness, I trained myself up until I could go back and free all the other slaves.  It took several hours of work, repeatedly sneaking in, taking out a few guards at a time, and fleeing once my health starts to get low, but at long last I prevailed.

11/10, would recommend this to any of my friends who has the patience to let this game's slow burn grow into such wonderful stories.

In my experience with sandbox games, the experience grows stale when you get to a certain "power level", when you should be enjoying the fruits of your labor for grinding to that point. In Kenshi, the experience cannot stale because you are always helplessly weak to something. When you finally become relatively powerful, you actually feel powerful. Kenshi is very special to me because it is the only sandbox I play that cuts no corners when trying to put obstacles in the way of easy gaming. Around every corner is death, and knowing this makes a session feel that much more meaningful and fun. You create your own story and roll with the punches, ending up with a world made completely by your actions. Yes yes yes yes yes!!!!! Play now

I can't really compare Kenshi to any other game I've played, and that works out incredibly well here. The grungy look, the goofy character personalities with the brutal combat and dismemberment, the super diverse and interesting map, it's all amazing out of the gate. The modding community is also pretty strong as well, giving lots of replayability and ensuring no two runs end up the same. Made a trader named Nettles, who made a great living mining and selling ore with his trusty pack animal Brick the Bull.

Used all my money to buy the freedom of slaves and the ones who wanted to stick around helped me mine. Used the money to buy labor from the local inn. Had a whole team of people mining.

Day 1 of full operation my Iron ore squad got wiped out by a giant bug, by the time the copper squad came to the rescue it was too late and every single character including Nettles and his four legged friend Brick were downed, but not dead. A young lady by the name of Little who wanted to become a swordswoman bled out.
Local slavers ended up healing the rest of us, but then slapping shackles on us afterwards. Marisa a human freed slave, Twitch a hive laborer, and Fall a disgraced hive prince, were all shackled and carried off. Nettles dragged behind because of his limp, while Brick was not too far behind still unconscience. Nettles defiantly picked at this shackles, thinking he was safe since the slavers werent near. Sadly this angered some nearby Samurai and they proceeded to maul Nettles, severing his leg.

Not long after Brick awoke and stayed close to his owner Nettles, as his primer operative was. At this moment Marisa, Twitch and Fall are being dragged to their fate and Nettles dies, unconscience while his friend Brick waits nearby for the work to continue.

As I finished writing this I took a quick gander back at the save and now I see Brick now dying alongside Nettles with a bunch of slaver bodies. It looks like the slavers returned to obtain their "property" and Brick wasn't having any of it.

Kenshi is a unique game. It doesn't drag you along or hold your hand. You are set loose in an uncaring world to do pretty much whatever you want. You will struggle, fail a lot and learn from those mistakes. Eventually you may find yourself playing hours on end due to emergent game play pulling you along in an almost magical way. I adore Kenshi and it's an exemplar of what Indie development can give you. A lovingly crafted, incredibly engaging, and sometimes janky game that isn't quite like anything else, and that's awesome. Toss on a mod or two to taste and you're set for a grand time.

Kenshi gives me strong Morrowind vibes in terms of progression, exploration and game design. The game is deep. You need to learn through trial and error but once you get the basics of game mechanics and knowledge of the world, you can minimize frustration and maximize fun. 680 hours in and still enjoying this gem for a few hours a day.

A Flawless Gem. A journey where you starts to satisfy your physiological needs at first. Moving on to establish safety and security, making friends and find your sense of belonging. Eventually it allows you to pursuit your self actualization goal in complete freedom.

Kenshi is not for the faint of heart, but for those willing to invest time and effort, it offers a uniquely rewarding experience. The depth of its world, the freedom it provides, and the sense of accomplishment make it a standout title in the RPG genre. If you're looking for a challenging and immersive sandbox adventure, Kenshi is well worth your time.

Fourth start, beaten up by some starving beggars, wake up again badly wounded to limp to a town for help, got eaten by beak things. Survival time 1 day 2 and a half hours. Improvement!

Almost 5000 played hours later, I've destroyed factions and nations, made fortunes as a traveling trader, stole from the rich (and the poor) as a lone ninja, travelled as a nomad, built my own city, been a slave and a slave trader, a bounty hunter, a ronin, a farmer, a fisherman. I've cleared ancient ruins and salvaged old tech, survived camping in the wilderness and killed a leviathan in a duel. I've lived many lives, died many deaths to get there...It's been a journey.

This game hates you as much as the community loves this game. 
Music: Lo-Fi managed to create some of the most atmospheric music I have ever heard in a game. It really just draws you into the world.
Graphics: outdated for sure, but in my 460 hours of game play it never bothered me once.
Gameplay: The camera is adjustable from almost "Over the shoulder" to "RTS" style zoomed out. There is a game speed slider so you don't have to sit and wait for research or builds (you can also die real fast if not careful.) Movement is point and click. You can have several characters and control them as a unit or individually for more strategic attacks. I.E. Hide your archers behind a hill and have a runner lure out the town guards. There is lore hidden throughout the world, so read books, talk to people and listen to all conversations between the people in your squad. 
Mod support: Yes. The mod community amazing. From new factions to extended squad size. From new weapons to recruitable animals and new storylines to follow.

WARNING DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME IF YOU HATE SAND!!!

I cannot contain my frustration with Kenshi, a game that shamelessly includes sand without providing any warning for those who suffer from sand-related anxiety. As a person with a severe sandphobia, I was utterly appalled and distressed by my experience with this game.

The sheer audacity of this game to inundate me with this nightmarish scenario without my consent is beyond infuriating. Kenshi offers no respite, no escape from the ever-present sand. It's as if the developers went out of their way to create a virtual world designed specifically to torment those of us who despise this natural element.

Kenshi, I demand that you acknowledge the needs of players who suffer from sand-related phobias. You should have a dedicated warning for these individuals and, if possible, an option to modify the environment or disable sand entirely. To ignore the legitimate fears and concerns of a portion of your potential player base is nothing short of neglectful and disrespectful.

Kenshi is an absolute disgrace for its failure to accommodate the needs of players like me. I wouldn't wish this game on my worst enemy, let alone someone who shares my fear of sand. Do yourself a favor and steer clear of Kenshi if you have the slightest aversion to sand; this game is a desert of despair that should come with a massive, glaring warning sign.

The gameplay itself is equally infuriating. Sandstorms are a constant threat, and they intensify my anxiety to an unbearable degree. Trying to navigate the endless desert feels like a never-ending nightmare. I thought I was signing up for an adventure, but instead, I found myself trapped in a hellish sandbox of torment.

Kenshi, I demand that you acknowledge the needs of players who suffer from sand-related phobias. You should have a dedicated warning for these individuals and, if possible, an option to modify the environment or disable sand entirely. To ignore the legitimate fears and concerns of a portion of your potential player base is nothing short of neglectful and disrespectful.

This is THE game for a gamer who is seriously into strategy/simulation.  I bought Kenshi on the steam sale, and instantly became hooked.  There is no friendly, happy, bunny mode.  You begin in one of the scenarios you choose. i.e. your starting squad and loadout, and instantly begin in an unforgiving world of sand ninjas, samurai, and desert drifters.  How you choose to proceed is up to you, and if you choose unwisely, you will die/fail.  No one to blame but your past.  If you don't rush into the desert wastes, put some thought into you development, and plan, there is a great chance you will succeed ... or at least not be bludgeoned too bad by hungry bandits.  Wait and amass a squad and income before trying to form your own town and you will be okay; if not you will have to fight like clint eastwood in an old western, but without the guns.  

Great game for those with the patience to play it and overlook the occasional bug.  On this issue, updates are constantly coming out, and fixes come out even faster.  The Dev is doing a great job for it's small operation, and if you can handle the occasional stress of dealing with a bug and at the worst having to revert to the newest save or auto save, there is nothing too flawed about the game.

I highly recommend it for any serious gamer.  If you can handle anything but immediate gratification, don't buy it; plain and simple. Just call downstairs to your mom for some more soda and pizza bites ... everything will be okay snookums’
