There's so much to do that's just [i]there[/i] from the start. 
What I mean is, there's virtually no restrictions on what is possible, excluding things like research for crafting and construction.

There are multiple basic starts that can be picked, from literally nothing in the desert, to five friends finding a place to bunker down. Going places isn't limited by anything but how harsh the areas are and how capable the party is.

It's a massive map that's pretty much dominated by arid enviorment. There is swamp and green enviorments but they are just about at select locations. I definitely wish there was more green locations, as farming is defined by what area the outpost is in and it can be very difficult to get anything else, until much later on with better technology.

The enviroments themselves are very nice, areas are sectioned off as biomes with general themes or a certain aspect, like [b]Screaching Forests, Spider plains, Black Desert[/b]. However, there's very little flat land. Virutally none. What little there is, is nearly the most hostile places to be. So anything planned on being built that's larger than an outpost is going to be jagged or hold off until the party is at higher stats. People may like that, I don't. Most of everything will be built at an angle or built in weird spots.

Also progression is really nice for the game. Skill stats such as combat, crafting, building, survival all advance the more they are done and benefit from other stats. So crafting medical supplies boosts medical, which makes it faster when patching wounds. mining helps with labor, athletics, and strength. Strength boosts heavy weapon usage, while dexterity is with lighter weapons. It can be a very purposefully slow game or modded to be sped up.

Even further, modding is not that difficult really. I've made a few custom starts for myself, one being just over the top so I could explore more and see more of the map and others for more roleplay options.


The developers are very nice and understanding people. There's a small group of them working on this game. Whenever issues happen, they are pretty quick to fix them when they are able to. They've started working on the second game, but haven't abandoned the first.


I do wish to see more games like this, that are genuinely open world with very little guidance that simply states "be free with whatever."
Possibly something like a more natural medieval or fantasy based, not just Far Eastern. Same concepts, different themed games. It's a type of game not really explored and should be.


I did accidently burn myself out quickly as I pretty much played the game for weeks whenever I had free time, but I definitely enjoyed it and will come back to see major updates.

Edit: The game is finished, and I've played a lot more recently. There's definitely a lot more to the finished product that I learn to enjoy, and try attempts in. Of course I learned a lot and make a pretty easy run going. I enjoy the upcoming of a playthrough over the final portion, so restarting is often a fun concept for me. The developers are now making a Kenshi 2. (Still).
400 hours in and I feel like there's so much to do with the game

Even though I'll start by stating that this game won't be to everyone's liking, I'd be hardpressed not to recommend it, especially given the amount of enjoyment I've gotten out of Kenshi so far, before and after early access.

This game will NOT be for you if: 
- you need the game to hold your hands, tutorials will only explain certain game mechanics
- you expect the highest graphics fidelity, the graphics in this game are in no meaningful way bad to my tastes, but I realise they won't be to everyone's liking
- you can't stand a challenge ...

Cause what this game WILL offer you is in fact a challenging world in which it is up to you to survive & thrive. Starting out your first few runs, expect things not to go your way, cause there's plenty of 'things' out there, looking to beat your characters to a pulp, after which, they can be left to die, eaten alive, enslaved, ... However, as you're coming to grips with how it all works, you'll get a character/squad going, after which the surviving part'll be easier and you get the real freedom to go and explore this world on offer.

A lot of bugs have been ironed out, not saying it's running perfectly smooth for everyone, but I do feel from my personal experience the game has matured a lot , seeing only the occasional crash in beta, and seeing the crash fix quite soon in changelog.

Many games hide behind the term 'sandbox.' Often it's a euphamism for shortcomings in gameplay, setting, story, etc.  
This is not Kenshi.  
No game i know offers the freedom found in Kenshi. It truly deserves the label 'sandbox.'
There is extensive lore to discover. A world to explore. Characters to meet. Battles to fight. Treasures to acquire.
This will be difficult. You will not always succeed.  But you will always be free to decide for yourself. 
Even starting as a slave in Kenshi, i feel more freedom to explore a personal journey than any other 'sandbox' i know.

Kenshi is a role-playing game that is unlike any other. It is a game that is about freedom, exploration, and consequence. The game is known for its non-linearity, its deep character customization system, and its brutal combat. In Kenshi, you are not a chosen hero. You are just another person trying to survive in a harsh and unforgiving world. You can choose to be a good person or a bad person. You can choose to help others or to exploit them. The choices you make will affect the world around you, and they will also affect your own character.
Kenshi is a game that is not afraid to be challenging. The world can be a dangerous place, and you will have to fight for your survival. But the rewards of success are great. You can become a powerful warrior, a skilled trader, or a respected leader.
If you are looking for a role-playing game that will challenge you and reward you, then Kenshi is the game for you.

This game is the prime example of "open-world sandbox game with RPG elements"

Kenshi é um jogo de RPG e estratégia que se destaca por sua jogabilidade complexa, liberdade de escolha e desafios implacáveis. Situado em um mundo aberto e pós-apocalíptico, o jogo oferece aos jogadores a oportunidade de explorar, recrutar personagens, construir bases e sobreviver em um ambiente hostil e brutal.

Sua mecânica de jogo única, combinando elementos de RPG, simulação e estratégia, oferece uma experiência desafiadora e envolvente. A ausência de um enredo linear permite que os jogadores definam seus próprios objetivos e estratégias, o que contribui para a sensação viciante do jogo, pois cada decisão tem consequências significativas.

A dificuldade do jogo, a necessidade de gerenciar recursos, enfrentar perigos e superar obstáculos, adiciona uma camada de imersão e torna cada conquista uma verdadeira recompensa. Kenshi é aclamado por sua liberdade de jogo, permitindo aos jogadores moldar suas próprias histórias e vivenciar experiências únicas a cada sessão de jogo.

No entanto, a complexidade e a curva de aprendizado íngreme podem ser intimidadoras para alguns jogadores, mas para aqueles dispostos a mergulhar em um mundo desafiador e cheio de possibilidades, Kenshi oferece uma experiência verdadeiramente cativante e gratificante.

A Sandbox Gem with a Slow Progression Curve

Kenshi is a unique open sandbox game that offers a world of possibilities. The freedom to explore, build, and create your own story is undeniably fun. However, there's a significant downside to this experience - the painfully slow character progression.

While the open sandbox aspect of Kenshi is undeniably enjoyable, the journey of leveling up your character feels like an eternity. It's a slow and often frustrating process, which can be a major drawback for those seeking a more rewarding progression system.

In summary, Kenshi is a game with immense potential for enjoyment, thanks to its open sandbox design. Still, the excessively long and often tedious character leveling can be a major turn-off for players looking for a smoother progression experience. If you have the patience to endure the grind, the world of Kenshi is yours to conquer.

This game is really something else. If you like games like Mount and Blade, with open world, complex party and base management, this game is surely for you.
Developed by virtually one person, Kenshi is an RPG game with RTS elements. In the game you can start as a lone wanderer, citizen of one of the nations, trader, group of lowlifes and many more. You have to embark on a grand adventure to... to do whatever you want, really. And that's the beauty of it. The game has no goal, no aim. You make of it whatever you want: you want to be a trader and earn lots of cash? You can do that. Want to gather a bunch of followers and build a thriving city? No problem. Become a slave uprising leader and destroy one of the nations from the inside? You bet you can do that in this game. The world is your oyster!
Although the game looks nice, graphics is not its strong suit. Sound design, however is where it's at. The music is very atmospheric and the main theme is truely a masterpiece.
The game has also a very thriving community that creates plenty of mods. After you finish with vanilla, you can easily mod this game to your heart's content and start the whole journey once more.
The options are endless and the price is very good for so much content. Definitely worth buying!

i purchased this game just over a month ago because it looked like it had alot of potential to be a good game.  After about 6 hours or so and quite a few character restarts i was telling myself "wow, this game is hard."  But then i remember the old saying of "whatever doesnt kill you, makes you stronger ( in this case...tougher)."  So now  the start of a game became a learning curve where you learn who attacks you on sight,  which groups attack other groups on sight, which npc's will join you for free....I still spent plenty of time on my backside.  But 30 hours into the game the groups that put me there are now the ones on their backsides(and probably naked to boot too).  I'm now at 150 hours of gameplay with still plenty of areas to explore and ideas to try. If you try this game, i hope you enjoy it as much as i have. Currently over 1000 hours played and still havent visited every area on the map.  Officially my new fallback game.  Always my labor of love nominee every year

Original review:

[spoiler]Kenshi is a good game, and has a lot of potential, but I simply cannot recommend it in its current state. It feels like an early alpha or tech demo, as it doesn't have a lot of content for such a massive world, and is extremely buggy.
In just a few hours of play time, my characters got stuck in every single piece of geometry on the map, lagged behind when a move order was issued, and even with 64 GiB of RAM, and two SSDs on a RAID setup, the game would struggle to load things quickly, and it never used more than 4.7 GiB of RAM, preferring to unload the map whenever possible.
Don't get me wrong, it was fun at times, but it feels unfinished, and the bugs make it nothing short of unplayable. I can't recommend this.[/spoiler]

Lost an arm and leg. All of them, actually. Got cybernetics. Realized it was better. Purposefully removed all of my squad's limbs due to the weakness of their flesh. The purity of the blessed machine made me disliked by this, like, huge religious cult. Wiped out the cult. Casualties widespread and on both sides, but mainly the cult. These weirdos that live in some foggy place took over some towns, and these other weirdos with pointy horns of their faces did the same. Made a lot of money, a couple hundred cannibals tried to storm my base, found a malfunctioning robot leading an army of malfunctioning robots. Got wiped out, myself. Had fun, 10/10, would remove limbs, destroy a cult, and die to robots again...

Have you ever wanted to crucify religious zealots? Have you ever wanted to be a weeb Pablo Escobar and make millions selling drugs in towns? Have you ever wanted to peel off someone's skin and wear it like a flesh robe? 

All these things and more can be done IRL but a lot more safely in Kenshi.

If you're into: 
- being a nobody, and struggling for a pittance,
- being beaten to an inch of your life by weak, lowly, starving bandits,
- being captured and enslaved,
- dragging your mangled body across vast deserted, lethal wastes,
- being cooked alive by laser beams from the heavens, 
- having your skin scraped off of your body, 
- having your limbs separated from your body,
- having the rest of your body eaten alive by walking nightmares (aka "Beak Things"),
- being able to come back from all of that to turn into a "Bloodsport Bolo Yeung of the Wastes - possibly with cool robotic limbs" and kick everyone's fleshy (or metallic) ass,
- delightful soundtracks,
- The Fist of the North Star.
- Beep.

Kenshi plays like Runescape if you put it in the world of Fallout, and added a bit of the Sims, along with Star Wars, and maybe even a little Morrowind for good measure. 

This game is nuts. It's a roleplaying game in the truest sense - it just throws the player in and lets them do anything, with all of the consequences that entails. The fun comes from learning how things differ between each of the factions and just trying to exist in a brutal world that frequently tries to crush your character. 

Every nation has their own rules and standards, and then the no man's land is survival of the fittest. Learn to pick your battles as you navigate creating a life within the desert. Failure is often your greatest tool - so long as you don't die. 

Between having a unique health system and squad-based combat, death is rarely an outcome for a crafty player. The stories that unravel as you narrowly avoid destruction time and time again will keep you coming back. And you will be richly rewarded for your time. 

This game doesn't let you come back from being an inch away from death for nothing. You will steadily grow stronger, and once you hit a certain point, your progress will grow exponentially. Everything you do is worth it because it will add to your abilities. The progression system works well enough that you can go it alone and still become a god-like figure. 

I highly recommend this game. I can tell that I will be playing Kenshi for years to come.

Walked across a desert. 

Broke into an ancient tower.

Lost a leg.

Crawled across the desert.

You find yourself as a lonely wanderer in a dusty post apocalyptic world. The sky above you presents with two alien planets visible at all times. This is not Earth. As you traverse the odd, dusty landscapes you quickly find that you are not alone. This world is alive with humans, several humanoid species, and dangerous beasts. Trading in goods of all kinds, even in people is prevalent, and wars wage between bandits, slavers, starving nomads, religious zealots, cannibals, traders and homesteaders. This is the world of Kenshi, a world that asks of you only one question; Who do you want to be? What is your goal?

Indeed, there is no set goal or storyline to follow in the game other than lore books, conversations gleaned in towns, and the relics of a fallen civilization all around you. At first this lack of direction could seem bland or daunting to those expecting the typical experience of an overstated plot to hold your hand and shove you in the 'right' direction. There's no right or wrong in Kenshi, though. If you want to spend your time in game as a trader building up a caravan and selling common goods or weapons to every town you pass through, you can. If you want to be a wandering loner simply exploring each biome as you see fit, go for it. Want to build your own farm, or establish your own town and preside over it as some sort of mayor or king? You can do that too. You can be a thief, a bounty hunter, you can sell your foes into slavery or let your pets (if you have any) feast on their corpses.

The possibilities are endless. Make no mistake, there is a learning curve to this game but not in the way you might think. You only really understand the way Kenshi works when you realize your character(s) -will- be defeated. A lot. And being defeated is necessary to become more powerful. Even losing a limb in battle has its advantages, as you can eventually replace it with a more powerful mechanical prosthetic. As long as your last remaining character does not die, you can play until your heart's content. And if everyone in your control does die? It doesn't change a thing. No game over screens. The world keeps going around you until you start a new game. 

In other words, Kenshi is a truly unique game in its design. Simultaneously unforgiving but incredibly rewarding. While graphically things may at first appear a bit dated, you can still find beautiful cliff-side vistas, areas of lush green, foreboding and dangerous badlands, the bones of long dead massive creatures or robots and plenty more eye-candy.

If you're a patient gamer who values a totally unique experience, there's no reason not to buy this one! I've never felt better about a gaming purchase in years. Give it a go!

Kenshi is an open world role-playing video game developed and published by Lo-Fi Games for Windows in 2018. Development of Kenshi was carried out primarily by one person - Chris Hunt - over the course of 12 years.
Having spent more than 100 hours in this game, I can say that I didn’t spend my money in vain. The game is great, especially if you know how to play roles depending on the start and plans for the game, because if you go through the same game over and over again, you will get bored with it after starting a new game. (considering that you restarted not because you died from a small dog as soon as you started or because you weren’t eaten by cannibals).

While I personally love this game, I would not recommend it to the majority of people. That's not a snobby, neck beard, Dark Souls fan-esque, "This game is too good for most people to appreciate!" statement. The game is just genuinely unapproachable. The world is hostile, the UI is confusing and unintuitive, there is no real objective to guide you in the right direction right off the bat, no tutorial, no real easy mode, no hand holding. None of that. I must have watched 20 hours of videos describing and explaining various things about the game and I still feel like I'm stumbling in the dark half the time. 

All of that being said, there is one thing this game does better than any game I've ever encountered, and its ultimately the one thing that keeps me coming back every time. The stories you make. The game has "quests" technically speaking, they are different from how most games do them. you don't run up and talk to a character and receive a five minute exposition dump, or a cut scene. Instead you are given small tidbits about that character and the world, and the rest is intentionally left for you to infer and speculate. Because of that the world is a little bit different for every player experiencing it. On top of that, the things that happen dynamically to you shape your own unique story on the fly. You might rise from a newly captured slave to a highly sought after bounty hunter, or start out as a wandering trader only to be drawn in to the lucrative profits that smuggling offers, and your story will feel real and personal because you'll be there to experience it every step of the way, rather than a cut scene telling you how much of a bad ass you are or how lowly of a position your character started in. All of this comes together to make me feel more attached to any given Kenshi character I've made over any other scripted RPG.

To sum it all up, hiding behind Kenshi's VERY rough exterior is perhaps the most immersive and genuine experience I've ever had in a game. Do your research and know what you're getting yourself into, but if it seems like something you can handle, you owe it to yourself to give this game a shot.

Kenshi has a reputation as a brutal, unforgiving world full of impossible challenges, and to be sure, the hardest part of the game is figuring out how to get started. A typical character begins, dirt poor and clad in rags, with essentially no meaningful skills. You're easy pickings for anyone to rob or kill. It seems like the game is setting you up to fail, and you'll quickly find that scraping out a meager profit scavenging corpses and mining copper ore, and retreating to the walls of the nearest city at the first sign of a threat is just about the only thing you can manage. It's hard to see what anyone would enjoy about the experience.

The key to finding the fun in Kenshi comes with the realization that combat experience is based on how overleveled a given threat is to you, and many of Kenshi's threats will leave you unconscious but not permanently worse off. Once you discover what doesn't kill you (usually) makes you stronger, you'll find yourself eager to jump into impossible fights, knowing that losing is just as valuable as winning.

And gradually, you will start to gain ground. You claw your way up to even footing with the packs of emaciated bandits that beat and rob you. You gain a small party of fellow adventurers to even the odds. You replace your rusty blades and wooden sticks with razor sharp masterwork weapons. You establish a base of operations and build up its defenses. Threats that were once insurmountable become frustrating, then fairly mundane, and finally trivially as you advance from a hopelessly outmatched nobody to a legendary swordsman who can single-handedly take on an army.

Beneath Kenshi's hostile exterior is a game about the grueling march towards self improvement, and the satisfying look backwards to find that all your hard work has paid off.

Kenshi: A Masterpiece of Sandbox RPG Innovation

Kenshi, the brainchild of Lo-Fi Games, stands as a testament to the brilliance of open-ended sandbox gameplay. In a gaming landscape often dominated by linear narratives, Kenshi emerges as a refreshing anomaly, providing an immersive and expansive experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional RPGs.

The hallmark of Kenshi lies in its unparalleled freedom. From the outset, players are thrust into a vast, desolate world with no predetermined destiny. The absence of a linear storyline liberates the player, allowing them to carve their own path in a dystopian universe. Whether one aspires to be a noble trader traversing perilous landscapes, a cunning thief navigating city streets, or a fearless warlord leading a band of misfits, Kenshi accommodates every playstyle with seamless fluidity.

The depth of Kenshi's world-building is truly awe-inspiring. Every blade of grass, every ruin, and every character contributes to the game's rich tapestry. The game's lore unfolds not through scripted sequences but through the emergent stories that players create with their choices and actions. It is a living, breathing world where the consequences of decisions ripple across the fabric of the game, creating a dynamic and ever-evolving narrative.

The squad-based mechanics add an extra layer of complexity and realism. As players recruit and train their band of characters, witnessing them evolve from vulnerable greenhorns to seasoned warriors is a gratifying experience. Each member of the squad possesses a unique backstory and skills, making every playthrough a fresh adventure. The game's AI-driven economy and ecosystem ensure that the world is in constant flux, responding to the player's actions and creating an environment where adaptability is key to survival.

Kenshi's visuals may not boast the hyper-realistic graphics of AAA titles, but it compensates with a distinct and immersive art style. The barren landscapes and dilapidated cities evoke a sense of desolation, underscoring the harsh realities of survival in this unforgiving world. The game's soundtrack complements the atmosphere flawlessly, shifting from haunting melodies in desolate wastelands to adrenaline-pumping beats during intense battles.

The game's modding community deserves a special mention. Lo-Fi Games has fostered an environment where players can shape and enhance their Kenshi experience. From graphical improvements to gameplay overhauls, the modding scene has breathed new life into the game, showcasing the developers' commitment to fostering a community-driven experience.

However, Kenshi is not without its challenges. The difficulty curve can be punishing, demanding strategic thinking and careful resource management. Some may find the lack of hand-holding and guidance daunting, but for those willing to invest time and effort, the rewards are boundless.

In conclusion, Kenshi transcends the conventions of traditional RPGs, delivering an unparalleled sandbox experience. Its expansive world, freedom of choice, and emergent storytelling make it a masterpiece in its genre. Whether you seek the thrill of combat, the intricacies of trade, or the solitude of exploration, Kenshi invites you to forge your own destiny in a world where every decision matters. It's not just a game; it's an epic journey, an odyssey of survival and self-discovery that will leave an indelible mark on the soul of every adventurer who dares to enter its vast and treacherous landscapes.

I am not normal about this game.

This game is what you make of it. I have a pretty high tolerance for jank/bugs but I've considered dropping Kenshi multiple times for the sheer frequency of characters bugging out and getting stuck in walls. The game is also very unbalanced and several systems appear to be semi-broken or pointless. At the same time, the variety of environments and the extremely interesting world kept me coming back. Even though some parts of it don't make sense, this is very different from other "management" games I've played like Dwarf Fortress, Rimworld, etc. Overall Kenshi is like the Alpha version of the greatest RPG ever made. It's inconsistent, buggy, frustrating, and extremely interesting.

Edit:
After my characters became stuck in a wall for the 500th time and I had to recall everyone back to my base I decided to change my review to a not recommend. There's a lot to love here but the lack of polish is so extreme that it just is not worth fighting the game to see what it has to offer. It's really disappointing because I really enjoyed parts of my experience, but the game is just borderline broken. 

There really is a fantastic game under all this mess but it is just so clunky that 2/3 of game time will be spent wrestling with poorly designed mechanics, engaging in tedious micromanagement (For your own sake use the bed healing speed up mod), or finding workarounds to bugs. I really wish the game would get out of its own way and let me explore this weird and fascinating setting. I hope that someday this game reaches its potential but it seems like the developer is already working on a prequel/sequel so its unlikely.

Assassinate noblemen, trade drugs, befriend ancient robots, hop in and embrace your inner degenerate. If you like facing unexpected challenges in an open world, this is the perfect game for you. Kenshi's strongest feature is how lively the game feels. The map is rich with content that encourages players to explore, and different regions of the continent have unique biomes. Gameplay can be tough at first, but the feeling you get from powering up is so rewarding. The game definitely isn't perfect, and you'll find the AI getting stuck on pathing pretty often. Some of the visuals can be a little bland as well, but fits well within the cohesive style. Even after many hours, Kenshi still surprises me at every turn. Please give this game a shot if you like open worlds.

It took a while, maybe three years before I finally understood how to approach this game but when I "got it" I was hooked.
Kenshi is a game with no story, you have to make your own, it's like a table top RPG with the game mechanics acting as the dungeon master, perfect for introverted nerds like myself. 
As in real life, this game doesn't care about your character, you're not the hero, if you die the game will continue to play without you just to show you how little concern it had for you. No game over screen here.
Put some effort into creating a story for your play through and you'll be rewarded though, I laughed when High Inquisitor Seta was defeated and carried off by slave traders, cried when my loyal pack of bonedogs were butchered in front of me by starving bandits and proud when Beep joined my team.
Sure, you can grind until you're OP then defeat all the bosses but that's easy and been done by so many other games time and again but this game offers you the chance for so much more, this game offers the chance for a completely unique story every time you play it because you make the story and no one knows where that story will take you.

Kenshi is an excellent survival sandbox open world game that doesn't throw any punches and expects you to fight back and not only settle for simple subsistence but persistence and flourishing in this rugged realm. There are competing factions that fight each other for control over a diverse continent and your character is thrown in the middle of it. There are hundreds of permutations and the world responds to your actions whether you remain a humble merchant or become a warlord and establish your own city. For me, the world of Kenshi is continuously fascinating and you won't learn about it through conventional means but by talking to NPCs, finding books and items across the world and simply by studying the environment around you. This was a world that has fallen.

[b]Kenshi is a difficult game to get into, but is worth it with how diverse and unique of an experience it is to play. If you're even remotely interested in it, give it a solid chance and you might be surprised at what you find.[/b]


Kenshi is an interesting mix of sandbox RTS, and an old-school MMO despite being single-player only.
You can control 1-30 characters, shape them in any way you see fit, and use them to explore an interesting post-post apocalyptic world.


Everything that a character does is tied to a stat. From fighting and sneaking, to simply running. 
So, everything a character does will improve over time. 
As a result, Kenshi has an incredibly satisfying feeling of progression - which is even further emphasized with how difficult the early game can be.



For better or worse, Kenshi has the absolute bare minimum in-game direction for the player. 
When starting a new file, all you will be greeted by is a scary looking HUD, and some barebones tutorial popups. 
After that you're all on your own.
Mix this with a difficult early game, and Kenshi can feel very impenetrable at first.


However, if the game sounds interesting to you in the slightest, I'll repeat, it's extremely worth pushing forward despite its jagged edges.

=========================================================


[b]THE GOOD:[/b] 
+Very unique RPG experience.
+Extremely moddable. VERY modular experience. Play how you want.
+You will spend a lot of hours on it if you like it.

[b]THE BAD:[/b]

-Modding is low-key required to have a smooth experience late-game.
-The game runs like a dumpster fire and you will have to accept this.
-Open world feels empty. There's nothing interesting to find that isn't marked on your map as you approach.

[b]THE INTERESTING:[/b]

>No in-game direction for the player. A true sandbox RPG. It's very easy to fall into your own 'campaign', and have it play out naturally. 
However, if you have difficulty making your own fun, you will have problems finding motivation to continue playing for long.

31 hours in and I'm still trying to figure out what the fuck I'm doing. Seriously.


Edit:

I'm now at 106 hours and have chosen a life of selling alcohol, narcotics, and slaves to people. It's the only way I've survived in such a hellish world.

Edit again:

After a couple hundred hours in the game, I can say with certainty that this game is about the buggiest, most incomplete and frustrating lump of shit I'll probably never quit playing. The amount of frustration for ... everything ... this game is and offers is only rivaled by the amount of fun you'll have trying to survive.

I recommend this game, but keep in mind it's incomplete and the dev likely won't make very many updates, since Kenshi 2 is in development.

A Brutally Realistic Sandbox RPG - A Hidden Gem

Rating: ★★★★★

Kenshi is a hidden gem in the world of open-world sandbox RPGs, offering a brutal and unforgiving experience that rewards patience and perseverance. Here's why Kenshi deserves a solid five-star rating:

Vast and Unforgiving World: Kenshi's post-apocalyptic, sword-punk world is massive and unforgiving. It doesn't hold your hand, and you're free to carve out your own path, whether it's as a warrior, trader, thief, or farmer. The world is filled with danger, opportunity, and mysteries to discover.

Freedom of Choice: You have the freedom to shape your character and your story. You can recruit companions, build your own base, start a business, become a warlord, or explore the world as a lone wanderer. The game doesn't impose a predefined narrative, allowing you to create your own adventures.

Complex Economy: Kenshi features a deep economic system, where your actions can impact trade routes, faction relations, and the prosperity of settlements. Whether you're a merchant or a raider, your choices have far-reaching consequences.

Unique Characters and Factions: The game is populated by diverse and unique characters and factions, each with its own lore and goals. Interacting with them adds depth to the world and creates dynamic and often challenging relationships.

Challenging Combat: Combat in Kenshi is tough but rewarding. You'll need to train your characters and employ tactics to survive battles. The game's limb damage system adds a layer of strategy and realism.

Modding Community: Kenshi has a passionate modding community that has created a wealth of user-generated content, from quality-of-life improvements to total conversion mods. This extends the game's replay value and customization.

Ongoing Development: The developer, Lo-Fi Games, has continued to update and improve Kenshi since its release, addressing bugs and adding new content.

While Kenshi offers a remarkable gaming experience, it's important to note that its steep learning curve and initially harsh difficulty can be intimidating. However, for players who enjoy challenging and deep sandbox experiences, it's an incredible journey into a unique and harsh world.

In summary, Kenshi is a masterpiece of emergent storytelling, offering unparalleled freedom and depth in an unforgiving post-apocalyptic world. It's a must-play for those who appreciate the complexity of sandbox RPGs and the thrill of creating your own epic adventure in a brutal and immersive setting.

To put simply, no other game will be like Kenshi. Its brutal. Its strange. Its clunky. Its breathtaking. Nothing else will make me feel what I felt seeing my boy serpentine away from beak-things only to lead them to a city for them to be slaughtered and for me to sneak out and scavenge their hides for scraps. Nothing else compares to building a home only for starving bandits to demand food, break down my gates, beat my guys up, then rob me of my possessions and leave. Not even RimWorld can invoke these feelings, you don't have pawns in RimWorld get kidnapped, then sent away to a slave camp, only for said slave camp to get attacked by giant land bats and have everyone get eaten and killed except for you.
Its all around a great game with some bugs but so many amazing mods to choose from.

This is an interesting game. It took me a while to wrap my head around, but I feel like I'm starting to get it. There are so many different game mechanics and strategies to try out, let alone the fact that random stuff is just taking place everywhere. You can customize the gameplay in a ton of ways, too, so if something feels too difficult or not difficult enough - you can tailor it to your style. Or just mess around and have fun. Most of my games so far have been less than a week before death, slavery or imprisonment and it's fine! Sometimes you just spend another week trying to get out of prison, losing both your limbs and eventually dying. Again - totally fine! These are learning experiences and like I said, I feel like I'm starting to get it but I also understand that I'm really just scratching the surface.

The game became a recruit-a-thon for my outpost to have people harvest resources to research technology while having endless mobs constantly attack even when i would dispose of corpses. Kenshi is a miserable game full of miserable people in a miserable world that expects your pathetic, frail body to squeeze joy out of dust. And you will. It won't be enough to satisfy. Not because the game hates you like many difficult games, but it's because this game is purely apathetic towards you and your plight. Those men on the horizon walking towards your unconscious body will mend your wounds, yes, but only because they have a wonderful set of chains to put you in.

The world does not care about you. During your efforts to squeeze out that joy you will become less weak and MAKE the world care. You will raise an army, or perhaps just become one. Or maybe you won't. Maybe even with your increasing lack of weakness you'll remain on the sidelines. They'll come to you. They'll be the ones who makes YOU care.

Smith the strongest weapons and armor, replace the weakness of your limbs with the strength of steel, and stockpile enough food to last longer than you could hope to live. The dust will claim it all one day. It always does. You will stand back up and happily become weak again. Kenshi may not care about you, but you will care about Kenshi.

Kenshi is one of those Legendary games that you can replay over and over, like Diablo 2, Sid Meyers Pirates and other cult favorites that can sit on your HDD for years, just in case you feel like playing again. And again And again.
This game is unforgiving, demanding, beautiful and rewarding. And the world is alive!
The AI NCPs are not static statues, as in other PC games, who wait for the players action to react. 
Its a living biodome! Totally interactive and changes with not only each action you take, but each action the NCPs do {even off screen}.
The graphics are now somewhat outdated, but still amazing when watching dozens of individuals fight each other in a battle. Each with their own animation, individual style and custom look -according to what armor, clothing or weapons are equipped.
If you like RPG strategy adventures that don't give a f*ck if you are face down in the dirt... if you are trapped in a cage for weeks {because the guards forgot you}, if you cant outrun a giraffe from Hell that will eat you alive into permadeath... or capture prisoners of your own to torture in blissful payback, kidnap world leaders, collect heads to sell for profit or build an epic city of your own with a post-apocalyptic, steampunk, feudal Japanese, wild western Sims vibe, THIS is the game for you!
Play vanilla or add a few mods from an extensive list available {recommended}.
For the price of a pizza, you too can spend almost 700 hours playing this masterpiece!
We are all looking forward to Kenshi 2 in the distant future.

Kenshi is one of the best survival/simulation games I've ever played. After breaking off from mainstream market games (fps/moba) and heading into more niche games like this, playing Kenshi is way more fun. There is a huge world to engage with and a plethora of mods that expand upon it even more. If you want to play as a solo character and try to take on the world's toughest enemies, it's definitely possible. If you want to micro-manage a squad of 100 people and designate them each an individual job, go for it. This is a great game for people who enjoy Rimworld or The Sims.

     In 2023, the graphics are a bit outdated and it's not as optimized as newer games, so it can take a bit of time to get the settings the way you like. The game, plus 30-40 mods, won't be bigger than 20GB which is nice for lower end PC's.  I'd suggest putting it on an SSD even though it is older. But, nonetheless, I recommend you try it out. Grab it on sale at the very least.

Pros:
In-Depth Character Customization
Animal/People Trading
Colony/Squad Management
A Vast World to Explore
Minimal System Requirements To Play
Cannibalism

Cons:
Loading/Rendering Time (for everything)
No Tutorial
Can Require Mods To Fix Some Issues

My PC Specs:
MSI B450 Tomahawk
AMD Ryzen 5 2600
RTX 2060
16 GB DDR4 3200
2TB WD Black
Samsung 970 EVO SATA SSD 500GB
Windows 10

This game is MIGHTY addictive. My very first playthrough attempt ended in disaster as I was jumped by a gang of bandits the second I left the town I spawned in. Turns out your characters WILL get their asses kicked most of the time to begin with, and the wonderful automated combat means there's nothing you can do about it. Lessons were learned.

On my second attempt, I made a hasty getaway from the previous ambush spot, only to be eaten alive by an evil brontosaurus thing. Again, nout I could do about it. More lessons were learned... Mostly the importance of running away.

This, combined with having to carefully plan out your base building, makes up for an experience that will constantly keep you on your toes. Or maybe you don't want to build a base, and prefer to join a band of mercenaries? That's cool, you can. Don't fancy killing, and want to be a humble trader? That's great. You can.

Either way you choose to do things, something WILL go wrong. Most recently, I was knocked unconscious and shanghaied by slavers. Planning my escape just gives me one more thing to work towards.

Kenshi is a great survival roleplaying game. The combat is hands off and mostly made up of movement and equipment. The game is a bit grindy though which is really the only negative I have about the game, that you have to grind before the game even becomes enjoyable. But the game does allow you to play how you want.

City building whilst fun I feel like the tech-tree is just really going through the motions, yes the more advanced techs require you to go looking for special items, these can be looted easily though if your stealth is high enough so the city building isn't really a challenge and I would in fact urge against doing it too early as it falls into the same annoyances as RimWorld and StarSector fall into where its just wave after wave of annoying enemies which is nearly always mitigated by designing elaborate kill boxes to game the system.

The world of kenshi is amazing though, its a very unique world and the art for the game is really well done and suits the style. It has a very unique look to it. I love the alien characters the game has which would all fit right at home in star trek or star wars.

Certainly one of the most unique games you will ever play. I highly recommend. Fair warning though it can be a bit buggy with characters glitching out and falling through the ground. I do think the physics engine was a mistake it just doesn't work well at all for this game.

I don't mind hard games, but this game is designed to be hard, while also not being designed all that well, so you're fighting poor game design in a game meant to be hard. Either one of those would probably be fine, but together it comes together for a poor game experience. Things like the map not being oriented north, immense areas of map that only exist to create space without having anything there to actually engage you, characters that don't quite behave the way you expect them to, a poor tutorial system, and more awkwardness. Combine this with a game designed to provide next to no resources, and no way to carry what you do find, I just couldn't get myself engaged. I would only recommend this to people who enjoy  working through a steep learning curve on an unforgiving game.

I love this game so much. It's so unique but it feels like a kernel of something more, and there really is nothing like this on the market. If Kenshi 2 is just this game in a better engine, even without new mechanics, it might become my favorite game. But this game has so many deal-breaking flaws such as:

- Bad UI
- Terrible visuals
- Awful load times
- Weird camera
- Lack of meaningful dialogue or characters
- Base-building is only feasible late-game
- Any amount of mods makes the performance even worse than it already is
- Descriptions of character stats that are just wrong

And lastly, the best way to do anything is way better than the alternatives by a lot, so as soon as you know them, the game becomes stale.

But Kenshi's brutally difficult progression and world spark my imagination like nothing else, so I still love this game, but man...

I still recommend this game. It's more interesting than anything else in the genre (open-world rpg sandbox), and if you're the right type of person this will be your favorite game, but I'm done until Kenshi 2 comes out in 2035.

I figure Kenshi deserves a review from me, considering the amount of time and the uncountable number of play throughs I've done.

The reality is Kenshi is one of one in my mind. When you look at the "More like this" section of it's store page, as a person who's played Kenshi you realize how unlike Kenshi all those games really are.

Kenshi is possibly the greatest sandbox that exists in gaming. It's a true do whatever you want game, the freedom feels unparalleled, and while you begin the game as nothing, you can conquer this world with enough time, patience and a large enough group.

There is lore, and things to discover about this mission, and there are a handful of missions/quests you can find out in the world, but there is no real narrative or goal/objectives for your character outside of survival and trying to carve out a life in a harsh world that does not care whether you live or die. 

You will watch your character bleed out as characters walk by ignoring you, hoping that one NPC might care enough to bandage you up before they walk away.

The graphics aren't going to blow you away, and even on higher end PCs there can be optimization issues that create frustrating frame rate issues that you will feel you shouldn't be running into, but there is literally nothing in this game that would keep me from recommending it to anyone who finds it at all interesting. If there is ANY PART of you that thinks you might enjoy it, I recommend it wholeheartedly.

Okay, so... Originally I disliked the game for being too grindy, difficult, and its lack of fast travel. But that was when I had ten hours. This game has really grown on me now. Maybe you won't like it at first, but it definitely gets better the more you play.

I still have problems with the lack of fast travel. I still don't like watching characters run for 15 minutes when I'm crossing the map. Also, the constant loading if you run at 3x speed (which you will). And for many aspects of the game, you'll want to be doing something on your phone while the game does its thing.

However, my opinion on all the other aspects has very much improved. There's a steep learning curve, but master that and you can start your playthrough off well. Training your stats can be grindy sometimes, but grindy in a good way. Seeing your characters progress is very satisfying, especially when they go from weaklings incapable of fighting of a starving peasant to being able to take on entire squads of armed soldiers with just three men.

The game is totally open ended, and you can choose to be literally anything. While many games that advertise themselves as "open ended" have a lot of restrictions on just what you can be, Kenshi does not (mostly, at least). If an NPC can do it, you can do it with enough training.

I could keep going, but I honestly don't feel like writing any more. Point is, Kenshi is a good game. It's definitely not for everyone, but it's an amazing game if you do end up playing it. I eagerly await Kenshi 2.

The atmosphere and setting pays homage to the greats; The original Fallout titles, Wasteland, ATOM,UnderRail, and many others, while bringing something fresh and unique in its own special way. 

  HOWEVER, it is entirely ruined by what I can only describe as an extremely contagious mental infirmity. Everything revolves around weebsticks. 
   There is this rich space age sci-fi setting, with robots, spaceship debris, mechs, alien life both sentient and non sentient, all wrapped up in a dystopian setting; and instead of anything even remotely related to any of that: the focus is mindless non strategic weebstick brawling. 

    "What about the xbows?" I hear the mouth breathers ask. Well, they are bait, plain and simple. The Ai is so completely fucking stupid that upon any single enemy getting within a half football field, the xbow incest products switch to weebsticks and charge like a bunch of mouth breathing weeaboos after watching japanese cartoons for 2 hours. No, there is no way to give orders related to tactics or strategy. It was made that way by design. The "stealth" run animation is really all one needs to see to reach this conclusion. 
  The ENTIRE point is weebsticks, which is a really damn shame. Such a waste of potential and talent.

   
   The whole premise is that thousands and thousands of years of war have ravaged a once great society..bla bla bla. Therefore, guns dont exist ect ect. Its flimsy at best. Just having the mere knowledge that guns exist/existed, well, read about peter struedinger. guy made a fucking shotgun while in jail and escaped with it. You also mean to tell me that every faction decided it was best to cease all RND and not invent ways to get a tactical edge? The first gun recorded was used in the year 1364. I'll let you do the math as far as how long modern civilization has been around.    

  So..the game. By itself, I wouldn't bother with this shit cake on a plate if it was for free.
  But what about mods? Can mods save it? Make it the way it should have been on release? Not entirely, but by the gods does it help. 
   For instance, gun mods, and proper stealth animation mods, and mods that allow the use of ranged weapons while hidden...yes it actually takes a mod to implement that. pathetic.
   I've personally been having a blast micro managing one character with a shotgun. Google JonTron shotgun vs sword, should be a 51 second clip. Pretty fun. as for the other npcs that decide to use guns? well, lets just say that an armed society is a polite society.

One of the best vibes out there ever. Nothing ever invoked the sense of wonder and adventure for me quite like Kenshi--and you don't get much of that in your 30's after more than two decades of video games.

If you liked the surreal world of Morrowind, the weird wide world of Kenshi will scratch your itch.

There is no voice acting, so you can bask in solemn silence in the middle of nowhere. The music is amazing, too.

The bugs are many, and they are annoying as hell. But the game at its core mechanics is already annoying enough so that the bugs make little difference. Just like your characters grow tougher, your mind, too, is getting tempered. The controls are well thought-thru.

I've only recently bought the Steam version for workshop mods (Valve, gimme my mods back for games I own on GOG!), but I've played well above 800 hours already. Only WoW and Minecraft can beat this number.

I started in a run down city in the middle of a rocky desert with no life in sight outside of the walls, and barely any inside for that matter.
From what I had seen from the trailers it didn't seem like things got any better, so I decided to stay around the city and try to find a good way to make money.

I started by mining at a iron vein near by the city. It was a pretty rough start since my first try I got instantly attacked by a bandit while on 4x speed. Needless to say I barely got away with my life.

Eventually things started going my way. I got a few hundred cats worth of iron, sold them at the shop, and started getting some gear. My plan was to become a bounty hunter, mainly because I held a grudge against that bandit that attacked me and his entire kind.

Things were going well. The area around the city was relatively safe and explorable and the city was always a safe haven if I ever got into trouble. Then, one fateful day, an entire army of bandits walked straight into it. I decided this was a great way to get loot for free, so I incited a fight that eventually turned into a large battle. There were at least 2 dozen bandits, and the only dedicated guards the city had were 3 ninjas, so I was somewhat worried it wouldn't work out.

However, despite being outnumbered more than 5 to 1, the ninjas absolutely decimated the gang of bandits. It was admittedly pretty cool to watch them hack and slash through the hoard, fighting while surrounded on all sides on a flight of stairs.

At the end of the battle, the ninjas sent the bandits packing, having only lost one of their own. I got a ton of great loot from the bandits, but I made a big mistake when I looted the ninjas' dead companion. Apparently people in this game don't take kindly to you when they see you wearing their dead friends clothes. This wouldn't have been too much of an issue, there aren't too many problems in the early game that you can't outrun.

However, after the battle, by some bug or feature (probably a bug) the ninjas seemed to have completely taken over the town. There was a ninja standing where the old shopkeep used to be, and another one always watching outside the bar. The city was unsafe, and more importantly, unprofitable. I had to leave.

The main issue with this is that this city was the only one really that was marked on the map. To find another city I had to go somewhere else, but I didn't know where. I wasn't gonna look it up; I'm no dirty cheater. Unfortunately I probably should have. I went north, the wrong direction apparently,

I wandered through the desert, becoming more and more desperate in my search for another city as I began to run out of resources. I came across a few outposts, but none of them had a place to sell my loot (I was overburdened btw) or buy any food. 

I was forced to become an outlaw, causing chaos and stealing food while guards weren't looking just to stay alive. I had become the very thing I had swore to destroy. 

Things only got worse. I was now a wanted man by the massive empire of religious zealots that I was apparently in the middle of. This became the least of my worries as I was jumped by a group of hungry bandits in the middle of the desert. I managed to escape relatively unharmed (thank whatever gods there are in Kenshi that I was sensible enough to buy some first aid kits at the first town before things fell apart), but my left leg was critically injured.

Eventually I was no longer able to walk, and had to crawl my way through the desert while I began to starve. I realized that my only hope was to find some civilization in this wasteland. They were probably going to lock me up on sight, but at least they would feed me. Hopefully...

Things seemed hopeless as I continued to crawl north, but just as I was about to give up I saw a weird looking outpost on the horizon. I was saved! I crawled towards it with the tiny bit of strength I had left in me. Guards rushed out of the gates, beat me up a little, then immediately hauled me to their prison. Things were looking up.

Not only did the guards save me, they even healed me and put me in some weird hunger stasis spell so that I wouldn't starve to death. This was so kind that I decided that I would wait out my entire sentence without trying to escape. I decided I would try to start a new life and try to become a soldier for the kingdom. Maybe one day I could become a lord or something.

[hr][/hr]
(the following part of the review pertains to a bug that I was somewhat able to fix and is no longer relevant)

Unfortunately, this is where my cool Kenshi story ends. Because, once my sentence ended, no one came. I waited another 20 minutes on top of the 30 I had already spent to serve my time (at max speed btw) and no guards came to free me. Apparently this is a long lasting and relatively common bug in the game, which is WILD considering getting locked up seems to be the most common thing that can happen to you in the world of Kenshi right behind dying. Escaping isn't really an option either, my leg is still completely busted and even if it wasn't the outpost is apparently a unique outpost filled with a type of guards that are even stronger than normal, making sneaking past them impossible and fighting them even more impossible with my low level character. Oh, and on top of that there is near constant acid rain around the outpost which I have no protection against and will very quickly injure me even if I do manage to make it outside. It's a perfect prison.

So I'm basically softlocked. I really wanted to like this game, and believe me Im going to try to like it whether it wants me to or not. I'm not giving up yet; I'll try a couple ideas to try to break out of the prison, the most extreme being dropping basically all of my possessions just to get a little extra stealth and sneaking out during a brief period of no rain. Feel free to help me out in the comments if you want. As soon as I get out of this I will update my review but as of now I'm leaving the game as a thumbs down because this situation is ludicrous even for a game that is supposed to be buggy.
[hr][/hr]

I found the only good way to fix this softlock was by soft resetting the world basically. Something kenshi lets you do with the click of a button which is nice. I believe that the infinite jail time bug occurs most commonly at outposts, so pro tip avoid any outposts where you are wanted at all costs unless you are confident you can escape. Unfortunately though, since my character was dropped back at the world spawn the entire story from above is...non canon I guess? The review has been changed to a positive but would definitely be a mixed review if possible, since its a perfect example of how some problems in this game can seriously ruin the immersion it creates. Still a recommend if you can put up with high amounts of jank and potentially frustrating issues, since its a really unique game.

Anyway this review is way too long already so thanks for coming to my story time Ted Talk.

I still vividly remember the first review I read of this game with the line "This game doesn't care about you" as the basic premise and it sticks to me to this day. Years later I realize how wrong they were about Kenshi. Not only does this game care about you, it wants to protect you from yourself and keep pushing you forward to success. Dying is actually kind of difficult unless you tweak the settings or act like a complete idiot. Yes, in fact, this game cares about you so much that you are REWARDED for failing. You grow stronger with each battle and even earn more xp for losing. Even with all the settings cranked up to be the most brutal, bandits will never steal your equipped items if they beat you unconscious and rob you, and even if you get imprisoned, the stuff they take is locked away in a chest and never despawns. This game does care about you, in fact, it wants you to succeed, like a stoic parent that knows you need to grow up to be strong so you are prepared for the brutal world ahead of you. It will punish you for stupid mistakes, and reward you for clever strategies, and even if you get beaten nearly to death, you will come out of that experience stronger than ever. In fact, the best way to get stronger early on is to let bandits repeatedly beat the piss out of you. There are so many ways to make money and so many safety nets to pull you back from the brink of losing it all. Even being maimed and losing a limb isn't the end, because you can buy or steal robotic limbs that are as good if not better than what you had before. 

I held off for years from buying this game because I believed the top review at the time telling me "this game doesn't care about you" and I took that as "you can lose everything in an instant because this game isn't fair" but that just isn't true. Even if you lose a limb, even if you nearly starve to death, even if you get robbed or enslaved you will almost always come out stronger than ever. This game wants to make you a god by beating you down and refining you under massive pressure to be the diamond it knows you can be. 

Don't make the mistake I did, get this game and know that no matter how bad things get or how grim things appear to be, you will almost always have a way out that will end with you tougher than before. Just remember, stay away from the Beakthings.

Here are some tips and overall gameplay experience of Kenshi. I hope it helps for your troubles:

🔸At the beginning the world is far stronger than you. Your character just sucks as you start from very bottom (You will die a lot). 
🔸Play cautiously. Hit spacebar for pause. You will have time to think. Don't try to be a brave guy. 
🔸Save scum. You may find yourself in the middle of the fight suddenly or you might be attacked by neutral factions for something that you have triggered (in towns expecially).
🔸This game is buggy af. Expect crashes, weird things etc. You can import your save file for the last resort.
🔸Border Zone is probably best location for beginners since it has less dangerous bandits and creatures and also it is close to two major factions.
🔸Well you may think that buying a fine weapon and a shining armor set should make stronger you. Remember that actually in Kenshi, literally everything is about your characters' SKILL. Even a decent sabre will do fine job with your op character.
🔸Travel and discover as much as you can. Kenshi is a rpg game that has tons of things to discover. Don't miss the content.
🔸The world Kenshi is unforgiving and brutal. Don't trust anyone.
🔸LOOT, LOOT, LOOT!
🔸There are major factions and they have some kind of set of rules. Learn them and obey their rules if you are penniless weak mfker. And they are waging wars. In fact, in every corner of the world, people kill each other. 
🔸You can set up a base but don't do that at early. It is mid-game content and when you do, you will have to defend your place.
🔸Weapons and gears have pros and cons. You should be saying which one is the best, which one is good for x? Well, it is the learning curve of the game. Search about it and get the overall idea.
🔸You should want to use some backpack for carrying extra stuff. Kenshi offers wide range of backpacks (also for your domesticated animals). If you need huge carrying capacity, then forget about fighting. A small backpack is also usable for "I want carry stuff and also fight". Btw, the more you carry, the less speed you'll have while running, and running is everything.
🔸You can find different shops in towns that you can distinguish them by their sign hanged. Night time they are closed. Don't disturb them or else you will be attacked by town guards and then get arrested.
🔸Bars are the places that can you find people for your gang. They will be weak too. Some unique recruits Low-mid range of skills tho.
🔸Food. You will need much food. Buying is easiest way but gathering meat from animals is cost effective (you are not killing them, they will be hunted by who knows. You will just loot the meat).
🔸And finally, prepare a long time-consuming game!

Kenshi plays like the Pre-Alpha Demo for the best game ever made

All the building blocks are there, it has every feature you could ever ask for and a massive interesting world. But it is the definition of a ocean wide and a puddle deep. I still havent seen everything in the game, but once you see something you basically know everything about it. And it does feel like the features are lacking in alot of ways, for instance there are basically only a handful of armour sets worth using, if you want heavy armour there is samurai armour or there is samurai armour or maybe you could try using some samurai armour (Or I guess crab armour if you want to make your character bad). There is exactly zero interaction when it comes to combat except maybe manually dodging attacks by moving your character but this isnt intentional, stealth is somehow less deep than skyrim, trade is as simple as X city pays Y amounts for Z markets dont change in any way (no way to influence prices by raiding trade caravans or anything like that), the "evolving world" is about as complex as if you kill X character Y city becomes destroyed no actual changes in factions no interacting with characters to cause civil wars or take power or change factions in any way, I can count on one maybe two hands the amount of NPCs you can talk to that are more then just "Give me your money" or "Give me your money for Y" or "Do X for me", the game doesn't even have a charisma skill so you can tell how little role playing there is to do in terms of interactions. Etc etc list goes on

Yet somehow for some reason. This is the single most captivating RPG ever made even in its half finished, broken, barely interactive, hardly functional state. Whenever I start a new run a entire week of my life vanishes. I just snap out of a trance with a character that has 90+ in every stat and has single handedly killed what realistically should be the entier population of the island three times over, and just realize that I havent done anything else for the last 5 days and I cant remember the last time I ate dinner. I dont think any other game can make running across a desert for 6 hours straight with 200kg of iron in your backpack to train strength somehow fun. Or just whole sale slaughtering essentially land whales for multiple days in a row and then spending another 5 hours straight of running around the world just to sell those 10kg pearls just so you can get a amount of money you dont actually need. And that is somehow engaging game play. This satanic curse the game somehow puts on me only seems to ware off after I have accomplished some absolutely ridiculous stuff for equally dumb reasons. like "Oh I want to get to 99 melee attack I guess ill just destroy the entirety of the united cities and holy nation so I can grind my stats a bit more". "I want $1 million for no particular reason. I guess ill kill every single bounty in the game with my solo character". I do not know how or why this game does this, I dont even usually think much about it, but whenever I decide to start a new run for no particular reason this just happens and it really is not okay.

This game has me so captivated and I'm happy I bought it in the first place. When I first started out, I didn't know anything. All I was doing was roaming and figuring out how to play. I struggled badly and I didn't understand until I got a feel and just did things my way. In Kenshi, you can become a lot of different things and partake in different events or roles. I specifically decided I wanted to do whatever I wanted. Fight any factions, steal from whoever, and just roam the lands as a person with no goal but to do what I want. Instead of having a goal, I just roam and figure out what I wanna do on the spot. I've joined and fought against so many different factions. The main character I've been playing for a while now is named bruhman. He is very special too me in a way. Bruhman is a martial artist, and for awhile I've been getting him very strong and trying to have him reach too the top in Kenshi. He's super good at lock picking, stealth running/walking, and thievery. My main way of getting cats for him is too just steal and sell. All these people are making farms and that's pretty cool but It's just easier for me too steal from shops and resell to tech hunters. I know I said I didn't have any goals, but I've been coming up with goals for bruhman. Too be the best martial artist, the strongest, and just dominate the terrifying lands of Kenshi. So far that's been going well. I hope whoever is reading this plans on getting Kenshi, if you truly understand the game, you won't regret it. PS: My opinion is too start from rock bottom so once you get stronger, you can get a robot limb.

This game is very fleshed out with mechanics as complicated as piloting a commercial airliner and that are as polished as a piece of metal that is so rusty that if you touched it your body would enter renal shutdown. The character models look like they have been hit with every illness since the dawn of man. And the combat is about as satisfying and fun as shoving pencils into your ears. The exploration is not forgiving because if you step into the wrong area you will be beat and stabbed by a bunch of religious and racist soldiers who are so devoted to their beliefs that if you are the slightest bit different you will be captured and sent to Guantanamo Bay. The building and base management has more complexity than a control station at a nuclear facility and the squad management makes me want to tear my eyes out. Still a 11/10 though.

The world of kenshi is a terrible place to live. you'll make your perfectly designed character thinking "Yeah it says the game is hard but it can't be that bad." you'll load up the Wanderer start seeing as it has the description "This is the way Kenshi was meant to be played." and you'll find yourself in the Hub, the saddest sack of shit place you could ever find yourself. The place is run by 2 factions that you'll find don't even matter, former holy nation servants, and the ninja smugglers. The first thing you'll notice is that you have nothing, all you have is a metal stick some rag pants and 1000 cats (the in game currency). You have a couple options but you're new so you go to the only building you see nearby with the word BAR out front. You'll go inside and a man will greet you so you'll probably go talk to him, he's the bar keep, but this is a ninja bar so he's selling a bit of everything. Food, weapons, bounty posters, books, random materials, etc. But you'll also notice something else, you can barely afford lunch let alone a weapon, so you buy yourself some food and maybe some bandages if you spot them and head out of town to try and figure out how to make money to get equipment. You'll probably see the iron resource nearby or if you're clever the copper ones a little further away and start mining, but it's slow and boring, so you speed up time. After watching for a little bit you probably get bored take what you've mined and sell it for scraps. maybe if you spent a couple hours doing this you'd get enough money to gear yourself but that's boring, so you go off to fight something. Maybe you got a weapon, probably a low quality katana or a saber and looking for a direction to go you look at your map and see a location called Squin. So you right click and watch, then you run across a group of hungry bandits. Now, you're not an idiot and you know you cant 1v10 a group of bandits even if they're starving so you run. You manage to outrun most and now only one is chasing you, now surely you're character weak as they are can beat a malnourished bandit so you send them to fight the single bandit. You lose. Badly. but surely your character will get back up so you can bandage yourself you just need to wait out the KO timer. What's a recovery coma...?

This is a tough one, and when i wrote this review i also took into account the cost of the game. 

Its borderline for me to recommend because the game is really hard work. But hard work in a good way if you stick with it.

Its taken me 20 hours to actually click with it. Multiple restarts, giving up early on and not playing then the other day i decided to give it another try. I started as the enslaved guy and for some reason this gave me a purpose and got me playing, trying to escape.

The game is really unique in how hard it is, giving you little to no help and zero direction so you have to make your own adventures. But once you figure it you can have a cool experience. 

So far in my  new game ive recruited a good band of 4 (plus me) and tried to set up a base, this was captured and taken over and i had to run for my life. Had near death with beak things, luckily ran into some beserkers who killed them for me, and as i went to heal their leader as thanks the jumped on me, so time to run again all the way back to the city. 

The game works best if you tentatively explore but be ready to run, take some fights nearer the cities but keep a man in reserve dont commit everyone, because if you all get ko and badly, no one will wake. 

So far this seems to work well for me and im loving the game. Just raided an old cache of old tech and got "rich" in my terms of over 20,000 gold (To mine a day you will  make about 3 k with 2 or 3 people to put that in context. My guys are secure with food in their bellies, semi decent gear and learning new skills.

The downsides to this game are really hidden storytelling and world building. There are small books which give really limited info in pubs. Some people give you one or two lines of conversation but its really limited. At first this is cool but later it becomes frustrating as you dont know why anything is as it is or who is doing what. They should have put more books into the world for you to read and made the characters in town have longer conversation lines and such, the system is capable of doing it. Just something simple like a guy who describes whats going on in that faction or a guy who you can ask questions but there is very little of that.

As an example in one town you can ask "you want an alliance" to which they say why would i ally with a guy with a rusty sword? And then you can say well what if i kill blah blah for you? But who even is this blah blah? I dont know who im offering to kill or where they are?  This side of the game is severly lacking and would be really really simple to remedy... If i  knew how to make mods and a bit about the lore i could even do it. 

Other than that the radiant events that happen are what make the game great, and watching the computer create moments. These ultimately save the game if you are willing to keep trying and get through the early stages.

Another great gameplay moment I had for example was seeing a group of guys in an outpost, Kralls Chosen. The guys are tough for me but i noticed a big fight between them and some traders. The fight was so close and i ran in to try to help the traders, backing back out when it was going badly. The traders won and i managed to get the leader of Kralls chosen who had a 30k bounty!!! This is insane early game. I grabbed him and my other team mate who had her leg wrecked and so my team of 3 (this was early game) headed to the nearest city to turn in the bounty. 2 running with one friend one enemy on their backs. Then when i was almost there a group of wolves attacked me. I had to drop the body and fight for my life. The whole team were downed and as this fight went on the bad guy got up an limped off lol!! I managed to get one companion up, and he dragged one of the others back to town and then came back for my main companion who was comatose but the enemy was nowhere to be seen just blood, so wether the dogs got him or he escaped who knows. 

But thats an example of the "radiant" kind of events that can happen and what makes me give the game a positive review despite its flaws. I would say maybe wait for a sale and maybe be sure you can put the effort in and it will reward you. 

Sorry if this review is a bit long but i had to explain as its not simple.

I really wanted to love Kenshi.

I was drawn in by the sheer ambition on display. Base building meets squad management meets dynamic world state! Non-linear storytelling with no level scaling! These are big, exciting features, and with people comparing it to giants like [i]Runescape[/i] and [i]Dwarf Fortress[/i], my interest was piqued.

The incredibly strong aesthetic helped grab the attention, too. Kenshi presents a wholly original vision, a post-post apocalypse setting chock full of poignant scenery and surprising dangers. The environments and music are simply stunning, and the sheer scope of the setting gives the game an eerie vibe that ratchets up the immersion nicely.

Sadly, being pretty and ambitious isn’t enough.

Though it delivers on many of its promises, Kenshi is held back by a pacing problem. For some, the incredibly slow pace of the game is an attraction. The argument goes that being a hero is more rewarding if you spend lots of time as a zero first. Though I appreciate the logic, getting anywhere and accomplishing anything takes [i]forever[/i], and attempting to speed the process is a great way to get yourself killed and sent back to square one.

This laborious, raise-stats-over-days style of RPG has largely fallen out of vogue, except among people with a huge amount of spare time. They’re just too much effort for most people when there are better returns on their time investment to be found elsewhere. If I want to fantasize about being a post-apocalyptic warlord, there are games that will let me do that without 80+ hours of grind.

Beyond the pacing issue, Kenshi’s systems suffer from a bad case of ‘video game logic’, and are often poorly explained or implemented. For example, base building is a mid-game activity - do it too early, and you’re dead. Trying to run a shop only works under very specific circumstances, and is absolutely not a good way to make money. Despite offering a non-linear, player-directed story, Kenshi has pretty specific expectations of you, and until you learn to write within the lines, it’ll kill you a lot.

Finally - and this is simply a matter of personal taste - the ultraviolence of the setting failed to capture me. Kenshi’s world is a canvas of human misery, hacked off limbs, slavery, and subsistence farming. The chaotic sandbox is designed to encourage and reward a tribalist mentality. Props for setting a vibe, but I found it too unrelentingly grim.

If you’re gaming on limited hardware, have a compatible kind of neurodivergency, and/or have unlimited free time, Kenshi could be the game of your dreams. It’s unique, brave and impressively deep. The sad truth is, despite these qualities, I didn’t enjoy my time with it at all. Not recommended.

Kenshi is an absolute gem of a game that takes the concept of open-world exploration and survival to unparalleled heights. Developed by Lo-Fi Games, this indie masterpiece offers a unique and immersive experience that will keep you hooked for hours on end. From its complex gameplay mechanics to its sprawling post-apocalyptic world, Kenshi stands as a testament to the limitless possibilities of sandbox gaming.

As someone who's put close to 100 hours into this game. Don't play it. The amount of bugs or issues with shoddy programming will have your entire life's work demolished in literal seconds. If you hate yourself and have thousands of hours to dump down the drain by all means but, there is no amount of patience and knowledge that will save you. Unless you feel like exploiting the game, at which point I just feel that kind of defeats the purpose of the hardcore aspect. Will I continue to play? Probably. Should you subject yourself to it? Up to you.
