A zen sandbox of brutality that allows a single player to feel immersed in a world; a folding of multiple genres into a sharpened game.

Kenshi suffers from basic, and often game-breaking, design issues but it was a joy to play. Extremely open ended, almost to a fault, it allows you to write the story from the start. Solo rogue/thief? Mining company? Rampaging bandits? You can do all of those things and more. 

I will say that things started to feel stale towards end game, when the game design requires highly repetitive grinding, especially on the combat side. I'd suggest modding the game from the start, especially some of the QoL and stat building mods that help speed up the mid-game (where you spend loads of time leveling skills). Also, the squad management tools/design is sorely outdated and very buggy - you spend a ton of time fighting the actions of individual minions. 

Anyway, total recommend but your mileage will vary. I'm nearly done for this push at 160 hours, though I could see myself coming back to do a completely different path next time.

Good game, but the building interface wants to make me kill myself.
Examples:
#1: You build two building sites close to each other, [this is natural as one area might have something the other lacks,] The two then join and suddenly you are closer to a town so you can no longer build on one of the sites.
#2: Workers won't use stuff automatically from animal backpacks.
#3: Walls built on hilly terrain often split so you can't walk on them, and you have to spend a literal half hour to hour just making the game work as it should from the get-go fixing the walls. [If you can't walk on walls you can't man crossbows, which are literally the only counter you have against the huge bandit waves that pop up from day 1 and attack your settlement].
#4 Can't build stuff too close to eachother. If you could build ramps more freely it would be fine for the aforementioned as you could just patch up the symptom instead of addressing the problem, but even the tiniest clip will prevent you from placing things.

Don't get me wrong, it's a great game but I will change my review to positive when the game improves the building system so it doesn't literally give me depression. This whole game is about dealing with setbacks and improving on them but I can't  deal with the trash bugs and flaws in the building system on top of that.

Note that you will likely never find an aforementioned site as stated previously that would circumvent some of the pain I feel with this game.

Edit: I got a jester emoji for pointing out the bad building interface? I mean, if you like spending 2 hours trying to fix walls more power to you. Go build a base on hilly terrain and you will see what I mean. Or was it for my window comment? Lol

I've played sandboxes. I've played multi-character RPGs, but I have never played a game which manages to incorporate both together without making serious limits to the characters you can utilize, or the complexity of the map you can travel. I couldn't endorse this game any more for people who enjoy high levels of freedom in their gaming experience. I will say, the pathfinding AI for the characters on the big map could use some work, but that doesn't make me any less excited to find out there will be Kenshi 2

Love this game. It's the only one I have for Steam actually - I've fallen down the MMO hole before and this is a nice RTS inspired RPG sandbox. There are a lot of things I hope they're improving for the sequel. Many of the systems seem well executed but ultimately need fine tuning and further exploration. What I would hope for, but is not coming, is an alteration of the Ogre Engine to update the reliance on a single processor (which I think was what it was doing) to multiple processors so that everything would run like a modern game. The only things to be desired are the before mentioned expansion of features and a graphics upgrade for sure - is that a bandit in the distance? Sure looks like a speck of pixels dancing in the distance... haha. Kenshi is my favorite - actually it's the type of game I've imagined could exist, as far back as my first time playing Starcraft as a kid. I think the way forward is to turn Kenshi's world and game experience into a Elder Scrolls type of game, in the sense of depth, graphics, interaction, lore and freedom - without  losing the RTS controls. I also wish for a Kenshi experience that incorporates online play, but maybe only local online gameplay with friends. I don't think Kenshi should have a heavy RTS competition mode, but it would be an interesting thing to experiment with. RTS was more or less a sport in the past - I think the RPG approach is better - however the things that Kenshi may lack is the feeling of being truly threatened by a thinking, strategizing opponent, whether that be another person or a machine. I could nitpick on all sorts of details of the gameplay/systems/features right now, but the game is amazing for something a single human being has developed on their own from an indie perspective. With mods this game is easily a 10/10.

Kenshi is an odd game. It's not an action packed button masher that so many of us enjoy, it's definitely not an easy game to get into. Kenshi excels, much like Morrowind, Caves of Qud, Rimworld, and other great Role Playing Games; in it's ability to tell stories and create very vivid encounters. 

Allow me to tell you the tale of SD-9 and the Blade Baron Works. 
(Genesis Mod, Myconid Race, Modded)

SD-9 was my first solo skeleton play-through and I immediately decided to make my way up to Worlds End to make a temporary foothold in good territory. I came across a myconid named Paras that could only... well, say Paras. Paras had no ability to trade with store owners, talk to NPC;s, or interact with them in anyway except physical. This made Paras a prime candidate to be my first martial artist. 

Standing at about 1m Paras was quiet, deadly, and would yell "KYAAAAAAH!" whenever he got a good blow in. The little guy was a boxing, break dancing fiend.

But even with him and my massive Skeleton marksman it wasn't enough as Kenshi often proves. I picked up a few skeleton hirelings, got them trained up on a myriad of combat and non-combat abilities, and began heading north. Much of the playthrough consisted of raiding labs, getting clapped, and having to heal my boys between running away. But then I met Rabbit, and my game changed forever.

I had never messed with prosthetics in previous playthroughs, and decided Rabbit, a spindly skeleton with skill in martial arts, was going to be the Logan to my weapon X project. After successfully removing all of Rabbits limbs (making sure to have medici bots on standby with a bed) I attached two masterwork sword legs I had pillaged, and two chainsaw arms. Rabbit became a beyblade dervish of death, and the little bugger saved my salvage crew multiple times including beating the ever loving frack out of a leviathan. 

I had a massive skeleton named Brick that was trained to take no damage single-handedly wipe out two Okranite raiding parties. He still stands guard, occasionally beating the living daylights out of dismembered foes with his trademark spiked bat. 

I made drugs, sold drugs, and built a large facility as an outpost where I intend to make the worlds best weapons and sell them at large across the world. I intend to wipe out all the Okranites and supply the enemy forces with top grade weapons and armor to do so. 

Long live Blade Baron Works. Long live Kenshi.

Kenshi is an exceptional gaming experience that I can't recommend enough. Its open-world sandbox, post-apocalyptic setting is incredibly immersive, and the freedom it offers in character development and gameplay choices is unparalleled. The depth of its world-building, from diverse factions to unique landscapes, is astonishing. Kenshi challenges you to survive, build, and thrive in a harsh, unforgiving world, and the sense of accomplishment when you finally establish your own stronghold or master a new skill is immensely satisfying. The constant updates and dedicated modding community keep the game fresh and exciting. Kenshi truly offers endless possibilities and hours of engaging gameplay. If you're a fan of complex, challenging RPGs with a strong sense of freedom and immersion, Kenshi is a must-play title that will keep you hooked for a long time.

Love the game, it’s probably not for everyone but if it clicks it’s incredible. 

Mount & Blade has a similar place in my heart, it’s a real piece of love you will never find in a regular studios product. Chris Hunt (and everyone at lo-fi studios by extension) deserves their success and Kenshi 2 is one of the only games I’ve been seriously waiting and looking at news for. 

The reviews saying it has all the ingredients for not so great games is true, it’s grindy, slow, punishing in a way that feels not fair sometimes BUT ITS EXCELLENT in spite of and thanks to these elements. You win one fight or make it to the next town and you’re legit happy to make it and explore a new zone or just rest at a bar. Like how Star Wars Battlefront or Kingdom Come Deliverance was fun because you get to be a single lil guy in a larger conflict and can become a force on your own that same feeling exists here but WAY better. If you’re a beast you earned it, if you get fucked you earned it. 

Mod community goes hard, base game is good but the community really elevates the experience for everyone. Idk what else to say the game is fucking cool dude give it a try. 

I may be drunk writing this, but it’s like drunk gushing to your homies abt how much you love and appreciate them. The creator and team deserve a firm handshake and props I already gave em my money I can only try and convince others to do the same. GIVE IT A TRY!

It's hard to get into, but once you do, it fucking sucks you in. The lore is interesting, the adventure is fun, and the problem-solving is really interesting. The game is difficult when you start, but as you recruit and learn more about it, it gets significantly easier. easily top 5 games of all time, I see myself having another 100 hours easily.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing
this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My
son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed
it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the
week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as
it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my
son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching
YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this
game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the
game, made my character and world and started playing but I
was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son
for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was
the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died.
This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again
and now we actually spend time together outside the house
together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be
had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many
happy memories.

Way too many annoying "quirks" and bugs for the game to be worth my time. Sold some slaves to a trader earlier, got paid, and then the trader and his guards just decided to kill me as if I had attacked them, in the middle of a city. Why? Literally no reason. Set up an outpost (don't do this early-game though, my mistake) and was constantly attacked by roving bands of bandits whom I could down, but you can't execute enemies in this game for some fucking reason??? which led to a literal horde of unconscious bandits that piled up quicker than I could remove from my outpost. This led to them constantly waking up and just beating the shit out of my characters over, and over, and over, and we were too hurt to run away fast enough from the first few fights. Then, again, with a completely new save and character I was just chilling in a shop and got murked by the entire town guard for NO REASON. 

Me being murdered in those two situations was obviously a bug and completely unintended, but I was just using the game's systems (selling slaves and items) and got punished for it. I also find it completely ridiculous that a game renowned for being brutal does not allow you to execute downed enemies, yet my characters are constantly left bleeding out for 20 minutes of REAL TIME at max game speed after every fight. This game is essentially grinding for the reward of having your balls crushed in a vice and I would really rather play a much better sandbox game like Rimworld.

Some things are missing, the npcs routines within town are weird, but hey... it's an early access, it's the "test" version, so i guess it's supposed to be this way. At least the game is playable enought for me to change my rocomendation... Enjoy the rest of the review (... or not... it's boring! :P)

This is actually a very unique game, with some features that make it (or could make) an addictive game. So, why did it got my negative review? Well... Let me start by decribid the good about this game (in my opinion).
So this is a 50-50 mix or classic RTS with RPG, you play and control everything from an aerial perspective. It takes place in a desert world filled with other NPS, and factions, and cities, beasties, robbers, cannibals. All have their own individual agendas. You can start with a single charcacter or with a small group (the game gives you hints about the "game style": more RTS or more RPG...), and once in the game you can do everything that comes to your mind or become almost anything. The rule is, if you see it hapening, you can do it too (wich is nice!).

At first you can make money by trading (there is a very dynamic and responsive economy) or you can scavage the land, steal, kill some baddies and take their stuff. Later you can have a hole bunch of people at your service (you recruit over time), build a citie or your own, found a faction, develop relations with others, extract materials from the land, transform them into valuable items.
Combat is very simple (just pause click click unpause wait) but very tactic. You can win or lose based on you strategy.
Each member of your group takes a specific role and you can train them to become more efective, give them "jobs", equip them (very oldscholl RPG, also nice!). After some time you have pretty complex production lines and organized tasks within your citie(s) to get everything working like a clock (very RTS).
If you are more of a warmonguer yourself you can orient all you production to get weapons a armor and train a hole bunch of "soldiers". Attack other faction (u crazy?!?), get rid of some cannibals, hunt some laaarge beast...
Every task you set to do gets an epic proportion because the game lets you "micromanage" almost everything. And because the world is so dynamic you always have to expect the unplanned. That makes everything so much interesting!

Example: u assemble a team of 6 proud warriors, well trained and better equipped, and set out to the nest of some very big, ugly and smelly beast to steal their valuable eggs and precious leather. U get to the nest, and after and epic fight you manage to kill the beast and take your prize. You barely escaped with you lives but your pockets are full you feel like the kings of the universe! You bandage and head back home. On your way back, you are ambushed by a fairly weak group of bandits, wounded and weak you fall to their blades and they take your hard earned beast-prize... After a while you group awakes, one brave champion had not resisted the injuries and would not wake again, you mourn the loss and..... REVENGEE!!!!! heheh
Get the point? The game doesnt have a main story and doesnt particulary gives you any objective at all, and yet it manages to give you a a proper scenario for all this little tales to take place and after a while you have a story of your own.
The world doesnt depend on your actions to progress, it has its own dynamic and its own agenda, you and your faction are just another element of it.

"THEN WHY ARE YOU GIVING A NEGATIVE REVIEW?" you ask...
Simple, i love all of what i just described and the game would be perfect if I could play it for MORE THAN 3 MINUTES WITHOUT A CRASH, a misscalculated stat, a forgotten status, a corrupt savegame, a reset of squad status, a reset of the economy...................
It just makes it impossible to not want to break the PC into thousands of pieces and then burn the pieces and bury them.
I love my PC so i'll just stop playing this. I've waited 1 year, and the bugs just kept increasing. Let's just say, i lost my faith in this project.

NOTE TO THE DEVELOPER: please just focus on stability, then focus on game data loss (like character status, and character stats loss, or even training benefits loss or reset...) I have waited more than 1 year since i bought the game to try it and be fair with it in my review. In that year you brought some fairly interesting improvements to game features (i admit that, yes) but also a gargantuan number of annoying bugs that made it simply unplayable.
I promise to check the game again in 2 months, and i'll gladly change this review.

Do you want an open world game with absolutely NO missions, quests, or point whatsoever?  Here you go!  Definition of sandbox done HORRIBLY wrong.  

Would you like to set up a base? Go * Yourself.  You will be raided non-stop until you go download 19 mods to make the game playable since the SLIDERS IN THE OPTIONS TO SELECT NEVER DOES NOT WORK!  No matter how you set the raid and attack options, it makes no difference whatsoever.

Would you like to wander the wastes after super power leveling the crap out of your character to all 90+ stats? Go for it!  We'll just have you miss 19 dodges in a row and be "rarely" decapitated by a STARVING WEAKLING with a strength of 4, a death that was decided BEFORE the starving waste of life was even spawned in! (Tested, had a save before anyone was spawned in, around the corner was one single starving bandit that was already injured, killed me every time I loaded no matter what I did, gameplay tested!)

Would you like to clean up your base?  Haha, go choke on someone else's cares, you dumb *.  Because another group of Dust Bandits are spawning just outside your vision and are going to attack while you are still trying to remove the corpses from the last attack.  We dont even give a * that you killed our King and claimed the bounty and now the Demands cannot happen, these are WANDERING spawns, so we get to cheat because our single person dev doesn't give a crap about you.

Would you like to properly defend your base with common sense things like patrol routes or guard positions, the way the AI already does it anyway so why would it be a big deal?  Why are you still trying to have fun?  No Sir, you need to download 3 MORE mods to add this functionality because the dev is too lazy to do it.

Not to worry, though!  The dev did build in one super handy tool that they "claim" fixes everything!  Just Import your save.  What does it do? Deletes all your stuff on the ground!  Tired of all those messy materials or backpacks you dropped or those weapons you removed from the 300 dead bodies piling up ready to crash your game?  Just Import your save!  It's so easy, all you have to do it exit the freaking game completely and re-launch it because the option to import is on the main menu and we hate you so we did not allow you to get there from inside a game, neat huh?  Careful not to hit the Continue button by accident, because then you have to re-launch it again, you stupid * piece of....

So that's it.  If you are into ridiculous levels of modding in order to make a game even marginally playable, Kenshi is your game!  Otherwise, go * yourself.

TLDR: Terrible planning, execution, support, development, and coding.  Only play if you are very proficient at modding.  Unplayable without severe overhaul.

In a realm where demanding players seek games that can truly surprise and captivate, Kenshi stands out as an exceptional gem. Within just a brief hour of gameplay, this game effortlessly shattered my expectations and swiftly claimed the throne as a temporary favorite. It is an absolute masterpiece, albeit not without a few inherent drawbacks that can easily be rectified by mods.

I wholeheartedly endorse Kenshi as a game that deserves recognition from everyone. However, I advise players to equip themselves with mods before embarking on their journey. These modifications effectively address and resolve most, if not all, of the game's limitations, propelling the experience to unprecedented heights. Kenshi serves as a beacon, an exemplar of what open-world games should aspire to be, catering to a diverse and enthusiastic audience.

The game resonated with me on such a profound level that I am compelled to bestow upon it a rating of 9 out of 10. This stands as a testament to the developers' unwavering dedication and boundless creativity. I eagerly await their future endeavors, eager to see what they have in store for us next. Kenshi is a remarkable triumph that should not be missed.😇

Kenshi...more like Ken-should-I-even-try-this-game. As someone who thought they were a seasoned gamer, let me tell you, Kenshi humbled me. From getting my butt kicked by a gang of bandits, to being chased by creatures that looked like they escaped from Avatar, Kenshi kept me on my toes - well, until those toes eventually got hacked off by a sword or something. But that's not the worst part. The real challenge was trying to micromanage a group of characters with the attention span of a goldfish. I lost count of how many times I had to run back and save my characters from certain doom after they decided to go on a walkabout by themselves. Long story short, Kenshi is not for the faint of heart or for anyone who values their sanity. If you're up for the challenge, though, be prepared for an adventure like no other. Just don't say I didn't warn you when you're crying in a corner after your squad gets wiped out by a pack of cute but deadly goats.

Kenshi is tough to learn, but once you get it figured out, it's incredibly rewarding. It doesn't hold your hand, you're not special and you'll probably lose a few characters before you get yourself into the groove. 
If you like a challenge, this game is worth checking out. It is a grind, that is certain, but as someone who doesn't generally like grindy games, this one actually struck home for me, for some reason. It feels rewarding, watching a character's stat increase by even a single point, especially with how easily that character could be maimed, slaughtered, cannibalized or forcefully amputated. By the time I had my first proper base established, I was feeling pretty high up, my squad even defended their home from one of the big factions that we upset, with aid from the allies we'd made. 
Yet, Kenshi didn't let me ride the high for very long, and soon it humbled me by cutting off my main man's left arm, to remind me of my place in the natural order. BUT, now he sports a mechanical prosthetic in its place, and it's made him even more dangerous than before, despite being one of the lower end arms. 
Make the best out of a bad situation, failure is only failure if you crumble to it. 
Highly recommend to anyone who enjoys games like Darkest Dungeon or Dark Souls (no, I am not calling this a "Souls-Like") who take joy in overcoming difficult odds.

Game feels like it's set in post apocalyptic desert environment like mad max but with Japanese feel and stile.
You fight with hand weapons only (maces, cantatas, swords, bows, shields ...)  and your actions improve your skill that you are using, there is no levelling.

You can lose your limbs and get robotic new ones. You can be enslaved or have bounty on your head, you can also play it as a strategy building game and control your new built settlement. 
Also I love the fact that game was made by one person over period of 6 years :-O\

If you like management type games and RPGs, this is the perfect mix. It's just enough management to allow you to thrive with mostly strategy without feeling bogged down, and just enough RPG elements to get you invested in not just your squad, but each individual character in it. 

Here's a tale from my experience with the game;

This is the kind of game to change your entire perspective on life itself. Failure is not the end, nor the beginning, but a constant in this world that you can either let destroy you or make you stronger. Allow me to tell you a story. The story of New Battlehill. 
Near the Shek city of Squin, not far east, was a small town. It went through many names. The first that stuck was Firstyeet, totally not a placeholder. It wasn't an notable settlement, merely consisting of a shack, an iron processor, and some walls to mildly inconvenience the roving gangs of Dust Bandits that liked to bully the residents. After being evicted from their own city once again, the residents, Denver, Soto, Ruka, and Meow, vowed to take back their home. After training and buying the best weapons and armor they could, they made their way back to Firstyeet. To their surprise, however, they would not have to fight. One of the bandits had picked a fight with a herd of goats. The bandits' defense failed against the caprine assault. From this, the town would get its second name - Densorumego. Den for Denver. So for Soto. Ru for Ruka. Me for Meow. And Go for the true heroes, the goats.
Peace would not last long but soon the residents of Densorumego would become strengthened by their constant fighting. On the elevated, somewhat round land on which Densorumego sat, there were many large fights involving a lot of people. If only there was some sort of name to reflect this... 
And from that, the town was renamed for the last time, to Battlehill.
Things were looking up. The town built its first farms and expanded to be almost four times its original size. But this peace would not last. Battlehill's new ambitions of self sufficiency would attract the attention of a new foe - The Shek Kingdom.
The Shek claimed ownership of the land Battlehill was on, and as such, demanded all food grown there be given to them. Confident from their many victories against the Dust Bandits, the Battlehillites refused the Shek demands. Their risk was calculated... but man were they bad at math.
All but one were nearly killed in the ensuing battle, and the one person that wasn't knocked into a coma was stuck on the wall because part of the wall was destroyed and he could no longer reach the stairs because of that. The people knew they couldn't fight the Shek, but they would not allow themselves to be subservient either. And so began their malicious compliance. The Shek would get all the food in Battlehill, as it would be none - The Battlehillites were moving.
I could write entire books about their journey around the west. The Fogmen, the ruins, the Screeching Bandits, there's many a tale. But, eventually, the people would find a new home. In the harsh and Beak Thing infested land of Vain, homeland of the Western Hive, they would found their new home - New Battlehill.
Jump to now, the city is thriving, they have more bread than they know what to do with, they've grown strong from defending their home from the Beak Things, and their population has grown. They are currently planning a reconquest of Battlehill, which was occupied by Dust Bandits shortly after they left.

There is a part I left out, between Firstyeet and Densorumego - I had repeatedly failed to retake Firstyeet, and I was about to quit the game. I was frustrated that I'd gone and bought the best arms and armor and still failed. And when I tried to set up a training ground on a mountain near Squin, bandits again came and defeated me. I went as far as to try and get a refund, which was denied. That refund being denied was the best thing that could've happened. I decided to give the game another try, and to try accepting my failures and growing from them. And if I hadn't done that, I would never have founded New Battlehill. None of the legend worthy tales my squad has been through would have happened. And I'd never have had the fun of going through all of them.

In short, get this game. It is just great.

I don't really make reviews very often. But, I have played this over the years and I always come back to it. While there isn't much direct story, and mostly in the background for the setting, learning as you go. The game may have a high learning curve, with a somewhat janky UI and learning can be a brutal process, potentially frustrating if you are not invested enough to put the effort in. I do recommend any new player put themselves in the proper mindset to push through that part.

However, throughout that process, I discovered one of my favorite games of all time. Kenshi is a game that can be enjoyed in elaborately different ways.

-Do you want to play a single-character focused RPG? 
-Do you want to play a settlement simulator similar to Rimworld? 
-Do you want to play a real-time CRPG focusing on a single party/squad?
-Do you want to play a squad management focused game, managing resources and different objectives you create for yourself?

All of these things in this glorious sandbox, are various ways you can enjoy and play the game. To make the story yourself and play it in anyway you want. Not to mention, the elaborate Mod Community. A personal favorite of mine is the Star Wars conversion mod. 

Please give this game a chance, and you'll enjoy an incredible experience unique to this game.

Have you ever wondered what the inside of a rusty cage was like? How about dragging your torso through the desert, as wild dogs feast on your severed legs? Ever wonder how fast you might run, if you managed to get cybernetic replacements for said legs?
Well, my friend, this sandbox offers all that, and more!
Look for treasure in sunken ruins! Begin to starve to death! Steal food from a nearby town! Get caught, and go to jail! Attempt to escape jail! Get mauled, and level up as a result! Break out, and lure the guards into a monster's nest! Wait for them to kill each other, and loot their bodies! Find a survivor, and imprison them! Offer them food, in exchange for a life under your rule!
Kenshi has a little something for everyone in the family! Why, granddad will just love running a cotton plantation! Buy today!

Kenshi is one of my all-time favorite games and is one that I find myself returning to somewhat regularly. I think the reason for its success is captured in it's mission statement: player agency and decisions. While there are a couple of optimal ways to play, there are many viable ways, especially when you consider that there are no predefined win conditions. There are quite a few categories of stats that can be worked on, some of which work well together, while others need to be focused on separately (you're not going to level weapon smithing while being a ninja). You can run a solo character in a game that feels like a more traditional RPG (which is still put together very well, even by itself) or play with many characters within a faction in a playthrough that feels almost like an RTS (not quite as fun as a dedicated RTS imo, but adds greatly to the rest of your options and can support your other goals). Mix, match, and enjoy! When you need to freshen up your experience, head over to the workshop, where there are many great mods that add to or overhaul the Kenshi experience, giving you more things to do, people to meet, items to collect, and enemies to face.

This may all make Kenshi sound like an easy game. It isn't, but that's part of the fun, since you know that if you meet a threat stronger than you (which is most of them at first), there is a very good chance you'll have the living daylight beaten out of you and you'll end up bleeding out, wanted by the law/serving a prison sentence, eaten, or enslaved. However, as any Kenshi player knows: anything that doesn't kill you gives you XP. In this way, the game is brutal and forgiving at the same time, which greatly adds to the enjoyment. Keep trying, and you'll make it, and you'll get a real rush when you finally solo a group of enemies that used to destroy you one-on-one.

I only have a couple of minor criticisms, which don't bother me too much, but I thought I ought to bring them up:

1) The game is kinda grindy. The only way you'll get stronger is through practice, and this goes for every skill. Also, your character(s) are garbage at doing things at first, so you'll lose most of the time early on. On the other hand, basically anything you do other than sitting around will get you XP in some category.

2) While Kenshi is open-world, it's not entirely seamless. Moving between different segments of the map entails some loading. This is not on a separate loading screen, mind you, but it is kind of annoying sometimes. This is mitigated by better processing power, but if you have a low-end computer, you may want to keep this in mind. Performance is generally pretty good in my experience, and most loading occurs when travelling quickly and when looking back and forth between your different groups in various parts of the map (your adventurers and town-dwellers for example).

The only game I've ever found where you truly aren't special, nothing makes you the hero, everything will be a challenge, some things are even truly impossible. Before finding this game way back in the day, I was an avid souls games player, but in those games you are the inevitability, the unstopping tide. This game is different, you put together your own stories, sometimes your story will be that the hero dies in the desert to unimpressive enemies and no one continues his dreams. That's just the way the story unfolds. The first time I played this game was years ago, my first playthrough was when the map had maybe... 1/16th of the map open at the time, if even that. I started as a guy with a dog, walked out of the small waystation it spawned you in, got my ass beat my bandits, they butchered my unconscious dog for food, and left me unconscious in the desert until I died from blood loss three days later. An intense first impression that made me fall in love with this game, it's not perfect and sometimes mods can be used to increase the fun, but I will continue to be an avid player of this game, because sometimes stories with no romantic or amazing ending is a good story.

A grain of salt is likely in order; this review reflects the admittedly poorly informed perspective of one still very new to the whole 'experience a documentary in video game format'. A bittersweet, yet painstakingly accurate depiction of one of humanity's less well known eras. Dev effortlessly ([i] and perhaps unintentionally [/i]) captures a plethora of parallels on the injustice and suffering that has been known to occasion our current era of magnificent developments, and age old conflicts.  

Play the game and you will be the recipient of a rare and valuable education. Be kind to yourself in the process.

Kenshi is an incredible storytelling game with a lot of depth. This is an unforgiving world, where you can just as easily lose fights as win them and end up with limbs chopped off or being eaten alive. The graphics aren't great, controls take a little getting used to, and there is a bit of a grind, but despite those drawbacks the game is still incredibly fun. With an incredible amount of lore and a variety of play styles (you can build a base and sell drugs, or adventure and sell slaves, or raise an army and attack entire kingdoms), Kenshi is definitely worth the price.

Overall this is a great game. The sandbox style allows you to do anything, or attempt anything at least with death being the most likely result. At first this game had me feeling very lost and confused, but as I experimented in the world I find out how everything works and it all become easy. 

Pros:
-The AI felt so realistic with how they interact with you when first encountered, their prompts are hilarious to see. I still like them a lot. 
-Lore and how it fits into the gameplay is nice.
-Skeletons

Cons:
-Loading world chunks is frequent and annoying, thankfully the loading is not slow.
-Graphics/graphical glitches, this stuff could be better but obviously it is an old game. With that being said you will run into areas where the camera isn't working properly and you need to constantly maneuver it to see what is going on.

This game just grows on you. One minute you’re wandering the land, hours later you’ve got your own custom-built base, a small number of crew/gang/etc., you’re constantly fending off starving people, trying to establish your trade routes (as in just walking the path yourself; there’s no “checkbox” for this one) without dying, and you end up playing until 5:30am when you’ve gotta get up early and you haven’t done that in 20+ years.

A wildly punishing strategy RPG with a unique worldspace, a great set of features and a respectable amount of jank. What Kenshi lacks in conventional beauty and polish, it makes up for in depth and intriguing world design.

It's hard to "recommend" Kenshi to anyone - I encourage you to watch gameplay and try to decide if this is the right game for you, because it's not really like anything else.

Because this game was built by one man (or visionary IMO) over 10 years in a custom-built engine called Ogre, it does have some issues with loading times between zones. But it's one of the coolest, most original universes and concepts to come out for a while. I guess it's a grim-dark Western with a lot of culture imported from feudal Japan. There's crossbows and katanas; you can earn your money as a trader, a bounty hunter, or maybe stick to mining, farming and retail of the weapons you smiths have crafted. It is fair to say that you should def subscribe to a couple of quality-of-life mods available in the workshop but there's dozens you'll want to play with after learning that the vanilla experience kinda demands every good fighter to have been pummelled into the dust, on the verge of death, dozens of times. Strong modding community, and kenshi 2 is officially in the works  - I specifically bought a PC in anticipation of it!

An awesome game, will keep you grinding and learning about the world for a long time as you slowly get stronger and stronger, becoming more confident leaving home, venturing further and further until you finally meet your end. Has a lot of freedom to play, no missions, no invincible characters, no one telling you what to do, unless you want them to that is. Be everything to the owner of a town or a slave too weak to escape it's captors. 

Mods truly make this game shine, giving it so much more life and content, and I think the mods heavily influenced my enjoyment of the game. Also, not hard to mod yourself if you want specific starts or to make special characters or even take exiting ones in the game and edit them, even making them recruitable. 

All in all a great game if you are willing to learn it and take the time to sink into the world, and start your own story.

Surprisingly well balanced between RPG, RTS and survival gameplay, and it's the only RTS-like game that I know of that has a seamless openworld.

There's no overarching storyline (least not that I've discovered yet), however the game has highly enticing mysteries to unravel and unique characters and factions to mess around with. You can do whatever you wish as its RPG mechanics are not railroaded at all and actually support causing chaos in several different varieties.

The game is somewhat difficult, which is expected given it is both survival and RTS-based. You might suck at first, but once you come to terms with combat training and effective income sources, you will shortly get on your feet pretty well. The game also features helpful and concise tutorial messages which appear as you are exposed to new situations and features, which is handy because the game can be quite complex at times.

Definitely recommend, the devs have updated the game a lot post-release and it functions pretty solidly now. They are also working on a sequel in unreal engine, which I personally can't wait to find more out about.

Don't get the hype behind this game. Tried to force myself to like it, can't break into it. 

- I was expecting a thrilling experience judging from the reviews and what do I get? Whacked around wherever I go.
Just a lazy way of telling you "the game is hardcore"

- The lore in the game? Yeah, it's not as interesting as people portray it to be ... I can tolerate mundane lore but kenshi in my eyes seems to lack any depth to it. Once again, don't get the hype.

- User interface/Controls or Learning the game? I swear I had an easier time learning Everquest project 1999 as a newbie.

- The world environment? Vast emptiness that's got nothing interesting to offer other than a load of mobs/factions trying to maul you. (Except the swamps, the swamps were cool to discover so thumbs up to that)

- Quests? Pffft yeah, virtually none existent in my short time of playing this game.

- Combat is trash. Simply put trash. I understand the aspect of trying to portray your character as being worth nothing and be an absolute good for nothing nobody but at least give me a fair chance of deciding my own worth in combat for god's sake. (Out come the fan boys telling me that if I micro manage my positioning and my block/attack ratio about 1000 times per each combat session + grind my combat/toughness skill I'll be able to take on an entire squad of 16 people or some sh*t)

- The grind. I've played enough RPGs/MMOs/Survival games, can we please stop normalizing grinding in games? This is yet another piss poor excuse of prolonging 'gameplay'. There is nothing fun/engaging about it and usually the satisfaction time you get out of it is minimal at best.

- Graphics? I personally do like them, just a shame that there is very little sight seeing in game to enjoy them. (Unless as previously mentioned, you're in the swamps)

I get it. It's a sandbox game. There is not meant to be any goal within the game other than to 'survive' really but at least make the game SOMEWHAT interesting other than throwing in cannibals and skin stealers to entertain the empty void that this game provides. (HURR DURR DURR MODS)

TLDR; Severely disappointed, would not recommend to anyone unless they're big into games like HOI IV or CK III/Europa Universalis and that's a big stretch in itself I believe. Tried to force myself to play it and it ain't clicking chief.

Kenshi has held me captive for nearly 70 hours with its enthralling open-world escapade. The post-apocalyptic setting demands careful survival strategy in a beautifully crafted universe. Just like DiGiorno's irresistibly delicious pizza with its signature cheesy crust, Kenshi offers an abundance of choices: from forging your individual destiny to skillfully navigating complex faction dynamics. Just as DiGiorno's delivers an incredibly satisfying taste, Kenshi's rewarding progression through realism and visually immersive landscapes create an indelible and utterly captivating gaming experience. Both are an unbeatable combination that keeps me endlessly enthralled, just like a freezer full of DiGiorno's ready to enjoy.

This game hates you and it's beautiful.  Not graphically, no, but in its desire to make you suffer.  And suffer you will for the first 10+  hrs, too broke to get ahead; starting over and over again because you lost an arm or a leg or something to the first dog you attacked outside of the town you spawn in and bled out dragging yourself on bloody leg stumps somewhere in the desert.  Perhaps finally 3-4 hrs in you almost have a base built but get beaten unconcious by a group of starving, rag-wearing hobos because you are weak af and can't fight for shit because of your missing arm from the dog earlier.  You think "I Almost had enough for that cybernetic arm too" as a slaver comes along and grabs you up to sell into bondage which ironically would heal you and feed you,  but you bleed out and die on the way to their hideout anyways.  Add the clunky game mechanics and its incredibly frustrating at first.  But, then the mods come, and that takes this game to a whole new level of customization and enjoyment.  Lightsabers or marvel characters, mods that could make you into a 500 stat 'roided out toon so muscular and huge how could it possibly even wipe, much less swing a sword and run 26 mph?  Super fun game to play, if the frustration doesn't make you rage quit first, you will probably drop 200+ hrs in it easily.   Easily.  Look at workshop mod collections first before downloading random ones here and there and getting a bunch of conflicts.  A few needed are only on nexus or the like.

Start with RE_Kinshi as its kinda the base mod the others may need.

Crab Raiders

10/10

> Begin my adventure as a lone flatskin wanderer, nothing but a steel club in hand and a cloth around my waist.
> I scavenge around the town for things to sell. Find nothing but a few worthless jugs which fetch me a few monies.
> Venturing outside, I find a few copper deposits. I decide to mine and sell as much as I can so I can afford food.
> Manage to make enough money to buy a good load of food rations. I  go to the tavern outside of town to trade the fruits of my labour when it is suddenly ransacked by a group of bandits. They mercilessly slaughter the shopkeep and his guards. I managed to make it out in time but they gash up my leg. It's a good thing I bought a first-aid kit.
> Continue to mine every day to earn as much money as I can. After I've bought up a good portion of food, I set out for Squin, a Shek settlement a few miles away. As I approach the gate, I come across the rotting corpse of a starved bandit, his hand reaching towards the gate in desparation. Poor devil. Feeling a bit guilty, but in need of good clothes to protect me from the elements, I take his shirt and pants. He won't be needing them anyway.
> On my way towards Squin, I am harrassed by more bandits who knick me in the head with a bolt, but I manage to outrun them and make it into town. The guards slaughter the bastards. I patch up my head and make my way to a nearby Inn to rest up.
> I proceed to live the life of a simple 49'er, mining copper deposits and selling the ores to merchants. On my first excursion, I got so caught up in my work that a gang of bandits jumped me and took all of my rations. I manage to bandage myself up but all the food I worked so hard to buy was now gone. I've been far more cautious since then.
> I eventually make the acquaintance of a young Shek named Ruka at the local pub. She was once a proud warrior, but her horns were cut off as punishment for faultering in battle. She was now nothing more than a servant. We quickly became friends and she agreed to stick by my side.
> After a little more copper mining, I'm able to save up enough money to buy me some new clothes, a sturdy pair of boots, and a decent sword.  I also hire another Shek companion, a female by the name of Meow. As part of her induction, I clip her horns and name our squad "The Short Horn Hoodlums".
> I decide to take a break from mining and explore the surrounding areas with my posse. After some travelling, we come across the reeking Swamps south of Squin. We venture into the swamps to see if there is anything of value.
> During our expedition, we are ambushed by a gang of swamp bandits. My companions and I are ill-equipped to fend them off and are gravely injured. We are left in the moor to bleed to death.
> My corpse is later devoured by the local wildlife. The remains of my two companions quickly decompose, claimed by the treacherous swamp.

Kenshi is a true gem in the world of gaming. With its vast open world, intricate mechanics, and endless possibilities, it's a title that deserves every bit of its 5-star rating.

From the moment I stepped foot into the harsh landscapes of Kenshi, I was utterly captivated. The depth of the world-building is simply astounding. Whether you're a lone wanderer or a leader of a thriving faction, the immersive storytelling keeps you engaged at every turn.

One of the most remarkable aspects is the freedom of choice. You're not tied to a linear narrative; instead, you forge your own path. Want to be a wandering trader? Or perhaps a fearsome warrior? The game accommodates every playstyle seamlessly. The intricacies of the economy, survival mechanics, and base building offer a level of depth that's both rewarding and challenging.

The characters you encounter are richly detailed, each with their own motivations and stories. Whether it's forming alliances, recruiting companions, or facing off against foes, every interaction feels authentic and meaningful.

Graphically, Kenshi's distinct art style paints a post-apocalyptic world that's both bleak and beautiful. The attention to detail in every nook and cranny speaks volumes about the dedication of the developers.

While Kenshi's learning curve can be steep, the journey is undeniably worth it. The sense of accomplishment as you overcome hurdles and grow stronger is unmatched.

In conclusion, Kenshi is a masterpiece that offers an unparalleled sandbox experience. It's a world where you're not just playing a game, but creating your own saga. If you're seeking a truly immersive, challenging, and endlessly enjoyable adventure, Kenshi is the game you've been waiting for.

Kenshi is a game that I originally thought "I would not like this game. I am not really a fan of RTS games.". However, after talking about the game for so long with a close friend of mine, I decided "Heck it, I'll give it a try.". Little did I know how quickly this game will challenge me. Being dropped into the middle of nowhere. Choosing what is considered the worst race to start with (Not knowing that at the time). Feeling completely helpless and lost in the already intimidating and desolate landscape right smack dab in the middle between the United Cities and Holy Nation warring area. Needless to say, yikes!

In my honest opinion, it took me quite a bit of time to get adjusted to how this game played. It is unforgiving, relentless and punishing for anyone new to the game. Having to be very careful with your fragile character(s). Stealthing around, gauging your attacks and knowing when to flee (or play dead, if unfortunate to run away and you miraculously survive). This game single-handedly gave me an amazing experience that I am pleasantly surprised to have. It has a lot of depth, working mechanical parts. Everything feels like it has meaning. The landscape, the combat, the interactions — pretty much *everything*. This game has a lot of downtime and you will park your rear just healing a lot of time until you become more familiar with the land, more geared up, more experienced and tougher. Oddly enough, it's not discouraging. If anything, it encouraged me more to press forward in this "survival of the fittest" landscape that also has some of the most dangerous endemic life or even simply the people who run any town(s). 

I really can not express the level of detail this game has. It has really become one of my favorite games. It is very odd considering it is an RTS but hey, when a game is good, a game is good. I really hope when Kenshi 2 comes out, it is just as engaging and enjoyable as this is and I look forward to what Lo-Fi Games comes up with.

A game with complete freedom of action. In it, you can engage in slave trading, city building, establish a sect or join an existing sect like a skin bandit or a holy nation. You can also be a lone warrior or create a squad to explore the ancient ruins, in which you can find grains of the game's lore and rare treasures, for which, of course, you will have to fight to the death with a variety of enemies, and these treasures, in turn, can come in handy to research ancient technologies. This game is difficult at the very beginning, but if you are not playing for the first time and already have experience, then there is an opportunity to install mods that really affect the game world very much and make a lot of changes and improvements. For example, you can improve the attack animation or increase the maximum number of recruits. You can add a huge number of different things and it will look like a completely different game. Of course, the game has flaws, bugs and so on, but it was created by a single person and this game is already about 10 years old, so it has something to forgive. I also heard about the development of the second part - Kenshi 2, I will definitely buy it as soon as the opportunity presents itself. I strongly recommend this game to buy, it is worth the money.

So after 19 hours in I can safely say, this game is absolutely amazing! 

NOW ALL NEW PLAYERS, 
I want you to know that at 19 hours played i'm still new, to explain further. 

At 19 hours I just:
1. Expanded my crew to 7, it was at 5 and it was kinda rough some days cus food was hard to come by. Making it to a city and then earning cash to make food was sometimes a chore; its like real work, but its so rewarding.
2. Finally found a secure way to make a good source of money, all I'll say is that it revolves around mining and an efficient way to do it. I don't want to spoil it to much cus honestly it was the most rewarding feeling ever to fiqure that out.
3. Started winning fights vs the bottom of the barrel gangs, aka the hungry bandits. I will say, the learning curve is massive, i'm still learning and I feel so achieved just where i'm at now figuring out a strategy to handle big fights with my 7 guys. Skill is everything, numbers isn't. THOUGH that doesn't mean go fight some massive gang cus sometimes them numbers get real lucky, but you want less people at first so they can actually level up.(and you can afford to feed them)

That's all ill say for now, but the game is definitely worth it at full price; this is the most fun i've had with a single player game in a long time if i'm quite honest!

This game is very unique and must be played to truly understand its concept and gameplay. There is enough story in the world to keep you engaged whilst the mechanics allow you to create your own adventure with your own cast of characters and goals. 
The map is expansive and contains many unique biomes which often have their own unique factions and NPCs as well as different landscapes, weather conditions and hazards.
Squad combat and the struggle to survive are the most standout features to me and are executed perfectly. 
If you want an adventure of your own, filled with slavery, cannibals, robot ninjas and holy wars, then this is an experience you will want to enjoy.

Addictive and rewarding sandbox rpg experience.  Starts pretty difficult, there is no hand holding in this game, but before long your challenges will be found in deciding between the many choices you have unlocked before you.  Do you become a Bounty Hunter looking to defeat the infamous badasses of Kenshi?  Do you make a fortune as a trader and live the high life while caravans trade goods between each of the warring factions?  Or maybe you set your sites on becoming a conqueror and building an army to take command of the world of Kenshi, pitting yourself against one or all of the corrupt nations?  Anything can be done in Kenshi, and its not really much of an exaggeration when I say ANYTHING.

A pure sandbox through and through, can you do absolutely anything you can imagine like in Minecraft? No. But can you become a drug mule and smuggle kilos worth of hash across international borders to make your fortune in Minecraft? Checkmate atheists. In all seriousness its a fantastically complex and yet very simple game, very high barrier of entry but once you get through that and start really learning the combat and character skill system you will have no shortage of fun. Diverse(ish) factions to interact with, limited races but enough to keep things interested and enough mods to fix any small or big gripe you will come across. Plenty more to talk about but get the game and experience it for yourself.

Kenshi has undoubtedly secured its place as one of the most exceptional open-world games to grace the gaming realm. With its sprawling landscapes, deep gameplay mechanics, and unparalleled freedom, it's a must-play for anyone even remotely intrigued by the sandbox genre.

From the very first moment, Kenshi draws you into its enigmatic world, where you're left to forge your destiny amidst a vast and unforgiving landscape. The beauty lies in its versatility – whether you aspire to be a nomadic trader, a formidable warrior, or a resourceful survivor, Kenshi grants you the canvas to paint your own story.

Embracing a harsh realism, Kenshi offers a survival experience that's both demanding and gratifying. Your choices have consequences that extend far beyond the surface, shaping not only your journey but also the very fabric of the world around you. With every challenge overcome and every milestone reached, you'll find yourself more engrossed in the intricate tapestry of this captivating realm.

The game's dynamic world is a marvel in itself. Factions vie for power, towns rise and fall, and opportunities materialize in unexpected places. The level of detail woven into this ever-evolving universe is astonishing, creating an immersive environment that invites you to explore every nook and cranny. Each encounter with diverse NPCs and hidden wonders adds to the sense of wonderment that Kenshi effortlessly delivers.

While not aiming for cutting-edge graphical prowess, Kenshi's distinctive art style is a testament to its unique charm. The audio design complements the atmosphere seamlessly, further enhancing your connection with the game's world.

Kenshi's learning curve may prove steep, but the satisfaction derived from mastering its intricacies is beyond compare. The game's vibrant modding community infuses it with endless possibilities, extending its longevity and ensuring that each playthrough offers a new adventure.

In summation, Kenshi stands tall as a remarkable achievement in the open-world genre, inviting players to lose themselves in a realm of boundless opportunities. With its expansive landscapes, immersive gameplay, and addictive mechanics, it's a game that deserves a spot in every adventurous gamer's library. Embark on your journey through Kenshi and unveil the myriad tales that await – it's an odyssey you won't want to miss!

Kenshi is a game that has bugs, but the community refers to them as features. The features that Kenshi has are insubstantial compared to how great the game is, however, they can be annoying from time to time. Thankfully the game has a great community with a ton of great information.

If you're going to start you're first play-through get these essential mods
- 256 recruitment limit
- Dark UI
- Compressed textures project (reduces loading times)
- Slopeless
- Race blood
- Reduced weather effects (Trust me, otherwise you'll barely be able to see you're squad through the rain)
- Nice Map [Zones + Zone names + Roads]
- Less buggy bughouse

This game is some kind of bizarre mad max flavored crack. That's the only explanation I have for it. 

There's a lot working against this game. I bought it well over a decade ago, wrote it off, only to find out the madman making it had worked on it for the entire time it took me to graduate college, work in my industry, realize I hate it, and go back to school, and finally they released it in 2018. It's full of jank, built on ancient technology and after all that development time pieces still feel like they are obviously missing. It refuses to explain itself beyond the bare essentials and does not respect your time. It's incredibly easy to make a decision that will take you hours to implement and then hours more to realize has doomed you. It's simultaneously punishingly difficult and incredibly exploitable if you are so disposed. It's unapologetically dark and full of cannibals, slavery, drugs, and murder. It's a workshop heavy game, with all the stress that comes with that. It is NOT for everyone. 

But dagnabbit if you are the type of person to persist past all of that does this game suck you in. It has the open world and oblique world building of an elder scrolls game combined with a degree of freedom and self-determination that I can't think of seeing anywhere else. It feels like a fully realized world that is having a conversation with you. It tells you you are weak by throwing hordes of starving bandits at you who pummel you into the ground but the very act of standing up again makes your people stronger. It tells you that you are inconsequential, sends taxmen to shake you down, runs you out of town, until one day you come back trained and armed and kill the leader of a faction and throw the entire world into chaos. It smites you with acid rain and orbital lasers and raids by bloodthirsty slavers even as you slowly build up a city of your own construction into one that rivals any of the established communities on the continent. It has crab tournaments!

I have simultaneously loved and hated this game at times, but I haven't been able to get it out of my head, and probably won't until I have asserted my dominance over this weird, slow, complicated game world. I sit at work thinking about my little team and what on earth I should do with them. Are they strong enough to make a pilgrimage north to defend some depressed fisherman from their resigned fate slowly being whittled down by the privations of cannibals? Should I send them into the fog to cut their teeth fighting endless masses of crazed queen-less insectoid cults? If I set up a base are they strong enough to defend it? Where would I even want to settle? What is my 10 step plan to getting strong enough to overthrow Holy Lord Phoenix and his racist misogynist army of zealot slavers? AND HOW DO I BEAT THE CRABS?

I appreciate that this game exists and I think it stands alone and unique, such as it is. It is a flawed masterpiece. Look before you buy to make sure it's the kind of thing you'll be into. 

Finally, long live Beep.

Si nunca has probado las arepas de choclo (también conocidas como cachapas), estás a punto de ser conquistado por una explosión de sabor dulce-salado. Se trata de un plato típico en diferentes regiones de Colombia y Venezuela hecho a base de maíz, choclo o “chocolo” que se doran en aceite o mantequilla y se rellenan de mucho, mucho queso. Son ideales para desayunar, cenar o simplemente disfrutar como merienda.

A diferencia de las arepas colombianas de queso que se hacen con maíz blanco y son saladas, las arepas de choclo están hechas con mazorcas de grano maduro, por lo que tienen un sabor y textura completamente distinto. Éstas se asemejan bastante a los hotcakes, son más bien dulces y esponjosas, y cuando se juntan con el queso, crean una combinación verdaderamente deliciosa.

Ingredientes para las arepas de choclo
Maíz: Puedes usar granos de maíz tierno fresco, enlatado o congelado para hacer estas arepas. Eso sí, si usas maíz dulce enlatado o congelado, asegúrate de retirar el exceso de agua y secarlo antes de usarlo porque tendrá mucha más humedad que el grano fresco.
Huevos: Además de aportar nutrientes, los huevos aportan volumen, estructura y la esponjosidad a nuestras arepas. Utiliza huevos pequeños.
Leche: Muchas recetas utilizan leche entera. Sin embargo, nosotros nos decantamos por la leche en polvo ya que no queremos añadir más humedad a la masa.
Mantequilla: Necesitarás mantequilla derretida para dorar estas arepas caseras y conseguir una capa crujiente.
Harina de maíz: Para contrastar el sabor del maíz y añadir un poco de textura a la masa, hemos incluido un toque de harina de maíz blanca (la misma de las arepas). Esto hace que nuestras tortitas sean un poco más densas y no se quiebren a la hora de asarlas.
Panela: Estas arepas son dulces así que utilizamos panela rallada. Puedes reemplazarla por azúcar o tu edulcorante favorito. Es completamente opcional.
Polvo para hornear: La levadura química nos ayuda a conseguir unas tortitas súper esponjosas.
Queso: Puedes usar cualquier tipo de queso fresco. Te recomendamos el queso blanco, cuajada o queso campesino. También puedes usar queso mozzarella.

Are you fucking serious? You're actually thinking about diving headfirst into the festering cesspool that goes by the name of Kenshi? Well, grab your shit snorkel, because you're about to drown in a tsunami of unadulterated frustration and misery.

Imagine this: you fork over your hard-earned cash for what's touted as an "open-world RPG masterpiece." But what you end up with is a colossal dumpster fire of broken mechanics, half-baked ideas, and enough bugs to rival a termite infestation. Congrats, you've just been royally fucked over by Kenshi.

Oh, and let's chat about combat, shall we? Get ready to witness your so-called skilled warriors flailing around like stupid morons in the middle of battles. Bandits? They'll make mincemeat out of you. Wild animals? They'll maul you into submission before you can even say "Why the fuck am I playing this?"

But oh, the pièce de résistance: the AI. Your party members will showcase a level of idiocy that defies the laws of nature. They'll charge headfirst into danger, get stuck in the most fucking ridiculous places, and come up with innovative ways to off themselves, all while you're left swearing up a storm and contemplating launching your computer out the fucking window.

And don't think for a fucking second that the world of Kenshi is any better. It's like traversing through a shit wasteland of monotony, where the highlight of your day is probably counting the grains of sand that make up the shitty desert.

But wait, there's more! Brace yourself for crashes and bugs that could only be the result of a %@&@ developer's twisted sense of humor. You'll be lucky if you can go  minutes without the game crashing and shattering whatever thread of sanity you had left.

So, go ahead, be my fucking guest. Dive headlong into the abyss that is Kenshi. Bask in the glory of its broken dreams, its shattered promises, and its relentless assault on your patience. But don't come crying to me when you're left huddled in a corner, foaming at the mouth, and fervently wishing you could fucking erase this fucking travesty of a game from your memory.

I'll be honest it took me several tries to get into this game. It can have a slightly steep learning curve if you just try to figure it out for yourself. However, I was always drawn back to it's bleak, lonely, dystopian atmosphere, and now I have to say this is one of my all time favorite games to play. Mods keep it continually interesting, and if you enjoy a challenge, this game is for you. It can feel very, very, very difficult at first while later on you may find yourself to be a complete bad-ass, but there always seems to be someone, or something out there, whether it be new NPCs or factions or simply bad situations you can get yourself into to keep the thrill of being alive... well alive! After multiple play throughs, I have to say the journey from weakling to formidable influencer is extremely rewarding. Best part is, even after you have been established you can continue to recruit weaklings and start the cycle over again of leveling up characters if that's what you enjoy doing.

In my opinion this game is fairly unique in it's styling. I've seen people describe it as simply a base building game. It does have that aspect, but that is only one. You can choose to play it however you want. Whether it be more a role play style or base / army and faction building. You can choose to be good, or bad, or both (I mean in reality isn't good and bad really full of mostly grey areas). It's basically a shite world, and you start with basically nothing, and try to make a go of it. You can even choose to start with a big fat smelly shite sandwich if you want to make it extra fun. If you don't know what to do when you start, you'll likely get a beating and stain the sand with your blood as you slowly lose your last breath with a mouth full of dirt. Then you can start again and try not to do they same dumb thing you did last time. Maybe one day you'll rule the world of Kenshi.

Gather 'round you wretched wasteland wanderers, and let me spin you a twisted tale of a game they call "Kenshi." A swirling vortex of chaos and survival, Picture this: a desolate landscape, a mishmash of post-apocalyptic nightmares, where bloodthirsty bandits and mechanical monstrosities roam with a sense of purpose that's more deranged than a paranoid junkie on a bender.

The controls? Well, they're as clunky as a broken-down dune buggy held together with duct tape and dreams. In this world, where every decision might land you in a cannibal's cauldron, elegance isn't the name of the game. But mark my words, dear readers, for all its grotesque charm, Kenshi possesses an addictive quality that's akin to the grip of a savage hallucination. You'll curse its name as you fumble through its intricacies, and yet you'll find yourself drawn to it like a moth to a bugzapper.

In the end, "Kenshi" is not a game for the faint of heart or the stable of mind. It's a wild ride through the savage landscapes of the digital abyss, a fever dream that blurs the lines between reality and the deranged fantasies of a chemically-altered psyche. Approach with caution, for once you enter this realm, you can quit, uninstall and walk away but you can never be done with it.

In the desolate aftermath of an apocalyptic event that shattered the world, Atritiusoinus was born into a life of hardship and despair. The land was a wasteland, where the remnants of civilization clung to survival amidst the ruins of what once was. Born to parents who had known nothing but suffering and struggle, Atritiusoinus was destined to carve his own path in this unforgiving world.

Atritiusoinus had been a slave in his early years, shackled by the chains of oppression, forced to toil under the rule of a brutal warlord known as The Phoenix. But as time passed, a spark of defiance ignited within him. Atritiusoinus saw others around him, those who had managed to break free from their chains, eking out a dangerous existence as thieves and outlaws. He yearned for his own taste of freedom, no matter the cost.

One fateful night, Atritiusoinus managed to escape from The Phoenix's grasp, slipping through the shadows like a phantom. He knew the wasteland like the back of his hand, having observed it while toiling away in the warlord's encampment. His newfound freedom fueled a desire for revenge against the tyrant who had held him captive for so long.

With a small band of like-minded individuals, Atritiusoinus set out on a path of crime and rebellion. They became skilled scavengers, plundering the remnants of the old world for valuable artifacts and supplies. They learned to navigate the treacherous landscape, avoiding mutant creatures and rival factions that sought to claim their spoils. Atritiusoinus quickly became a charismatic leader, inspiring loyalty and courage in his comrades.

As their reputation grew, Atritiusoinus and his crew began to challenge The Phoenix's rule directly. They launched daring raids on his outposts, disrupting his operations and striking fear into his heart. Atritiusoinus used his knowledge of the terrain to outwit The Phoenix's enforcers, leading them into traps and ambushes.

But the life of crime was not without its sacrifices. Atritiusoinus faced moral dilemmas and internal conflicts. He saw the impact of his actions on the innocent survivors caught in the crossfire between his band and The Phoenix's forces. The wasteland had turned him into a hardened outlaw, but he still held a glimmer of compassion within him.

Amidst the chaos and danger, Atritiusoinus forged unlikely alliances. He encountered a skilled gunner named Truth, who had her own vendetta against The Phoenix. The two formed a bond born of shared goals and mutual respect. Together, they hatched a plan to bring down the warlord once and for all.

Their plan was audacious and dangerous, requiring every ounce of their cunning and bravery. Atritiusoinus and Truth orchestrated a massive uprising, rallying the oppressed survivors across the wasteland to stand against The Phoenix's tyranny. The final battle was a fierce and brutal struggle, with lives lost on both sides.

In the end, Atritiusoinus faced The Phoenix in a one-on-one confrontation that would determine the fate of the wasteland. It was a grueling battle of wills and strength, with Atritiusoinus tapping into reserves of determination he never knew he had. In a climactic moment, he emerged victorious, ending The Phoenix's reign of terror and bringing a semblance of justice to the shattered world.

With The Phoenix defeated, Atritiusoinus faced a new challenge: rebuilding and restoring hope to the wasteland. He and Truth, now his partner, worked tirelessly to establish a semblance of order, forming alliances with other factions and providing aid to those in need. Atritiusoinus had come a long way from his days as a slave, transforming from a symbol of defiance to a beacon of hope in a world desperately seeking redemption.

And so, in the midst of a desolate wasteland, Atritiusoinus's life of crime and rebellion evolved into a noble quest to bring light to the darkness, proving that even in the bleakest of times, the human spirit could rise above and forge a new future.

This is a weird game, but I've enjoyed it a lot. I wish there was more content in that you could speak with more people or do more goal oriented "quests." The cities and NPCs are super vacuous, which can make things feel pointless. You also get no context for the world, the factions, the history, nothing. You really have to entertain yourself with this game, but you are given enough freedom and options that that isn't hard to do. It's like building a model train set in a digital, hostile world. 

It's cool that you can find a niche for yourself in the harsh world of Kenshi in a somewhat organic way. For example, I ended up starting a base surrounded by the extremely hostile and powerful beak things, mostly because it was isolated from humans, and had good resources available. Although the beak things constantly posed a threat to my squad, we learned to live with them, and over time we used them to attack bandits, we scavenged equipment from the humans they killed, and we got good at killing them individually so they would provide a consistent source of food. 

I felt it was cool you could use the dynamic world of Kenshi to thrive in creative ways. However, because everyone else is so aggressive and strong, most of those ways mean turning your enemies against each other and scavenging. This is not necessarily super fun, and in a way doesn't give you the freedom that the game promises.   

Glitches happen, but my game has only crashed a couple of times. 

Edit after full release:

I was a fan of this game before, now it's one of my favorite games ever. My complaints have been largely addressed, while what I liked about the game is even better now.

Edit after 500 hours:

Now I have to say, by sheer amount of hours, that it is my favorite game. It's almost like a hobby in itself, you can always work away at a play through in little bursts. But I think now I've finally exhausted the content, after multiple play throughs, and have enjoyed it a great deal. And who knows, perhaps I'll pick it up again someday, if Kenshi 2 does not come out soon enough, just to wander through the beautiful wastes of Kenshi again.

You can hate yourself, go solo, start with an arm missing, hungry and with no equipment and decide to go the martial arts route in a world with robots. But, similar to RimWorld, it's not over as long as you still have at least one person alive. They got their legs cut off, lost that other arm, and left to die in the desert? Well, it'll tough, and mostly luck, but yeah... You can technically recover... I didn't, but you can.

ok, you can see I didn't play for very long.  It was the camera.  It's not a follow behind nor can you really set it to be for very long.  I simply could not handle trying to get the camera so I had a good view of my character and the surroundings or what he was headed into.  Camera gets blocked by terrain between you and your character.  Camera doesn't follow behind character very well and usually ends up following along side or any which way depending on the route your char is going, based on the destination you set for it.  I can't imagine trying to fight or do anything significant with this camera behavior.  I generally prefer first person views which also is not available.  However, I can do 3rd person with reasonable stable camera positioning and transparent intervening terrain.   This is none of that.   As a result, I have not gotten into any of the specifics of the game other than mining a little bit.   Even so, I have to not recommend simply because of the camera, which is a shame to have to say.

I tried to give this game a chance but it didn't offer enough. Despite being a sandbox game there is a surprising lack of anything you can do. All you really do is go mine rocks or loot dead people until you yourself get killed by a giant group of raiders in the middle of the desert. I'm sure there are some things to do once you get going, but the journey there is super boring. All you do is click on a town on the map, and sit for 10 minutes in 3x speed while your character runs to it. Good luck if you actually try to loot anything because you'll be moving half speed. Once you actually make it to a town, every type of trader sells the same 10 items. There is no real crafting system from what I could tell, the only crafting is base building which is essentially impossible. This means that you can't improvise any sort of medical items or tools.  You wanna go mining? You don't need a pickaxe, you just have one! It just isn't fun and doesn't feel like a true sandbox survival game.
