Great game especially for its price and it was made by 1 developer. It has its bugs but good saving practices can circumvent that. There is also save importing. From my own experience so far, bugs are minor and the ones that I found were very amusing. (Got stuck in an outhouse once, I decided to make a character sit on it but got stuck when he tried to leave.) I save often so it was a minor inconvenience. You can use another character to pick him up if you have one.

Pros:
You can tweak the game settings to allow for as many npcs as possible. You will be able to witness and participate in large scale battles that can spread from a small valley to a whole plateau.
Got a character killed? Use another! Training multiple characters is like making backups. Just remember to train and equip them.

Cons:
Game was made by 1 guy. Don't expect AAA polish.
Sometimes parts of the game bug out. I had a bug once where a whole town didn't spawn npcs so it was a ghost town that others still visited but did nothing. Shops were locked. Goods were still there, it was like they just left. Spoooookyyyyy!!!

Absolutely brutal mechanics to learn, this game teaches you to know your limits as your character/group, whether your character is super weak, a woman, or another race, this game will make sure to punish you for it! Overall one of the best experiences I've had on any sort of game even remotely similar to this, and that's saying a lot.

I can't recommend this game enough. Trying to describe Kenshi to someone is difficult. Its kinda like a squad based RPG kinda like Pillars of Eternity but it definitely gave me some Mount and Blade vibes as well as feeling like an RTS in other ways. Suffice it to say, this game is amazing and one of the most unique games I have ever played. It is also pretty hard, if the description wasn't a give away there. But it is SO worth it! Oh my gosh this game is so fun. I LOVE this game so much! And it has Steam Workshop support so there are a plethora of mods for it too. Overwhelmingly positive has got to say something right? If you are on the fence and think anything I have said sounds interesting then PICK UP THE GAME! If you are anything like me you will be kicking yourself for not pulling the trigger on it sooner!

Kenshi is The Sims meets Skyrim.
     It is The Sims for the players ability to create characters that you must manage in order to have them properly live a healthy life.
     And it is Skyrim for it's fantastical open world and freedom of what your can do, but Kenshi surpasses Skyrim in its freedom, there is no great threat you must stop, there is no war you must fight in, those things are there in Kenshi, but you have more freedom over it. You can claim bounties for cash, or become the bounty and destroy all of those who stand in your way.
     There's plenty of battles in Kenshi between the factions, and you may partake in them, but you can also start wars, rebel against powerful leaders and take their throne.
     But not everyone is up for the task of starting a rebellion, and you don't have to, you can just be a farmer who grows crops to trade in for cash so they can eat, or a miner who sells ore to the local populous. The possibilities are quite possibly endless, if you can pull it off.
     Even if you're a little tired of getting your ass kicked by starter game bandits, you can always get mods that make you start out with maxed out stats and OP gear. Kenshi truly has something for everyone.
     Sure, it is a little hard to pick up for beginners, but everyone's looked up a tutorial on youtube some time or another.

Kenshi's most interesting feature is the wide variety of playstyles it offers, varying from straight RPG to survival to tower defense game depending on whatever you feel like doing at the moment, which it does by taking a minimalist approach to gameplay, not really prodding the player to do anything besides 'not die' (rarely even giving any real goals at all), and this can be a refreshing change from the usual 'fetch me 20 bear butts' questing that many other RPGs do.     
Unfortunately that minimalism seeps into places it doesn't belong; the lore's a bit thin, the AI is often too simplistic, too much important info is buried in easy-to-miss book items (like the rules of the violently-luddite Holy Nation) or just not well explained in game (you'll be doing an annoying amount of google), and the game gets too quiet later on, as the majority of characters are silent outside a few one-time quips.

AI pathfinding is bad enough to deserve a separate mention, I often have to micromanage my squads just to keep them going in the same direction or not get spread halfway across the map, and it (along with the clunky UI) makes multiple squads or large armies nigh-impossible to handle.


It also lacks any hint of polish - the absolute mountain of bugs, spelling errors, poorly tuned physics, the clunky UI and clunkier base build system make it feel like it never really left the dev stage. I particularly dislike having to frequently use the 'import tool' - a sort of save-repair tool - to fix things that go wrong, as it resets NPCs you've killed.   
Some design decisions left me scratching my head, and I was also constantly running into features I expected to exist - like setting your own squads to patrol as the other NPCs do - not being present, and instead having to go dig for mods.

Additionally, there's quite a bit of loading lag going on; I haven't had an issue with it personally but for those with less powerful PCs it might be a sticking point.

Now despite all that, you could still find enjoyment in Kenshi; if you're the sort of person who sees a bug in a game and sees an opportunity for a new mod project rather than a point of frustration, or spends hours on hours slapping mods into a game before you even start your first save file, welcome to Kenshi. It'll happily eat up all your time.   
But the average person isn't going to have the patience to dig through the buggy dumpster fire part to get to the game beneath, so it still gets a 'not recommended'.


Also, using the naruto run for sneaking characters is an unforgivable sin.
Worth every dollar.

I recently had the pleasure of diving into the captivating world of Kenshi, and let me tell you, it was an absolute joyride from start to finish! Kenshi, developed by Lo-Fi Games, offers a unique and unforgettable gaming experience that sets it apart from any other game I've played before. From its open-ended sandbox gameplay to its post-apocalyptic setting, Kenshi delivers an immersive and challenging adventure that keeps you hooked for hours on end.

One of the standout features of Kenshi is its open world, which is truly massive and feels like a living, breathing world. The sheer freedom the game offers is refreshing, allowing players to forge their own paths and shape their destiny. Want to be a humble trader or a merciless bandit? The choice is entirely yours. This level of freedom ensures that each playthrough is a completely different experience, adding tremendous replay value to the game.

The depth of gameplay mechanics in Kenshi is mind-blowing. As you start with a single character and build your squad, you'll find yourself faced with numerous challenges and opportunities for growth. The character development system is well-crafted, and every member of your squad can specialize in various skills, making them more proficient in combat, crafting, or other vital aspects of survival.

Moreover, the world of Kenshi is harsh and unforgiving, which may seem intimidating at first, but it's one of the game's greatest strengths. You'll face hostile factions, dangerous creatures, and scarcity of resources, forcing you to strategize, adapt, and make tough decisions to survive. The sense of accomplishment you get from overcoming these challenges is truly gratifying.

The graphics and art style might not be the most cutting-edge, but they possess a unique charm that complements the game's post-apocalyptic atmosphere perfectly. Additionally, the sound design and music enhance the immersion, pulling you deeper into the world of Kenshi.

The developer's commitment to the game's community is also commendable. Regular updates and patches demonstrate their dedication to addressing issues and improving the overall experience. The modding community is thriving, allowing players to customize and expand their Kenshi adventures to their heart's content.

In conclusion, Kenshi is a masterpiece that captures the essence of what a true open-world experience should be. Its sprawling world, deep gameplay mechanics, and freedom to forge your own destiny make it an incredibly rewarding journey for any gaming enthusiast. If you're seeking an unforgettable and challenging adventure, look no further than Kenshi. Embrace the wasteland, survive, and thrive in this post-apocalyptic gem!

Up there with Fallout New Vegas with the level of adventure and story telling Kenshi has to offer. However where those 2 games differ, is missions. Kenshi has no missions and no set quest lines. This game is at its core, just a world. Your character is spawned in and is now just another miniscule cog in that world. However if you want, you can become an even bigger part of the world and collide with some of the biggest factions and take over the world. Or you can stay as a lowlife and scrap with bandits and never really settle down. There's so so much more however. The world is extremely explorable and fun to live in. Tons of groups and factions along with 150 unique characters in the world you're able to interact with and learn about as well as potentially fight and explore together. This game took 12 years to make mostly by one guy and you can tell how detailed and passionate this story creator is. The game is great and personally I love the RPG element behind it which is the only thing that might hold this game back for some people. Personally though, this is probaly the best RPG you're able to play. The world is unforgiving and terrifying. The world does not care about you and couldn't give a shit less what you have to say or do. They will enslave, beat, mug, eat, mutilate, stab, and skin you. It's terrifying and thrilling. Enjoy every moment.

Kenshi, at first glance, is a game of survival and exploration. Yet, beneath its rugged exterior lies a profound philosophical narrative that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming. It is a testament to the human spirit, a digital canvas that paints a vivid picture of resilience, adaptability, and the relentless pursuit of meaning amidst chaos.

The game thrusts you into a desolate, post-apocalyptic world with no clear objectives, no hand-holding tutorials, and no promise of survival. It is a stark reminder of our own existential condition, a reflection of the absurdity of life as proposed by Albert Camus. Like Sisyphus, we are condemned to an eternity of struggle, pushing our boulder up the hill only to watch it roll back down. Yet, it is in this struggle that we find our purpose, our joy, our defiance against the indifferent universe.

Kenshi's open-ended gameplay mirrors the philosophy of existentialism, emphasizing freedom, choice, and personal responsibility. You are not a predestined hero, but an ordinary individual, carving out a path in a world indifferent to your existence. It is a poignant commentary on the human condition, a nod to Sartre's proclamation that "existence precedes essence". In Kenshi, you exist first, and it is up to you to define your essence, your purpose, your values.

The game's brutal difficulty and unforgiving nature serve as a metaphor for life's hardships. It is a crucible that forges character, a trial by fire that echoes Nietzsche's sentiment: "What does not kill me, makes me stronger". Every defeat, every setback, every loss in Kenshi is a lesson, a stepping stone towards growth and self-improvement. It is a testament to the resilience of the human spirit, a celebration of our capacity to endure, adapt, and overcome.

The social dynamics and moral choices in Kenshi further enhance its philosophical depth. It forces us to confront the ethical dilemmas and moral ambiguities that permeate our existence, echoing the moral philosophy of Immanuel Kant and the ethical dilemmas posed by utilitarianism. Every decision, every action, every alliance in Kenshi has consequences, reminding us of our agency and the ripple effects of our choices.
fuck yeah

Hey there fellow gamers! Today, I'm going to talk about Kenshi.

The game that left me speechless, and my thumbs sore. First things first, Kenshi is not your typical RPG game. It's a harsh, unforgiving, and merciless world where you have to claw your way to the top, or end up dead in a ditch. The game starts with you, a nobody, wandering in the vast desert world, with no resources or guidance. The sense of isolation and desperation is palpable, but trust me, it only gets worse from there. The game is so hard, that it makes Dark Souls look like child's play. You'll die, and die again, and die some more. And each time, you'll learn something new, something that'll help you survive for a little bit longer. You'll scavenge for food, water, and weapons, and avoid any hostile faction that crosses your path. And when you're not running for your life, you're building your base, and recruiting other survivors to your cause. But what makes Kenshi truly stand out is its sheer depth and complexity. The world is alive, with its own economy, politics, and history. Every character you encounter has a backstory, a purpose, and a reason for being there. And the game doesn't hold your hand, nor does it spoon-feed you information. You have to explore, interact, and experiment to uncover the game's secrets. And speaking of secrets, Kenshi has a lot of them. From hidden treasure troves to secret factions, there's always something to discover. And once you do, you'll be rewarded with new gear, new allies, and new challenges. The game never gets stale, and even after hundreds of hours of playtime, I'm still discovering new things.

Of course, the game is not without its flaws. The graphics are dated, and the combat can be clunky at times. But honestly, that's part of its charm. Kenshi is not a game that tries to impress you with fancy graphics or slick gameplay. It's a game that tries to immerse you in its world, and make you feel like a survivor.

In conclusion, Kenshi is not a game for everyone. It's hard, it's complex, and it demands your attention. But if you're willing to put in the time and effort, it's also one of the most rewarding and satisfying games out there.

So, if you're looking for a game that'll test your mettle and your patience, give Kenshi a try. Just be warned, once you start playing, you won't be able to stop.

Hey, you! Yeah I'm talking to you! Do you like The Sims, but you always felt like it lacked a sense of dread and despair? Do you like the Fallout CRPGs but always felt like the turn-based combat held the game back from true greatness? Do you like RTS games but wanted to opportunity to build/foster your own thriving farming/drug manufacturing community?

Well, Kenshi might just be the game for you. On a moon in the far-out universe, you experience life on a planet that was once home to an advanced civilization; I say once-home because there have been multiple catastrophes in the time before your arrival which have practically left this place uninhabitable. This game doesn't care whether you play it or not. You might be figuring out how to keep your small band of invalids from starving to death somewhere out in the desert while, across the continent, nations of slightly less-pathetic peoples wage war. 

This is a living world that is constantly changing. It has deep lore that WILL NOT be spoon-fed to you with cutscenes or burdensome exposition. Go forth and make your story as you see fit, and remember: with enough imagination and ambition, anything is free real-estate.

As the sunrise, so did the smoke from the ashes of their homes. Only five were left in what remained in the once quiet village in Verge. Jentai, a woman whose strength and height alone brought a commanding presence. Leo, a thinly built young lad whose whose quick planning allowed for himself and the others to survive. Skell, the only skeleton in the area who is in search of a new master. Twitch, a born fighter who wishes she could have done more. Battai, the only Scorchlander in the area who is often quiet with his appearance covered. Without a home or an allegiance to the neighboring kingdoms, they had become nobodies. 

The five set their sights to the north and entered the desert. Battai kept an eyeful watch as Leo forewarned the dangers that lie ahead. Reaver platoons could be seen from the far distance which sent the group sneaking and hiding out of sight. Jentai developed a growing concern seeing Leo stagger in the hot sand and having trouble keeping up. Taking it as both an opportunity to help and gain her strength, she grabbed hold of Leo and carried his limp body over her shoulder. While this in turn ended up slowing Jentai down, she still felt empowered by the act and confident about protecting him. 

At about 15 paces away, Twitch was suddenly leading the pack as she discussed the next destination with Skell and Battai. Their only nearby options were Black Scratch and Brink, both under the United Cities rules. Skell was indecisive on the matter where as Battai gave a slight nod upon the mention of Black Scratch. All they knew of the locations was their positions on the map. Brink appeared to be larger, but Black Scratch was closer. Battai then pointed to Black Scratch on his map in which Twitch relunctantly agreed to. 

The five approached the gates and greeted by the guards. They were allowed entry without question, even if it became apparent the group was without money or even a shirts. Leo was seemingly asleep and still perched on Jentai's shoulder as she observed any opportunities for shelter. Battai signals for the group to follow and they spot an abandoned home to take refuge in. They camped on the floor, but were wary about staying there over night. Staying there was technically a crime. 

As Leo came to, he suggested that they must find ways to make money in order to stay here. The group then discussed opportunities such as mining, farming, crafting and looting. They each revealed their past expertise. Leo's ability to craft clothing would net them large profits if only they had access to a machine. Skell's knowledge of making weapons would also prove fruitless. Jentai who farmed and mined for most of her life mentioned an iron mine just outside the village. Battai and Twitch while inexperienced went along as they had the strength to carry the materials back. 

Leo and Skell would keep watch as Twitch, Battai and Jentai went hard at work. Twitch begin to vent her frustration about the Reavers destroying their homes and being unpunished. Leo shouted something and it was at that moment, a group of Reavers appearance in the distance. Twitch was for a second overwhelmed by  the sight of their numbers as Jentai was quick to raise her fist. Brink guards quickly intervened, getting in between the two groups. After a quick battle, Brink was victorious and walked away from the remaining Reavers who laid there dying. 

Twitch removed a sword from a Reaver's hand, claiming it as her own. Skell listed a piece of armor and calculated it's worth. The idea then dawned on the group that looting and selling this equipment might raise enough to buy their home. Three days past between mining and another skirmish at the gates. Jentai would start to participate in these battles which inspired confidence in Twitch and latter Battai  to do the same. Each night, Leo would dress Jentai's wounds who noticed her body being stronger and harder each time. Twitch would also become more aggressive with Battai fighting by her side...

This is the hardest game to review because while i absolutely love it i can see why someone would hate it. Its hard. Very hard. You will die constantly and at times the game feels impossible and like your being punished for playing, but once you get the hang of it its amazing. The world is enormous and the lore is astounding. i think the most important thing i can say is this game is only as fun as you make it, there's no story, there is no ending, you have to entertain/motivate yourself. Wanna be a bounty hunter? Sure. Drug runner? You can. Treasure hunter? Farmer? There's tons of different ways to play and none of them are wrong but if you're not invested in your characters it can get old. Still 10/10, i recommend watching youtube game play to give you an idea before you start, i bought it totally blind and it was not what i was expecting but i ended up loving it all the same.
Can be hard in the beginning, but it gets much better.

Are the graphics low quality and game engine outdated? Oh yes, and then some. But don't let the visual shortcomings stop you from experiencing one of the best survival RPG experiences ever made. There's nothing out there I can directly compare Kenshi's gameplay to - it is unique and extremely addicting.

There are elements of complex crafting (almost on the level of SWG), survival, RTS, automation, exploration, hack and slash looting, stealth assassinations and thievery, trading, and base-building, but being in a huge sandbox world means you can play or not play it any way you like. Not to mention the huge number of mods and reshades available to further customize the game.

I hesitated for years on buying this game because of 'the look' and finally bought it on sale, just to try out and return it if I didn't like it in the first two hours. I should have bought Kenshi years ago. Less than three weeks and I'm already 184 hours into my first game. If I ever get bored with the little empire I've built in the Foglands, I can start again with one of the many starter scenarios. Maybe I'll start as a slave next time...

After 2000 hours and one my longest played games on Steam I felt I should update my review. Kenshi is one of a kind in very many aspects. It scratches a very unique itch for RPG players, especially hardcore survival types. You can't really get this gameplay anywhere else, closest would be something like 3-D Rimworld but Rimworld has more depth and is much more fleshed out. Rimworld also has it's focus on a story generator which lends to always having great stories despite their being no actual written story or dialogue. Kenshi is very very similar in that way, you make your own story, it's there to find if you search for it. The characters just don't really distinguish themselves except through backstory and lore. Really good lore too.  
So why this instead of Rimworld? The action and animations of course. It hits all the areas that Rimworld doesn't hit, namely the combat and the exploration. This game is one of the greats in terms of power creep, progression, and balance. But then why wouldn't it be a perfect game? What's stopping you from playing it all the time? 
As I learned more about the game I became disappointed in some of the games more frustrating facilities. Things like frequent crashing through certain biomes, no notifications on attacks, needing to load your game to make your characters work, enemies spawning on you on game load, entire houses being useless because characters can't enter due to placement bugs, poor pathfinding sometimes right into an enemies sword.(its a topdown rts) Unfortunately it's a growing list. Despite the annoyances and how frequent they are I would say Kenshi is a great game that's got some annoying things in it. Overall my 1000's of hours would say that's worth it. Then I realize how little progress my characters have made despite me power leveling 6 hours a day for the last 4 days. And I start to feel the time sink and I feel like I've spent way too much time on something I get very little from.  
Then my wife comes in and says "Oh my god your still training?" or "Is this like a training game or what?" And I realize that not all that time was spent on fun gameplay.
 I just spent 30 actual hours training to 70 skill across the board with 6 characters on triple speed. That's the kind of time sink your looking at. And if that character dies, load or cry you just lost a legend lol. 
I think most would see my 1000's of hours and say "This must be a good game." I would say, watch a LOT of gameplay and see if it's something you want. Then make sure you have a LOT of time set aside. Your about to watch those characters crawl towards success only slightly faster than you do in real life. 
All in all great game, one of a kind, with some frequent annoyances that can probably be ignored if you don't take it too seriously.

I like base building and raising champions from scrubs...I also love playing as a stealth character whether it is a thief or assassin...I really had a great time playing this game.  I confess to using some mods/cheats to cut down on the grind times...I think I used a mod that adds more comprehensive dummies that can raise your scrubs' stats to a higher level because I found the dummy cap to be too low for my liking.  Whatever.  It's worth killing some hours in the world of Kenshi.

Kenshi is a game that should still be in early access. It is poorly optimized and you will encounter issues with FPS no matter your system. Several features feel incomplete or have small frustrating issues that should have been addressed before release. There are not enough tutorials or the ones that exist are not specific enough, requiring trial-and-error or a quick google search. There's really not much of a story available and it's difficult to get invested in any of the factions.

Past these grievances, however, it can be very enjoyable. Managing a squad, creating your own settlements anywhere you want in the world (as long as it isn't right next to another settlement), the health system, the openness, and the setting are strong points. Kenshi is something special and I hope for a sequel.

My first every run I started off as a slave. A simple scorchlander, who was captured by the Holy Nation. I was unsure what exactly to do, so I stayed a slave for 80 in-game days. Approximately 9 hours in real time. I did my duty, and trained various skills such as sneak, lockpicking, and toughness for when I got my ass beat. Slowly but surely, I started to dream of escaping. I began stealing and stockpiling food in the building where my cell was. I began sneaking out at night, and unlocking other slave's shackles. The slaves were starting to try and revolt/escape. This caused havoc and chaos in the slave camp. However, there was still way too many guards. So I continued doing this, planting the seed of rebellion every night. I recruited 2 other people and together we were going to escape. 

The day came when it was now or never, angry slaves by the dozen started to revolt against the Holy Nation. I saw this as my opportunity and took all my food. The three of us began to make a run for it, we were got pretty far but then the guards took notice. We had about 20+ guards chasing after us. Luckily, my main guy was FAST. I trained and did sprints everyday while in the slave camp, in hopes that I would one day be able to outrun the guards. My other two friends however were not as fast... We got to the exit and ambushed by a patrol right outside the gate. I lost my arm!!! My damn arm was cut off by these bastards. I noticed my two other friends were knocked unconscious and carried back to the camp..... I ran into the desert without an arm and clueless on how to survive. I vowed to return and rescue my two friends. 

130 hours later, I had recruited quite the entourage, and we built a camp about 30 miles to the south. We were growing strong, and the Holy Nation took a notice. My main guy who started it all eventually lost every limb through combat. I replaced his limbs with the strongest prosthetic limbs in the desert. I was a deadly martial artist. The time had come to wage war against the Holy Nation. We began leaving our camp and hitting patrols and capturing key leaders. Crucifying them on front of our fortified camp. 

We eventually marched back to the slave camp with 15 warriors and slaughtered the Holy Nation, freeing all the slaves. Where were my friends? They were nowhere to be found.....Maybe they made it out? Or maybe 2 years of excruciating labor killed them. I wish we reunited and I could of told them tales on what I've seen out there..

This is merely one small slither of the story. In between escaping, was hundreds of struggles and adventures.

Very different game from my usual go to.  It's essentially a closed sand box that you can manipulate as you see fit.  The hardest part is learning the very intricate systems (armor and armor stats, weapons and weapon stats, weight, attributes, counters, sneak, taking prisoners, being a prisoner, food harvesting and management, factions, rest/recovery).  It takes a while to get the hang of it.  Once you reach the point you start to grasp how the systems work you're either gonna be hooked, or you're gonna pass.  

The game is very unforgiving, there are going to be countless trial and error attempts at understanding and/or executing certain plans.  This is a game that is not going to do too much hand holding.  You live, you learn.  You die, you learn more.

The best part: Once you get the hang of it, you realize just how much replay-ability this game has.  Countless hours.  

The worst part: You'll constantly be learning new systems and how they interact, IF you pay attention.  There are penalties or buffs that are hard to spot or understand if you don't read/study carefully.  Also leveling up different attributes can take time depending on your methods.  

If you are one that finds the systems and sandbox world to be interesting and worth understanding, then this is a game (like most) that can be insanely exploited, or thoroughly enjoyed.  Or, in many cases, both.

PS. There are definitely power spikes at certain points.  You'll start as the weakest creature in existence but you can eventually become insanely powerful with a band of the baddest warriors on the map. Throughout the leveling process the world slowly begins to open up and then quickly gets bigger.  Eventually, you realize that you've crossed that threshold needed to explore the world semi-safely.  But, be ready to accept the consequences of the unknown..... its a dangerous world out there, for a toy.

> Start as a naked hobo in a desert without an arm

> Disobey orders so they beat you up
> Fake down and crawl away when they're not looking
> Heal yourself up, pick the lock, sneak away
> Things going okay
> Watch the Holy Order and The Empire war from a mile away
> Holy Order wins, everyone leaves
> Steal their clothes
> Holy Order thinks you're a slaver
> Holy Order attacks you 
> Other arm gets cut off
> Take off the armor of The Empire
> Run to Holy Order town
> Wait for night
> Loot the fuck outta that town
> Take stolen shit to another city
> Buy new arms
> Start getting away from being stuck 24/7
> Die to random wolf pack you didn't notice 
10/10 game, would suffer again

Probably in the top 3 sandbox games I've ever played.  The zero to hero gameplay is incredibly satisfying. Very few games allow you through intense struggle to rise from total ineptitude to absolute unit in such a cool manner. 

Watching your character get shredded & unlock new kinds of attacks and evasions as they progress is just amazing. Learning the lore of the world as your squad chit-chats while traversing the vast wastes is organic narrative perfection. 

In youtube or written reviews, commentators often seem to find this game visually unappealing, I just can't wrap my head around that.  Kenshi is a beautiful game, the landscapes, armor, clothing, characters, weapons, everything is consistent & it all comes together to create an amazing overall aesthetic.  

I was a child before the internet, I have extremely fond memories of playing with action figures and staging epic battles for hours. I was just moving figures around in my back yard but in my mind great struggles were being fought out, defeat or victory were never assured.  When all I had to rely on was my imagination it went wild, Kenshi gives me almost the exact same feeling. 

The ONLY complaint's I could make are almost certainly just engine limitations, load-times when travelling & some self destructive pathing (please don't swim through that lake of acid my dude). Otherwise this game is about perfect. Waiting patiently for Kenshi 2.

This game will grab you by the balls, subsequently causing them to rupture and bleed all over your expensive gaming chair, but in doing so will create an addiction inside of you greater than any cartel street crack you'll find. And to top of the amazing highs and ridiculous come downs this game will have you experiencing, it was made by ONE FUCKING DUDE. Shoutout Lo-FI games, grog and hashish for life.

First off, yes - Kenshi is janky, sometimes buggy, and will more than likely crash on you more than once. If you can look beyond these flaws, Kenshi offers a very unique and fun experience. The game offers you a lot of freedom, being able to start off pretty much anywhere and in varying situations. You get to create your own journey and (to an extent) shape the world around you.

Started out as a wandering loner, got beat up by pretty much every enemy group I encountered, ended up with a missing limb. Resorted to thievery to get enough money to be able to acquire a new robotic arm, and felt pretty good about it once I did, only to find out that the Holy Nation apparently hate anyone with robot parts. I quickly got into trouble visiting one of their outposts, got the tar kicked out of me once again, and promptly got taken into slavery. All that in the span of a single day. Kenshi is wild.

There's a bit of a learning curve as far as the game mechanics go, but it is not so bad, there are also a lot of mods available in the workshop worth checking out. (Though some of them might increase the bugs/janky behaviour you may encounter.)

Kenshi is a very open ended sandbox where you decide what to do.  You can choose to wander the world and explore old ruins or bounty hunt. You can buy a house in city and craft weapons, armor, or brew alcohol for a living. You can build your own base out in the world. Better yet, everyone including your characters and other NPCs all follow the same stat board making you no one special. This game is on par with Rimworld and similar titles when it comes to open end sandbox game play that can create wonderful stories.

Kat was a wandering swords-woman. Each town she visited, each bar she stayed, she met many kinds of people. From towering skeletons, to feeble stick people. And sometimes, she ends up forging friendship among them. 

With these people, she fought tooth and nail for their lives against the raging Holy Nation, the patrolling bandits and the god forsaken beak things and they have always triumphed. 

On a calm night in Shark, Kat turned restlessly around her bed.  She tells her comrades that she is tired and wants to settle down. Her comrades stared at her in disbelief. "Kat? The lady who drinks the blood of bandits, great gorillos and Holy Paladins alike? Wants to retire?"

A long silence casted upon the crew until one of them broke the silence with laughter. "Then a home we'll find!" and the calm night turned into a frenzy of laughter and happiness.

As the crew settled down, they have built their houses, tended their crops and raised their walls... unbeknowst to them, a group of cute herbivores walked into their settlement and earned their hearts and minds...

Until they saw the crops. Turned rabid did the herbivores as they feasted on the crops. Kat and her crew tried to stop them, the herbivores turned their attention to them instead and soon an onslaught begun.

Here lies Kat and her crew, their lives lost to the wilderness of Kenshi, not from the bandits, the Beak Things, or the Holy Nation... but to the horrors of the Herbivores, the Raptors.

The end.

Kenshi is what you make of it. 

It is a harsh world, where suffering is around every corner.

Are you willing to embrace that you're going to get assaulted and left to die, over and over again? Embrace that the world doesn't care about you and will take everything from you, even your freedom?

If you are, you will eventually get back up, become stronger, find powerful weapons, Recruit new allies, build your sanctuary against the onslaught, wage war en discover what happened to the world that was before.

In my opinion, Kenshi is the best game to ever come out of early access. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys games likes dark souls, Mount and Blade, Baldur's gate, Age of empires and everything in between.

It's taken forever to build up enough confidence to strike out. Once I did, i remade my base, built massive walls and encircled resources. Put up crossbows and whenever attacks come I turtle up. 

Frustrations are large party battles, and armor that hits you with penalties is easier to go without so far. A lot more types of weapons could be introduced like shurikens and throwing stars since there's a heavy Japanese vibe. The world map seems overly large for the redundant monsters. For all it's setbacks I am still waiting to go home after work and see how much further I can push out.

It is an extremely good game, but it is clearly lacking in certain aspects. Stability and graphics are the only problems i have encountered that couldnt be fixed via mods though, so if you dont mind the graphics i would 100% recommend this game. I also definitely recommend using mods.

There is a good base and fun to be had in the game with the combat/survival but unfortunately it is too limited and underwhelming, not fleshed out enough. The map is huge but very empty, with so little of interest, uniques, so few secrets or treasures. Almost no interactions with anyone or anything, not even the basic stuff, not that much to do, the world doesn't feel alive, everything is static. Nothing changes if you come back to a place after 2 months. Ruins don't get rebuilt, destroyed houses stay rubble. No faction war. The immersion takes a hit. You will just encounter groups of humanoids roaming around regularly with generic gear and carrying no coins. On that topic the gear you will find is quite poor, nothing stands out, a lot looks like makeshift scraps, there is a lack of variety. Cities are tiny and don't have much to them, a few stores and a bar most of the time. A couple of houses maybe. The game economy is not interesting to partake in since it's fake (timed shop refresh). I didn't see any missions/quests (without joining a faction) except bounties which are not that many, one or two per (major) area.

I like sandboxes and i don't particularly care if there is no story no plot guiding you when the game has deep mechanics and you can participate/influence the world (like X games). Making your own fun is often better but here the game just doesn't provide enough, it feels like an old solo mmo but without the quests. You can't even capture buildings/bases or cities without mods, and from what i've seen it's still limited and disappointing. The antique engine is really struggling to run the big map, with regular loadings while travelling. Some areas are very stuttery, like it's loading something every 2s (on max distances). The sound design is nothing memorable.

The targetted/localized damage system is quite good but it is ruined by the impossibility to finish off someone or keep attacking them after they lie down unconscious. They'll just keep getting up several times after a few mns and attack you, they can even sprint with critical wounds (other than on the legs). This is especially a problem when you are trying to clear an outpost and they just keep reviving and shooting from the roof mounted harpoons at impossible angles.

I gave the vanilla experience a fair chance but mods seem to be a requirement to fully exploit the potential of this game.

Edit : with a dozen mods and particularly Universal Wasteland Expansion, (which alone is half the size of the game !!!) most of my issues with Kenshi seem to be addressed. The game goes from feeling early access to a competent full release. I need to keep playing but i would probably recommend the game in this condition with such needed overhauls and additions.

I live, breathe, and die Kenshi. I won't stop playing this game until the sequel comes out. If I get bored playing other games, Kenshi is always a shoulder to cry on. Even if I'm not bored, the allure of bloodstained sand and a life of slavery is too much to ignore and I go back. You can play it like an idle game, or an rpg, or a little economy sim, or a large scale rts combat game, really anything you can think of there's probably a backwards explanation of how Kenshi can give you exactly what you're looking for. Humanity will be complete when the "beam yourself into Kenshi" technology is developed. There will be no more up to go. Nothing can fully explain what this game has to offer until you inevitably put your 1000 hours into it. Buy it.

Although I find this game to be absolutely awesome because of how cut throat it is and the reward which can come from being fully battle ready and defeating those once undefeatable enemies, I have to warn new players of the cost which come from just being able to do that. I have played this game for 120 hours now. In that time I have hardly explored the map and my squad is at mostly a decent stat level around 20 for most squad members on important skills. The biggest drawback to this game is the amount of time you must grind to get more skilled. This is a core component of the game which can make it a hit or miss. To me, it is both good and great but depends on your desires and circumstances. Training can take HOURS and HOURS of time which is really really frustrating! Why I have such an issue with this is that I can play for hours and only make a margin of progress. This is only worsened by the fact I have made the mistake 2 to 3 times now of trying to start a base too soon. The game doesn't discourage you from base-building early on but makes you learn the hard way-- being raided, time and time again. Raids are extremely frequent and will absolutely obliterate your squad if you are not ready. Asides from this problem of base building, base building removes the power the player has of being a nomad if you are not self-sufficient enough to protect yourself. When I expanded my squad, I have always had to CONSTANTLY manage between all my characters. This has been tolerable during the start, but later it just becomes mind numbingly tedious and greatly disrupts the immersion and pacing of the game.

Overall, if you are considering purchasing this game, I strongly advice you wait until getting a decent sized squad with strong stats before you ever build a base. Additionally, I also recommend exploring the world just for the sense of discovery and the loot you can find which is much better for arming your characters then gathering weapons and armor through trade.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Review:
Kenshi is an extraordinary game that defies genre conventions and delivers an unparalleled gaming experience. Developed by Lo-Fi Games, this open-world sandbox RPG offers a captivating blend of freedom, survival, and limitless possibilities. From its vast and unforgiving post-apocalyptic world to its deep gameplay mechanics, Kenshi stands as a testament to the brilliance of indie game development.

One of the most remarkable aspects of Kenshi is its immense open world. Set in a harsh, desolate wasteland, the game allows players to forge their own path and make their mark on a ruthless, dynamic environment. Whether you choose to be a nomadic trader, a warlord conquering territories, or a humble farmer trying to survive, Kenshi provides the freedom to pursue your ambitions with minimal handholding.

The level of detail and realism in Kenshi is astonishing. Every character, from the protagonist to the lowliest bandit, has their own agenda and goals. The world is alive and ever-changing, with factions waging wars, economies fluctuating, and towns rising and falling. This dynamic nature ensures that no playthrough is the same, fostering a sense of immersion that is hard to find elsewhere.

The gameplay mechanics in Kenshi are both deep and challenging. As you start with nothing but your wits, you must gather resources, recruit followers, and train them to survive the harsh realities of the wasteland. The crafting system is intricate, allowing you to build anything from small shacks to sprawling fortresses. Combat is unforgiving and realistic, requiring tactical decision-making and skill development to prevail. The learning curve can be steep, but the satisfaction that comes with mastering these mechanics is immensely rewarding.

Graphically, Kenshi possesses a unique aesthetic that perfectly complements its gritty and desolate atmosphere. While the visuals may not rival those of AAA titles, the game's art style and attention to detail make it an aesthetic treat. Furthermore, the soundtrack sets the tone masterfully, enhancing the feeling of isolation and constant danger.

One of the greatest strengths of Kenshi is its dedicated and passionate modding community. With an active modding scene, players can customize their experience to suit their preferences. From quality of life improvements to extensive content additions, the modding community has expanded the already vast world of Kenshi, ensuring countless hours of gameplay.

In conclusion, Kenshi is a true gem in the gaming world. It pushes boundaries, challenges conventions, and rewards players with a unique and unforgettable experience. Whether you are a fan of open-world RPGs, survival games, or simply crave a game that allows you to create your own narrative, Kenshi is an absolute must-play. With its limitless freedom, deep gameplay mechanics, and ever-evolving world, Kenshi sets the bar high for the potential of indie game development.

It was just me and my dog, roaming the wastelands. We were the dynamic duo, until we weren't. Some ragged bandits came and beat me unconscious and killed my dog, the future looked bleak for my first run until some slave traders came about my body and patched me up, but mercy wasn't their intentions. They took me back and sold me off, but I was able to break free with some fellow slaves. It was just us out in the lands, and so we started a humble farm, but I had a deadset goal to stomp out all bits of slavery in this world. One thing led to another, and we started selling rum. One thing led to another and we started hiring people. One thing led to another and we started hiring mercs. One thing led to another and we soon realized that if we wanted an army, we needed it to be of soldiers. One thing led to another and we started sending mercs out to knock out wanderers and drag them back to the farm. The farm grew into a city, but it needed defenders. One thing led to another and we started practicing our combat skills on the prisoners we captured, beating them unconscious before sending out the medics to fix them up and throw them back into their cages, waiting for the next round. 
 
I still want to end slavery, but I'm starting to think the lengths I'm taking to abolish it are arguably worse than the enslavement itself. This is for you, old pupper.

For a single-player RPG game, Kenshi is the best! Absolute hours worth of replay-ability as you can do anything as you wish, like being a wandering trader, drug smuggler, slave liberator, or even waging a crusade against The Holy Nation or The Empire. Aside from its clunky graphics and buggy-ness, the dev actually delivers (I learned that this game literally made by one man!). One aspect I like about Kenshi that failure is the best teacher. For example, your characters will level up their toughness stat from getting beaten up by enemies, bonus point if the enemy is stronger than them. So don't fret if you find your characters got their ass whooped and brought to slavery on day one, as this is the way Kenshi is intended to be played. You can always grind your way out by continuously try to pick-lock the cage key and make escape from the slave camp. With enough training, someday you can even avenge your captors and free all their slaves.

I want to like the game. I REALLY do. But unfortunately, this is one of the least user friendly games I've ever played. It controls like a CIV game, which I like, but everything else is not user friendly at all. Now I'm no stranger to hard/obtuse games. But this game is just...wow. I drop in as the wanted outlaw. I have some legendary sword that has few rivals. Cool. Guess what...I barely managed to beat a little pig. Then out of nowhere, a holy knight comes after me in the middle of the desert and wipes me out. Legendary sword my ass.

I knew full well going into this game that you have to build yourself up. I get that. I like it when games start you out as a weakling, but only when it's well balanced. There's a BIG difference between starting off as a weakling that can 1v1 enemies in starting areas, vs starting off as a weakling that can barely handle a small pig. We call that bad balance.

I want to like this game. I REALLY do. But the clunk + enemies just slaughtering you and it being extremely difficult to build yourself up is a joke. And just because "you" who has 1000+ hours says it's "easy", doesn't mean it's easy for someone starting out with the game after being used to games with decent to good balance. The squad system hooked me in, but the clunky design and unforgiving start cut the line. 

If you like this game, good for you. I'm happy that you got around the aids that is the beginning. It's a no from me. If you started out with a squad/were a little bit stronger/enemies were a bit weaker, then maybe I'd still be playing. And I'm sure there are paths that allow you to start with a squad instantly, and I know you can lower the difficulty sliders, but A) that defeats the purpose of playing a game for me, and B) if I have to lower the difficulty that much off the bat, I don't think your game is well balanced. I'm not a Dark Souls cringelord, but I'm not a mobile gamer either.

The graphics and UI are the highlights for me, as well as that squad system, but if there's a bad smell in the air, I can't enjoy them. It's a no for me. Go ahead and clown me. Waste your points.

You don't have to build a settlement. there's plenty of other ways to earn money and you can steal and buy everything you need. the settlement building is fine if you want it, but isn't forced.

The modding support through steam workshop is a nice bonus that allows you to change your game or just beef up the graphics.

Ultimately if you like sandbox rpgs that truly let you do as you please. Kenshi is a challenging and rewarding experience that I would highly recommend.

I bought this game not really sure what to expect, and I certainly did not expect to get as into it as I did.

Firstly, this game is not for people who like winning, and cannot handle losing  or parting with something they spent hours or days obtaining. This game is quite literally about struggling to survive. Chance of survival is extremely slim, especially for your first 5-10 characters. I am just finally getting to around 25-26 days on the same character, but many characters I made a new one within minutes or a couple hours in.

To truly enjoy this game, you have to realize you are supposed to be attacked or targeted by d*ckheads practically all the time and you will lose your stuff very often. This game will punish you every step of the way for making either the right or wrong decision and you have to not get mad at it.

In my opinion, this game is both stressful and beautiful in it's own ways. Something about the depressing nature of practically everything in the environment, the music, and even down to the morrowind-esque [i](?)[/i] graphics, adds to the hopeless and constantly foreboding feeling you have while playing. With that said, you will have key moments where things just work out in your favor, and those moments make the game so entirely worth it. 

Also, the fact this game is just one big single-player PvE experience is a huge plus. Not having to worry about PVP or other annoying players makes the game so much more immersive and an individual experience (invite-only/2-4 player co-op would be nice though I do have to say).

Definitely worth it on sale and I would argue this game is also worth it full price.

First time playing, it is exactly what all the hype makes it out to be: BRUTAL. Never thought that I had a hope in Rebirth Hell of ever getting anywhere past being murdered, eaten, eviscerated or (less dramatically) starving to death. However, after a bit of persistent grinding, trial and error, and more luck than autosaves can procure, I managed to establish myself enough to appreciate the rather dismal but opportunity rich world around me.

Kenshi can be explained and pitched as thus:
You're not special. You are neither "the hero" nor "the villain" of some prophetic story giving you some sense of guidance or purpose. You are just another mouth to feed trying to eek out some form of a pathetic excuse of a living in a world where not only no one cares, but the gods/developers themselves have thrown to the deep end without so much as a by your leave. It is hard, but if you're resourceful, patient, quick, and know where your F1 key is,, then perhaps you may just find yourself enough experience.... to know what you did wrong before you died and start another save where you do it a little bit differently

Kenshi offers you an RPG experience like no other, the beginning, goals, ending are solely based on what you want to accomplish, you can be the bad guy, the good guy, a thief, a peasant. You can disguise yourself as an enemy faction to infiltrate them and loot their belongings.

The stats to this game are in depth as well, you start out as basically nothing, you are nothing to no one, when you die the world simply just goes on. You can't even really fight someone one on one and expect to win or live until you've leveled up your skills and attributes. The progression feels rewarding as you slowly build up your squad and abilities, building your own fortress / cities to become even stronger, fending off raids become more gratifying as you get to steal their loot too, or conducting them on nearby towers.

The mods are practically endless, and very easy to install / uninstall due to compatibility with the steam workshop.

If you like a unique RPG experience, there's genuinely no other game quite like this, the lore as well is pretty deep. After you get through the sluggish process of learning how the game works and how to really play, Kenshi is a game you'd easily sink hundreds of hours into.

Kenshi is the sort of game i can lose myself in. It's clunky, it's held together by pure will force an feels the like, it's got outdated graphics... and non of it matters. It is one of the only sandbox RPGs that really FEEL like a Sandbox. I have had runs where i role-played, i have had runs where i build a mighty base, i have had runs where i played a small group of adventurers that explored ruins and sold the contents while they slowly became stat-gods. It's the freedom that makes this game special. There is a huge Modding scene and with most games of this sort (think Rimworld), Mods bring a whole new layer of depth and customization to the game. So yes, i highly recommend this game. It's worth looking past the chunkiness, for beyond there lies greatness.
It has been 12 hours on my first go, and I am beginning to understand the love for this game.

This game is freaking dangerous! Went into it completely blind and ended up pulling many "all nighters". Sure the graphics are a bit dated, but the utter amount of things you can do in this game is crazy. You will die a lot,  you will be confused, it will kick your ass in almost every possible way if you let it, but that's the pull of the game. You make your own stories from wandering the desert, to getting revenge on the cannibals that ate your favorite squad member. When you get that one character finally doing something bad ass, its so satisfying!
    You can craft, raid, steal, trade, build a settlement and even an army. There's even snippets of lore characters share when they interact which is nice. Just pick a direction and go! Kenshi,  is the ultimate sandbox RPG. Also the modding community for this game is pretty kick ass! SERIOUSLY can't wait for Kenshi 2!!

This game is truly a sandbox experience, you can be a drug trader that makes millions, a wandering swordsman, or a relic hunter.
The experience of learning kenshi will teach you that the world is unforgiving to even the smallest mistakes, which makes it so that you know you truly earned everything you obtained.
Every level up is important, including hidden stats like crowd combat.
When, or i should say if you make it to the point where you can 1v5 it's a very satisfying experience, but getting there is like trudging through mud in flip flops.
A beautiful world, interesting story that isn't told directly, but by listening to the rare dialogue from townspeople and NPCs, and best of all is the music which is incredibly atmospheric and captivating.

Can be a lot of fun if you set your own goals, especially with mods.
I can't however in good conscience say this game is complete. it feels like a sandbox but half of it is gravel and/or bedrock. Being able to mod in a pickaxe does remedy it somewhat, but I don't think it should fall on modders to fix the game nor me to find the fixes. Bethesda design practices are not something to be admired, in my opinion.

This game comes very close to being possibly one of the best games ever made. I strongly recommend everyone who intends to play this game to download mods because there are mods that basically fix most problems as well as rework mechanics and add a lot of content. Nevertheless the base game is what’s being discussed in this case mostly, first of all one of the most annoying problems is that this game has a lot of grinding, whether it is walking from A to B or improving stats or producing stuff it undeniably wastes too much of your time. Another problem is that despite being supposedly finished it still lacks a lot of polish and it’s not just bugs like pathfinding breaks constantly, there’s a lot of crashing and loading problems, also very strange balancing decisions. Lastly, as far as problems go I feel like the game also lacks a decent amount of content, but it’s also sort of spread out and thus most people don’t notice it, for example there are really few animations for the various actions and attacks you have, there’s too few character customization options, there’s too little interactions with commerce and with factions, most of the wildlife is just beak things, some areas like the cannibal plains don’t have much going on in general. Despite all of those problems the game is still great, of note is the whole world of Kenshi both the map and the lore, it’s all both very alien and familiar at the same time, it has a lot of interesting characters, events and places all with unique terrain. The combat is also great and distinct from most games, it both adds to the immersion and the limb system adds a whole layer of strategy to fights, it also helps display the strength of enemies and animals. It’s also important to discuss the difficulty, the game is very hard and sometimes unfair, but still the greatest advantage one can have in Kenshi is knowledge of the game, learning the mechanics and the world is the most important thing when it comes to overcoming the difficulty and therefore the game rewards planning and exploration. The base building, though not mandatory, is very much worth trying and grants access to many items. It's very cool to be able to essentially create your own town that can be equal to or even greater than all the other cities in the game. There’s still a lot more but I think I’ve said enough, Kenshi is an amazing game with a lot to offer, and those that stuck with it know why it’s so addictive.

One of the most impressive sandbox simulation games I've ever had the pleasure to play. Kenshi strikes the perfect balance between passive simulation and active strategy in that the game world can exist and operate without any intervention from the player but should the player choose to engage, they can discover how in-depth the game can get.

The setting, atmosphere, characters, world governments/tribes, and interactions are like if Feudal Japan had an illegitimate child with The Holy Roman Empire and left the child to grow up on an alien planet reminiscent of Pre-Christ Mesopotamia. Yeah, it's crazy and I love it. It's difficult to put into writing what makes Kenshi stand out among other battle simulation sandboxes so I highly recommend checking the game out for yourself if any of this is piquing your curiosity.

A few stand-out features:

- limb-based combat with the ability to bleed out, go unconscious based on what body part is injured, and the chance to lose a limb altogether with the opportunity to replace it with a prosthetic
- town-building system that ties in with you being able to establish your own tribe
- what race and affiliation you choose to play as will determine how others treat you
- stats that increase based on how often you use the associated skills (think Skyrim's skill leveling system)
- stealth mechanics that are meh but serviceable, can't fault the game too much here as it isn't an explicitly highlight feature, I just chose to mention it
- cannibalism!

I highly recommend Kenshi to anyone who is familiar with simulation games, strategy games, or role-playing games and is looking for something totally different to get immersed in.

10/10

There's something special about Kenshi, a bit of old school nostalgia with a lot of freedom to play how you want.  As a sandbox game this has one of the better executions.  Rough around the edges with visuals, but all in all a great experience.

You start as a nobody (or a starving, one armed nobody in the middle of a desert full of slavers if you like the challenge), you have no skills and barely have some rags to cover your ass, it's up to you to find purpose in this post-post apocalyptic world where almost everyone wants a piece of you.

You're not the chosen one and you're not stronger than anyone unless you climb the food chain by taking risks, losing fights, and training hard, and this reflects on your character starting looking like a holocaust victim but ending like a JoJo character as their journey toughens them up.

Also, ALL characters can die and the world won't stop because of it, you can be the one doing the killing and shaping the world of Kenshi to your liking, should you have the skill to fight an entire army and challenge the faction leaders, few things are as enjoyable as soloing the entire Holy Nation or United Cities, watching your character go on a rampage, punching off filthy slaver limbs into the stratosphere.

Oh and you can also build a town anywhere, though building in some places comes with risks of extortion, taxes and bandit raids.


Or maybe you don't want to do any of that and just live as a slave, merchant, thief, bandit or anything you want really.

I'm on medical leave today so it's probably the rare free time I have. And I thought "why not write a review for Kenshi"? I rarely write reviews but this warrants it. Why?

1. Production

I came across Kenshi on YouTube about how this game was largely coded by a single person. And how he had stuck to it for more than 8 years (I think it was 10 years in total) before getting the break he needed after suffering much in production hell. And the vision he stuck by "a sandbox RPG" is great. I came across a few players who told their own story on YouTube of their own Kenshi adventures. Now I am hooked.

2. Gameplay

This is a RTS game with RPG elements in a Survival Game genre. If Mad Max had a kid with Fallout 1/2 and genetically altered the kid with Dune, this would be it. The game can be "unfair" and "unforgiving" but it is shows the reality of the world that was build. 

RTS - Yes
RPG - Yes
Survival - Yes
Base Building - Yes
Souls Like Deaths - Yes
Mods - Yes

There's plenty of flexibility in the way you want to go about the game that it can be daunting. Just note that:

Graphics - Not Really Fantastic (But Mods Improves This Somewhat). But Charming.
Story - None. It's Up To Your Own RPG Narration (I Find Myself Talking Out Loud My Characters' Stories)
End Game - Not Really. It Is Really Up To You To Define Your End Game
Glitches - Some Clipping. Some Restarting. Some Bodies Flying From Time To Time.

Thanks Christ Hunt for this game. You've taken so much time to make this game a reality. Now it has taken so much time from my real life... and counting! And I enjoy every moment of it. I hope big companies learn a thing or two about the fun and depth of a game. Not everything is about the graphics. Kudos to Kenshi!

Kenshi is a wonderful game that strives to reach the pinnacle of what gaming is: the creation of a new world to live in. Despite many wonderful story driven titles, games will always be second rate mediums for storytelling, behind books, movies and television. Kenshi excels at what games are meant to do by building an immersive, unique world rich in lore and full of character. Character progression is a strength, with no class and the possibility of maxing all stats and skills. Gameplay is an RTS/RPG hybrid that works very well. The base-building offers freedom and creativity rarely seen in games today. This is an indie title, so there are some issues with jank, balance and graphics. Some factions and areas seem unfinished or not fully explored. Some may be left that way to keep a sense of mystery. These issues don't detract much from the experience. On the contrary, comparing Kenshi to the unfinished AAA messes that have released recently leaves me increasingly jaded with the current state of an industry that seems interested only in extracting as much money from their playerbase as possible. 

In Kenshi, you are nobody special. Emergent gameplay is core to the Kenshi experience. Get robbed by a group of bandits, then saved from death only to be enslaved and set to work in a mine. Toil away, building strength and toughness, until you escape. Run into those bandits again, and exact your revenge. Go to war with a major faction. Free slaves, spread the glory of Okran, or purge the world of their zealotry. Every setback is an opportunity to add another chapter to your story. So buy the game, and write your own. You won't regret it.
A unique and fun game worthy to be in the "all time best" category, along with Rimworld, Skyrim and ARK.

Kenshi is an absolute game-changer that reignited my passion for video games. It's a unique experience that swept me away into a vast and brutal world, where survival is the name of the game. The freedom it offers is mind-blowing—you can shape your own destiny, build a thriving empire, or simply become a wandering warrior. The depth of its gameplay mechanics and the intricate world-building had me hooked from the start. Kenshi challenged me in ways I hadn't experienced in years, pushing me to adapt, strategize, and overcome obstacles like never before. It's a true gem that reminded me of the incredible potential and limitless imagination that video games can offer. If you're looking for a game that will reignite your love for the medium, Kenshi is an absolute must-play.

Probably the best open sandbox game I've ever played. I've read reviews that claim you can be or do just about anything in this game, and they are absolutely correct. Want to be the lone ultimate bad ass? Sure. The best weapon smith on the planet? Cool. Open up a 5 star restaurant? Okay. Free hundreds of slaves and cause a mass revolt? Why not. Essentially the possibilities are almost limitless, and what can't be done with the base game can likely be done with mods. Easily worth $30, getting it for anything less is steal.

BE WARNED!

This game is not for people that need to have their hand held. This is a true open world sandbox game. You're not going to be told what to do, when to do it or how to do it. It's ALL up to you and you alone. Don't buy this game if you lack any kind of initiative and need some sort of rail to guide you through a game cause this ain't it.

This is a difficult game to recommend. There's a lot of potential here, but you have to put in a great deal of effort to make any meaningful progress. Needlessly complex systems are either poorly explained or not explained at all. The world is very large and there are plenty of interesting locations to discover if you can survive long enough to see it. 
Most of the fun in Kenshi comes from barely surviving combat encounters, limping back to camp, and seeing your character slowly grow stronger until you can stake your claim in the desert and build a settlement of your own. There's not much in the way of story and the lore is sparse and vague. It's very much a sandbox (literally) for you to make your own story. If that seems compelling enough give it a try. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Kenshi is an absolute blast! The moment I discovered that the safest way to toughen up my characters was to abduct unsuspecting travelers, lock them up, and unleash some serious whoop-ass on them (don't try this at home, folks), It's like a twisted fitness program for my virtual warriors. But hey, survival is no joke in Kenshi. With a success rate that makes winning the lottery seem like a cakewalk, you'll quickly realize that you're just as feeble and inexperienced as you are in real life. And trust me, in Kenshi, the threats are as real as they get. Flesh-eating spiders, desperate hobos, and who knows what else? It's a dangerous world out there. But amidst the chaos, there's a strange sense of satisfaction in overcoming the odds, even if it means ending up being sold as a slave. Kenshi, you've earned yourself a well-deserved 10 out of 10 for delivering a gaming experience that's both hilarious and unforgettable.

What a weird and wonderful game!

It's hard! It's so goddamn hard! But it's so much fun...

There's really only one goal: survive. But after you figure out how to feed yourself and not bleed to death after every fight (and there are so many ways to go about doing this), it's time to make your own goals. Become a merchant, become a bandit lord, become a cannibal hunter, build a small town, destroy a small town, destroy the existing factions, explore the depths of the ancient ruins and figure out the big questions about the world everyone's too busy trying to survive to answer.

You are not special, you are not inherently important. But who you become? That's all up to you.

Before it is anything else, Kenshi is a survival game. Strong RPG elements, action, squad management--all these things are there, but for 90% of the game, you will struggle to survive. Even on the easiest difficulty, you will start the game as nothing but an easy target for roaming bandits. You will hit insurmountable obstacles. You will be afraid of going beyond the safety of a town's walls. But, if you stick with it, you will hit a point where everything clicks. 

All the trials you've faced and overcome, all the walls you hit, all the times you felt the mercilessness of Kenshi's world... It forges you--and your characters--into a creature that thinks like a survivor and a scavenger, and eventually, something much more. Perhaps a noble samurai setting out to punish the many evils of the world; perhaps a warlord set on creating a drug empire. Perhaps a ninja, or an explorer, or a bandit. But once you've learned how to survive in Kenshi, the game world opens up to you, and it becomes a game of wonder, opportunity, and curiosity. 

Kenshi has jank. Kenshi is occasionally hard to look at. Kenshi feels a little dated. And there is no experience like Kenshi. If you like survival games, RPGs, and sandbox games, there's something here for you that you won't find anywhere else.
