Admittedly, I’ve lately been struggling to find a game that fully captivates my attention. Luckily, this all changed with an impulse buy - Kenshi - during the Steam Winter Sale. 

Kenshi was made by Lo-Fi Games for PC and is their only product to date, although Kenshi 2 is confirmed to be on the horizon. It was released into Early Access in 2013 and then as a finished game in 2018. It was also, to my understanding, largely the effort of one person. Kenshi roughly translates to swordsman in English, but at the start your character will likely be either a punching bag or food. Yes, food… 

Somehow Kenshi has achieved being a rather inspired blend of a single player Runescape and Fallout (no, not the modern ones: I mean, 1, 2, and Tactics). 

Perhaps the true beauty of Kenshi is that it is an open Sandbox. There is no main quest, side quests, essential characters or overarching plot to follow; no no no, just like every day life, you are stuck on a rock with what skills you have and make the best of it… Or you can do what I did, and make things worse for everyone else! Of course, that’s not to say there isn’t a history. There is, should you choose to seek it out. There are some characters, books, and even environments that will enlighten you as to what came before.  

There are also optional house building mechanics where you can build up your own base, trade hub, or even city. Furthermore, you have crafting which allows you to make your own clothes, armor, weapons, and food. To try to give you some idea of how expansive your options in this game are, I’m going to list all of the skills that I can think of off the top of my head without looking them up: Weapons, Athletics, Swimming, Cooking, Engineering, Armorworking, Weapon Smithing, Science, Assassination, Stealth, Robotics, Lockpicking, and Thievery. To further illustrate, you know the Weapons skill I just mentioned? That’s not a single skill, it’s actually 8 or 9, I couldn’t remember them all without looking them up. 

On the weapon side of things you’ve got: Polearms, Bare Fists, Katanas, Sabres, Giant Cleavers, Crossbows, Turrets, and more. By the way, if your strength is high enough, it is entirely possible to punch someone’s arm off… It’s… pretty crazy. 

There’s a multitude of stats that affect how good your character (or characters, should you decide to recruit/travel with others) is at combat; there are a few hidden ones too like what species you choose for them. That said, like I stated earlier, you will start the game out weak - regular goats will give you trouble. Somewhat ironically, getting beaten to a pulp - which will increase your toughness stat, should you survive - will make you stronger and more effective at combat. You level up your stats by doing them over and over, although there are some caveats to what works and when. 

The combat is really simple, your character handles all of it theirself; no abilities, specials, or anything like that. All you can do is click on who you want them to attack or click away from them to have them flee while praying that they don’t get cut down in the process.

The health system in Kenshi is REALLY interesting. Each extremity has its own health bar and when a certain threshold is reached your character will go unconscious (it’s different for each species). The best thing about this, and I won’t let anyone convince me otherwise, is that it is possible to lose limbs from combat or lack of treatment. Fortunately, it’s possible to get robotic replacement parts should you be skilled enough to buy, steal, or make them! 

Also worth mentioning is the inclusion of  a blood/oil (depending on if you are a robot - err, sorry, the game calls them Skeletons) and a hunger bar, so it’s entirely possible to bleed out or starve to death as well. I’m going to be real with you, when I saw that there was a hunger bar, I was worried this was going to be The Sims in the desert, where I’d constantly have to stop what I was doing and search for food, but as luck would have it you can actually change how frequently your character or characters get hungry at the start of the game. 

Although cruel, Kenshi is generous in the aspects that matter. You can tinker with a lot of settings at the start of the game, like the aforementioned hunger frequency, you can also change the frequency of dismemberments, enemy base spawn rates, squad size, global population, death chance, and things to do with towns you might build like their raid frequency.           

You are also provided with a large list of starting states during character creation. These don’t lock you into any one playstyle, but can make for an interesting intro or help you get started toward something you are hoping to achieve with the character. For example, you can start out surrounded by hostile cannibals, traveling in a group, traveling with a dog, or as a slave; just to name a few. 

I’ve had a lot of harrowing and funny moments with Kenshi. I think the one that stuck out the most to me was a time where Stork was traveling through cannibal territory and after knocking out and mortally wounding tons of malnourished cannibals, he was knocked out by a cheap shot, but luckily his vitals were fine and he was going to make a full recovery… or so I thought. You know what that remaining cannibal did? He picked up my unconscious character and started carrying him back to his camp to eat him. By complete happenstance, a traveling nomad saw and killed the cannibal; thus granting Stork another day at life. 
   
So yeah, Kenshi is a lot. It’s ultimately what you choose to make of it and how you decide to play. There’s also an active and very healthy modding community whose mods are easily accessible through the Steam workshop. 

My praises having been sung, there are a couple of things to be aware of. Firstly, while you can interact with every single character/creature/whatever in the game, it is important to note that you cannot talk to every single one. I’d say that dialogue is limited to a select few characters in each area; somewhere between the 10’s and 20’s, but I wouldn’t necessarily consider that a negative. It just means that the characters that can be conversed with tend to have something of actual substance to say or some sort of purpose behind their words, whether that is segueing into selling you something, being recruited, checking you for illegal goods, or something else.  

The other thing probably goes without saying as to the open-ended nature of the game, but it can be buggy at points. I haven’t run into anything gameplay ending or egregious yet, but I did end up having to leave behind a companion because he got stuck operating a turret and wouldn’t get off it. Granted, I could have reloaded an older save, but his stats were garbage and overall I didn’t deem him worth the effort. There is another answer of sorts, game importing! 

Game Importing was made as both a work around for bugs and a new game plus of sorts (should you check the right options). Importing keeps all of your characters, gear, and stats, while also giving you a wide range of optional things to import like: research, buildings you’ve made, major NPCs statuses as alive or deceased, and relationships with factions. 

For a game that I’ve seen go on sale pretty frequently for around $15 and having managed to dump 30 hours into whilst barely scratching the surface; I’d say the Kenshi was definitely worth it and I am looking forward to diving further into it after I clear away some of my backlog.

Reminds me of the X series, where you can seemingly do anything. The problem with many sandbox games is they have no story, the foundational lore is boring and there's no world building and development beyond what the sandbox experience can offer, and the bugs are usually insurmountable because the amount of work to make a game that defies genres is extraordinary. This game achieves all of these negatives in spades. 

My constructive criticism to this developer would be to look at how the X series has developed their mechanics and more importantly how they have woven the lore, hand crafted missions, and world altering decisions into the sandbox experience. X4 is easily the most refined sandbox game I've ever played, and with that in mind I can see this game's potential.

Kenshi was like a dream game come true - over time.
I bought Kenshi at the beginning of it's long development. The world was small and everyone had weird hair.
I would play it for a while, deinstall. Waited half a year. Check it out again.
It took a long time, but now Kenshi is one of those games that never leave my SSD. 
Excellent gameworld, even more excellent mods to tweak it in the way you want it and literally endless possibilities to play you character(s).
The "grind" in the beginning can be a little hard, but if you are like me, you don't perceive it as such.
I have build sprawling cities, merchant caravans, assassin guilds, played lonely wanderers, relgious fanatics and brutal bounty hunters. 
Kenshi is a game that requires time, but if you can invest that time, you'll be rewarded. (And will also die horribly in the beginning,)

Want to make your game brutally difficult and unforgiving? Cool. Want to make a big open world where players set their own goals and make their own fun? Great! I can get behind those ideas! But make sure you design it well, and don't waste my time. For example, the game (for some reason) makes a big deal out of weapons having indoor and outdoor bonuses or penalties. And the game gives you 2 weapon slots per character! Great! But there's actually no button assigned to switching between Weapon I and Weapon II. Also, only a few specific kinds of backpacks will let you stack items. Also, there's no kind of fast travel in the game, not even an in-game lore friendly transit system like the silt striders in Morrowind. Those are just some examples, I don't want to make this review too long. Just know I had a lot of "What were they thinking?!" moments while playing this game. I can definitely see how some people have thousands of hours in this game. It teases you in just the right way, makes you think "okay once I get some decent gear, I'll be able to have fun," or "okay maybe once I get a good squad going, then I'll be able to do more and have fun," or "okay, maybe once I do a few bounties, that will make the game worth it," or "okay once I explore that corner of the map, maybe I'll run into something cool there"...or the big one "okay, once I make my own outpost/city, THEN that will make all of this worth it." But no. You were tricked. The fun was a mirage. There was only janky open world survival crafting with brief moments of inspiration. But hey get hyped for the sequel!

Absolutely amazing game, I bought it with doubts about how good it would be, but those were quickly squashed.
Took me a while to get my head around it being a squad game. I am so used to playing RPG and this seems very RPG like I found it confusing. 
Once I realised that I was not playing my toon but playing god, it all came clear.
The immersion is great, no quests, no story line, and the tutorial is just an smart help popup. It is just you against a very harsh world. 
Takes a bit of cunning and a little thought, but you can easily make enough to buy food, get that city condo or join the local thieves guild if you fancy.
Or go for a scenic tour, get a drink and some snacks (IRF) hitch a ride on a trader and have a safari. you can pick up some trinkets along the way too.

I highly recommend this game, but get a clock near by, It is addictive, and time quickly passes.

This is one of the true greats.    It's genre defying and defining.  It's a challenge on many levels and both gratifying and satisfies many different itches.  I cannot recommend it strongly enough.

it took a moment for me to get into the graphics, but now i kinda like them a lot, buggy as they are. the landscape is beautiful and everything is very gritty. i like that. i've been playing with many mods, however, and i hardly remember the vanilla game, so my review is based on playing with a crapton of mods. 

the game itself is difficult. unless you cheese the settings or use mods to make life easier, you're gunna get rolled. probably immediately. the learning curve is a bit steep because there's no hand holding or telling the player what to do and how to do it. there's no real tutorial other than some help text about certain things but, honestly, it's not the most helpful. (to me anyway). for example, there's a tip about playing dead, but it doesn't tell you how to play dead, it just says what happens if you get up from playing dead and enemies are still around. not helpful. so i did end up looking a lot of stuff up online. thankfully, there's a decently sized community full of very helpful people. 

once you get into the game it can be a lot of fun, especially if you enjoy challenge. everything i accomplished felt really good. building my own base and group up was slow, but satisfying. i did get messed up many times and had to recover over and over, but the setback wasn't anything i couldn't handle... there's settings when you start about NPCs looting you, limb loss chance, death chance, how hard everything hits, heal rate, etc. i don't mind recovery.... but i'm sure a lot of people find it very annoying to spend so much time in this game near the start injured and unable to kill anything.

My Name is Hal and this is my story.
I'd like to tell you all a tale of a great man, a man named Sand Ninja Johunn.
My Life began in the great dessert I had been wandering for many moons my arm missing and I had not eaten in days.
Slavers came to me, the Manhunters. They beat me and took me to the great United Cited in the dessert or they tried to that is. Enter Sand Ninja Johunn The greatest man who had ever lived This man comes barreling over the dunes just outside the city gates blade in hand he alone cuts down every Manhunter with ease never even being touched himself. In the battle I break out of my binds and loot a Manhunter and assist Johunn after the battle we are stormed by United City Samurai. They arrest me for being poor and enslave me yet again into a cell I go with no arm and broken legs, there I sit for 3 days never being fed, healing of nothing but sheer will. When I feel better I begin to pick my cell door after days of trying Im out in the cell down the hall I spy Johunn also arrested I break him out honoring my debt to the great Johunn. Johunn is enraged he alone unarmed butcher every samurai in the prison. I follow him into the streets we make it to the gates we stopped by Samurai, I run. Johunn fights alone fighting ten men at once and winning after making short work of the last of soldiers he joins me as he runnings towards the open dessert I hear a loud crack I watch a harpoon tear through Johunn I run to him I and we soon are captured yet again. Back in the cells I am next Johunn the Samurai made an example of the man and cut every limb from his body. I stayed with him in his death throws as we slowly rotted in the slave pits Johunn dies and several days pass. One day the Samurai are very few in the city I take Johunns gear hidden as a sand ninja I escape slavery and flee to Worlds End, Johann even in death has freed me. I live my life to be as great as Johunn I became one the strongest men in the lands hunting slavers and freeing those like me In the memory of The Great Johunn but one day a day like every other day the world changed forever people starting going missing soon everyone was gone the whole world filled with animals and the odd survivor. It was nice at first I lived like a king in The holy city but soon I wished for death, alone and unchallanged I knew, I knew I would never die I death like Johunn's and so I walked into the great dessert once more seeking death and I found it the city I was from many years ago still bustling with life and slavers I walked into the city dressed as My old friend Johunn the ghost of the sands had returned for days I fought, freeing slaves and killing samurai and manhunters. I soon came to my wounds I was arrested they butchered my like they did Johunn I remember being thrown into a cell as I lay dying I saw something and seconds before death the world made sense for once. I saw a young man just as I was broken, limbless and weak. In this moment I had many questions but only seconds of life left I resigned my confusion and smiled at the young man in the cell and told him he will have a great journey ahead of him and to never stop surviving. I died happy that I lived and died as my hero had.

This is a game that tells a story through emergent game play. If that is a thing you are interested in then this is one of the best examples I have ever played. There is world lore, it is good and interesting and leaves as many questions as it answers but really your story will be your story. 

It will kick you when you are down and it will knock you down often. If you come in blind it won't be an easy start. That may be a negative for some so it's important to say, but the game for the most part isn't hard to learn so much as there is just a hell of a lot of game to learn and the good thing is that there is a pretty well updated and detailed wiki for when you just don't know how to do X. I have also found it auto saves very often so on the few occasions I have outright died, I found even if I had forgotten to recently save I didn't loose very much if anything. What's more if you are the type of player who really likes to get deep into the numbers, come up with crazy ideas and try to execute them, then this game can scratch that "what if" itch in a very satisfying way. What's even better is that if you aren't that type of player, and you really just want to progress with out getting too bogged down into the details, it is absolutely playable from start to "finish" (as far as I can tell there is no hard finish, you just finish when you feel it's the end of the story you are playing) with that approach as well.

I can't compare it to anything else since I've never played any game like it. Out of the games I have played I guess Rimworld is the closest match and if you enjoy that game it is likely this is worth a look, but even then, it's very different as an overall package.

In terms of the major faults. Whilst I appreciate the graphic design, the graphic fidelity is pretty poor even for it's release of 2018 let alone today in 2023. It's also a bit grindy at times although some of that likely comes down to approach and caution. My final complaint is that it will crash, maybe eventually or maybe often depending on your luck but I have crashed a couple of times in my time played so far and I know from checking online this is normal, if anything I have been a bit lucky. The game is good at auto saving so significant progress is rarely lost although a crash at the wrong moment could be pretty annoying.

Started off as a nobody, getting beaten the shit out of everywhere I went. This strange thoughness stat kept getting higher and higher. New friends needed...

I continue the path to explore the map, me and the three friends that survived all my foolishness. Little did they know, they were the start of what I have now, the elite squad in my most dear game of Kenshi.

This is not a standard RPG that forces you to follow a certain story. It's also not a game that you can pick up quickly and expect to have a good time. This game doesn't care about you or your time/family/friends/job but once you reach the point where you have a squad of highly skilled fighters that can literally punch the arms and legs off of their enemies then you'll earn the respect of your estranged family/divorced wife/boss who fired you. Or you can just mod the crap out of if it and skip the grinding all together. It's an enchanting sandbox game where there's always something new to find and it's a flawless masterpiece without any bugs or crashes.

This is not a game you play for the graphics... or the combat... or a predetermined story...
This is one of the most unique games I've ever played where you're plopped into the middle of a world that is doing just fine without you, and you are no bigger, better, or stronger than anybody else. 

It's up to you to figure out how to survive this truly merciless world. The game doesn't even END when you die. The world keeps going for as long as you watch the screen, going about its business the same as it was before you spawned into it.

You as the player character are very much a simple meaningless person in the chaos of this post apocalyptic world. Literally every person's experience in playing this game is its own unique story, full of hardship, victory, loss, defeat, starvation, desperation, and just trying to survive one more day despite so many odds against you. I'm not being hyperbolic, this is a MUST play game. Everyone needs to experience it at least once.
You will never realize how much time you have spent on the game in one sitting.

Old School kind of game. No loot boxes(bane of my existence), no additional content for the game itself at all. This game is extremely well done. Graphics are sort of current but also dragon age vibes from older editions of the game, from older open world rpgs, from before the dark times of dlc and such.

 Very good survival game with an open world you can explore. You will die a lot but it is rewarding when you succeed. Save often. Even the 'easy' scenario you will die a lot. I actually found 'wanderer' was the easiest for me so the challenge of keeping multiple characters alive turned out to be my middle ground. Try out different scenarios to find what works for you and your play style would be my recommendation. 

This game really highlights what people can do when they aren't too stuffed up there own ass-holes, like the supposedly 'AAA devolpers'. This game deserves so many awards they'd have to pay to received just to claim to be 'aaa'. 

While this game does not have a linear story there is enough story bits you can find and enough to explore you kinda just make a story as you go while finding out about the world you have been dropped into. 

I am new to this game, after finding out about it from a video that dropped into my feed one day, but after a little bit playing with it(instead of reading instructions lol), I find it is a vast world but you cannot just traipse across the map without great care both before and during doing so, which itself makes it feel more like a world that could exist. The post apocalyptic aspects you find places... such as the boats by the deadlands coming from a certain direction is just another indication. So far nobody acknowledges that it happened but the signs are everywhere and people just kinda live on top of it. You can buy a place in a city or town and have a place there and you can make your own settlement, but anything you build can be destroyed. So far there is more security in the already secured settlements but... not always. You can be attacked basically anywhere. 

I cannot overstate what a joy(and a frustration at times) this game has been the past few days. It is truly amazing. If you aren't careful it will suck you into it, because while there is no linear storyline for you, as the player to follow, there is enough lore and npcs to discover and settlements to wonder about, to find yourself engrossed in the stories they tell and in wondering if there is a way to find what happened and why the world has those ruins in game? You make your own story but the world is also rich with enough story to make that plausible. It's by no means a blank slate, which is the mistake those supposedly 'triple a' game developers would do trying to copy this if they did(the fact they have done dirty to games before doing things like that means at some point it will probably be attempted but it would be too bland with too little love put into it).  

You must always be conscious of threats. From wildlife, from other humans(mostly from other humans and humanoids actually but... some of the creatures in this game will f you up too- most of them- okay all of them that won't peacefully walk by actually so far have killed me at least once). You won't be able to fight everything. Your athletics skill will help you greatly- you will have to run away from many threats you cannot fight. The leveled lists aren't here to hold your hand in this game. I like this very much. It is quite challenging and it feels like a world that could exist.

This is one of the jankiest, most unpolished, frustrating and anti-quality of life games I have ever played in my entire life. The AI consistently forgets to do what you tell it to and has the prioritization skills of a 3rd degree methhead. Controlling your character is less "control" and more "suggesting" they do something and the grind to level anything at all seems to be modeled after the kinds of MMO's people beg others to stay away from. 

The graphics look like if Runescape Classic added 12 more polygons, the world loads in chunks like unfitting gears grinding against your sense of immersion. The systems are obtuse and confusing under the guise of 'difficulty' and the eye-blisteringly abrasive UI looks like Fallout 1 or 2 had a crack baby with popup ads from the early 00's. The tagline "There are no hero characters" is a straight up lie when facing down nation leaders or unique enemies with 85+ all skills and the sheer amount of running you'll end up doing should give this a "running simulator" tag before anything else. 

So WHY THE FUCK would I EVER recommend this game? Because although it's been one of the most absolutely fury inducing gaming experiences of my life that have ended in hurling more insults and inventing slurs that don't even really exist at my screen in pure rage... 

If I don't hunt down and imprison every last member of that Holy Nation so I can use the skin peeler mod on their self-righteous flesh I can never feel complete as a human being. Because despite all the vitriol I vomited up at the beginning of this, this is a one-in-a-million kind of unique game experience that comes together to make something unlike anything else I've ever played. It's an MMO made for one, a universe and game system that really truly doesn't give a shit whether you have fun. It's entirely unique to the palette in the most campy, terrible and frustrating yet wonderful, fulfilling and exciting ways possible. It's a game that is so bad it becomes good, so good it becomes bad. And it's this warbling between horrible and incredible that will probably keep me playing it well past CoD 2056 or Diablo 9 or whatever other lifeless corporate product arrives to try and convince you it's doing something unique and different. 

As much as I fucking hate this fucking game there is genuinely nothing else like it. Kenshi doesn't give a damn whether you love it or hate it. And that's the point, which is why I will keep hitting that play button until I rule the barren hellscape this game presents to me. And when I'm done, I'll hit it again.

What can I add to all the glowing reviews?      How about....

BLOODSPORT!  -The Kumite

 -  say it... say iiiit !!!   

This sandbox can do a lot!   After mastering the controls and gaining substantial wealth through shear luck, I had created a character that could not be seen, (stealth), could one shot kill, (sneak attack), and single-handedly brought down every gang leader or 'King'.  Well, brought them all down to...The KUMITE!  

Imagine waking up, from a slumber, a King with armies and weapons and gold. Now, in a daze from a blow to the head, you find yourself in a rusty old cage like a crabby old crab. (luvin' those crabbies btw)
An incredibly fit man with only  a rag covering his crotch, is opening your cage and passing some moldy bread to you. 
You find yourself starving, a feeling you've never had in your lifetime of dictatorship and cruelty.  As you consume your life giving tasteless block of carbs, your eyes drift to the other cages.  "My God!" you whisper under your breath...

The room you are in is a dimly, torch lit, arena...of death.  The stench of dried blood, human or otherwise, the crumbling pile of old weapons and armor discarded in the corner, where your eyes lock, there! your armor, and your sword!  If only you could reach...or sneak a chance at picking this rusty lock!   

A loud bang and your cage door is opened. A huge monster of a man is now dragging you out, your fingers curling around a rusty bar, resisting...futile.    The overhead lights flash on, blinding you, still coming out of a light coma. 
A new sound pounding in your head, a drum...beating...boom...boom...BOOM!   A roar of chaos from a crowd of dozens of cheering drunkards demanding your death by dismemberment for your crimes.  Then you notice the machine...its...spinning and grinding away the final remnant of a man, much like you, who found himself in a predicament that no man wants to awaken to. The only thing left now, is to wish for death to be swift. 

Dux, Frank Dux, walks calmly onto the platform, one way in, one way out. The gate is guarded by a fierce dog like creature. Winning this fight is the only option.  Dux comes closer to you, you're staggering to get up, a painful surge from your left leg displays a robotic limb!  Your leg is missing! Those bastards!  As you stand, the crowd boos.   Dux turns his back to engage the crowd's cheers for him, "Dux, Dux, Dux!.."  It's the last name you'll ever know.   

In a flash Dux side kicks your chest and you crumple.  The crowd ROARS!   "Kumite! Kumite!"  
You yell into the deafening silence, "You bastards!  You'll never get away with this!!!"  Dux's flying jump kick lands knocking you over, once again, yet this time, your right arm is now hanging by a thread.  Consciousness fading... the sounds of the mocking crowd grow silent...as the sound of a flesh flaying and bone grinding torture machine begins......

Yes, I created an entire Bloodsport arena for my crew to enjoy the rush of a fight to test their skills against the best of the best.  Thief, beggar, cripple, or King.  No one is spared, anyone can\will join, whether they want to or not.  The fun part, keeping them alive long enough to fully android them (or handicap) only to stake them out front of your base fort to attract the enemy trying to rescue them.   The only difference is that in my Kumite, there is no word for 'uncle' (Ma-te). 
Only death. 

Everything about this game will change the way you believe games can be made.  Besides the lack of voice, which you use your imagination for anyways, it seems as if what ever happens to you is REALLY up to you.  Yes, you run a lot. Yes, you need a crew, ultimately, and yes you will probably die the first few times you start. But you can do it. And that feeling of reward and dopamine drip is what you've been searching for all those late nights when you're realizing there's nothing good out and the best games came out before you were born, maybe.  Kenshi is amazing.  Mods or not, the vanilla product is an essential part of any gamer's list. It doesn't just change the way you believe games can be played, it changes the way your brain thinks about the rest of Life in general - Never accept that which is offered to you unless you know clearly the options you do have that are not offered. This...is life.

[h1]A flawed masterpiece[/h1]

Usually I don't like games without a set goal/goals and a curated narrative arc unless they are management sims or something similar. Kenshi breaks this mold. So far 71 hours in and several restarts later, I still feel like I've barely scratched the surface. Kenshi is unforgiving and you need to learn from your mistakes. With the default starting scenarios, you're normally worse than a farm hand at start. Screw up once and you'll quickly be a limb short and bleeding out on the desert sands and are actually happy when slavers passing by spot you, patch your wounds and "rescue" you into their cages.

The amount of stuff and mechanics really impresses me, even more so as they mostly work and give depth, thought being simple enough to not choke you under them. After larger fights between factions, the field is usually covered in dying people (YOU can patch up and sell to slavers in turn), others crawling with smashed or severed limbs, some lying unconsious or comatose, some might even feign death. It's not just "everybody dead, I like that". And you can mess with the factions and things do change.

Your outpost can experience raids and tithe collectors. Research is implemented in a nice way and specialization bears fruit fast. Many functions can be automated by making them into jobs for the members of your group. Your compound can function as anything from a military base or a bandit camp to a farm or a trading post.

That being said, Kenshi does have it's problems. they mostly come in the form of undeveloped facets of the game. There's so much stuff in it that it's inevitable some things will be left on the back burner. Trading is one of these. While you can be a traders, either travelling along a route or having your own store, the customers and trade goods are implemented way too simply for my taste. For example you can't set your sell prices and some stuff you can sell is not wanted anywhere and just stays there, gathering dust. Also the social aspects with the NPCs are quite limited, though there's some fun stuff going on in overheard conversations and chats between your characters. A lot of these problems can be marked down as problems stemming from the size of the dev team (as I understand it Kenshi was a solo project and the upcoming Kenshi 2 has more people involved).

[b][u]In Conclusion:[/u][/b]

I really like Kenshi despite its rough edges. For me it's a breath of fresh air and another reason to keep an eye out for indie games and leaving the risk averse AAA-companies on less attention.

Pre review disclaimer: This is THE second best game ever made.

Play Kenshi NOW

Now, I know I have to post an actual review of the game after this or some british cigarette is going to complain in the comments about meme review whatever.

Kenshi is THE sandbox game. Theres a lot of commentary about kenshi being "insanely difficult," "incredibly unforgiving" whatever. That is true, but not in the way you would expect. The game is hard because you dont know the world. All of the difficulty spikes are avoidable by carefully learning the world as opposed to attempting to game it. You CAN game it, dont get me wrong: but that requires a deep, in depth knowledge of the world that comes naturally with time.

Theres a reason why so many people have 500, 600, 700 hours. Its because the game is incredibly full of things to do, but things all happen slowly. I have three playthroughs on record. THREE. One got to mid game, the other two are around late game. The idea of a "300 hour playthrough" is an absurd idea thats normally reserved for a highly cultivated experience in a game like DOS 2 or PFWOTR, not a sandbox rpg. The fact that Lo-Fi pulls this off is nothing short of midas fucking magic.

Now, thats not to say I havent modded the game. Most people mod the game. However, Kenshi isnt, to put it bluntly, a post morrowind bethesda game. You dont NEED to mod the game into functionality, or into having features. Modding is great, and despite the game's engine, Ogre, being basically a v4 engine made with mud and hope, doesnt horribly destroy performance even at higher settings (I do not have a high end modern setup, my PC is from 2018 and its parts were dated then)

This is all you need to know. If this interests you: buy kenshi. If you are dissatisfied within like a dozen hours? Play more kenshi. If you're dissatisfied at like 60? Shit guess I was wrong, but at least you're supporting a fucking awesome dev.
(not even going to get into all the good choices Lo-Fi makes, theyre up there in top 5 dev teams along with Ghost Ship Games, Digital Extremes, and Iron Gate as just the best devs of all time)

Kenshi is a game that I feel truly encapsulates the freedom of a sandbox RPG in a post-apocalyptic world. In a stark contrast to games like Fallout 4, Kenshi makes no attempt to paint you as a special protagonist or a destined savior. Instead, you're just another survivor, trying to navigate the harsh realities of this ruined world, and that's the beauty of it.

In Kenshi, you start at the bottom rung of society, experiencing life just as any other denizen of this dystopian world would. There's a steep learning curve to the game, but once you get the hang of it, it offers a level of immersion that few other titles can match.

The game allows you to live any life you want. Want to be a nomadic trader, a bounty hunter, a farmer, or even an empire builder? The choice is all yours. You can hone a variety of skills, recruit team members with their unique traits, and even build your own city anywhere on the map. This unfettered freedom is one of Kenshi's greatest assets.

But it's not just about survival and growth. The world of Kenshi is rife with political strife, notably between the Holy Nation ,the United Cities and Shek Kingdoms, each with their own philosophies and methods. Slavery, banditry, and all manner of social ills are common here, and as you navigate these complexities, you can choose to support a faction, remain neutral, or go against everyone.

What's fascinating is that your choices have genuine, often far-reaching consequences. Picking a side can drastically alter your gameplay, sometimes leading to outcomes that you may not have anticipated or desired. This level of dynamism keeps you on your toes, as you must constantly adapt to the evolving world around you.

Visually, Kenshi isn't the most impressive game out there, but its unique aesthetic works well to underscore the game's grim and unforgiving setting. The world is vast and filled with distinct biomes, each with its own unique threats and opportunities.

Kenshi is a difficult game; it doesn't hold your hand or guide you through a pre-ordained narrative. It's a game that drops you into a brutal, post-apocalyptic world and says, "Survive." But it's precisely this challenging yet rewarding gameplay, coupled with vast freedom and impactful choices, that makes Kenshi a special gem in the world of RPGs.

[b]A Brutal and Ambitious Sandbox RPG[/b]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Kenshi, developed by Lo-Fi Games, is a unique sandbox role-playing game set in a post-apocalyptic world. With its unforgiving gameplay, open-ended exploration, and deep mechanics, Kenshi offers an immersive and challenging experience. Prepare to navigate a harsh and dangerous world as we delve into the intricacies of this ambitious RPG.

[h1]Vast Open World and Exploration[/h1]
Kenshi presents players with a vast and desolate open world to explore. From sprawling deserts to dense forests and bustling cities, each location is richly detailed and filled with unique encounters. The freedom to traverse the world at your own pace, discover hidden secrets, and encounter diverse factions creates a sense of adventure and discovery that keeps you engaged for hours on end.

[h1]Non-Linear Gameplay and Character Progression[/h1]
One of Kenshi's defining features is its non-linear gameplay and character progression. The game doesn't follow a traditional narrative structure, allowing you to forge your own path in this unforgiving world. Whether you choose to be a trader, a bandit, a mercenary, or a leader of your own faction, the choices are yours to make. As your characters gain experience, they can improve their skills and abilities, opening up new possibilities for survival and growth.

[h1]Harsh Survival Mechanics[/h1]
Survival is at the core of Kenshi, and the game doesn't hold your hand. You'll face constant challenges, from hostile creatures to bandits and competing factions. Managing resources, including food, water, and supplies, becomes a crucial part of your survival strategy. The threat of death is ever-present, making every decision and encounter a matter of life and death.

[h1]Base Building and Faction Interactions[/h1]
Kenshi allows players to establish their own bases and build their own settlements. From small outposts to fortified cities, the possibilities for base building are extensive. Gathering resources, recruiting NPCs, and defending your territory become essential aspects of the gameplay. Interacting with various factions, forming alliances, or engaging in conflicts adds depth and complexity to the world of Kenshi.

[h1]Dynamic World Simulation[/h1]
The world of Kenshi is alive and ever-changing. The game employs a dynamic world simulation that goes beyond the player's actions. Factions wage war, cities expand or decline, and economies fluctuate. These dynamic elements create a living, breathing world that feels immersive and believable.

[h1]Modding Community and Customization[/h1]
Kenshi boasts a dedicated modding community that has created a wealth of user-generated content. From quality-of-life improvements to total conversions, mods enhance the game and offer new gameplay mechanics, items, and quests. The ability to customize your Kenshi experience ensures that the game's replayability is virtually endless.

[h1]Atmospheric Visuals and Sound Design[/h1]
Kenshi may not feature cutting-edge graphics, but its stylized visuals have a unique charm. The desolate landscapes, detailed character models, and atmospheric lighting contribute to the game's immersive experience. The sound design complements the visuals, with a fitting soundtrack and ambient sounds that enhance the post-apocalyptic atmosphere.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Kenshi is a challenging and ambitious sandbox RPG that offers a unique and unforgiving experience. Its vast open world, non-linear gameplay, and emphasis on survival create a sense of immersion and freedom rarely found in other games. While its steep learning curve and harsh mechanics may deter some players, those who embrace its challenges will be rewarded with a deeply satisfying and memorable journey. If you're seeking a gritty and immersive RPG that pushes the boundaries of player agency and exploration, Kenshi is a game that deserves your attention.

It's a great game and I've had a lot of fun playing it. There's an active modding community, and it isn't too hard to tweak stuff yourself if that's your thing. It is a unique gaming experience. I wish performance was better, but Ogre 2.0 game engine does not support multi-threading. If you're going to play you really should watch a beginner youtube video, because things are a bit different than other games. Some injuries to your characters will be permanent, but most won't be. Don't get discouraged if you get the crap beat out of you in the beginning - that's how your characters build up stats like "toughness". Better to gain those stats early than struggle against harder opponents that have a greater probability of chopping your limbs off.

Looking forward to Kenshi 2. This developer deserves the $ more than most do.

[h1] No single click mouse support [/h1] 

[h1] About the game [/h1]
The devs of Kenshi are one of the most amazing devs ever. (Dont be scared of my time limit, I played before), They truly love their community and clearly are making a game THEY enjoy rather then a game that makes money. I will always support these kind of devs, and will certainly be buying kenshi 2. 

The game start slow and it is hard, and you may be confused, or think theres not much to do. GIVE IT A TRY, dont give up, watch a youtube video on the game before judging it because there is so much you can do, that you probably dont understand. There is a reason this is overwhelmingly positive. It is very good at simulating what survival in this world really would be like, and its not afraid to add stuff other games would not add, such as the option to be kept as a slave if people manage to beat you up and decide they want a slave.  It really adds realism and harsh choices .

[h1] About single click mouse support.. [/h1]
 It would be nice though if there was support for single click mouse, most gaming LAPTOPS have a single click mouse, and a very large portion of people use these.  it is impossible to do certain menu actions with one in this game as you need to hold down the click button to keep action menus open and click with the other. It would be nice to change this in settings where the menu stays open with a single click. Forcing many people to buy a mouse to connect to the laptop when many of us don't like using mouse.  Usually laptops dont use a single click mouse but for some reason, huge gaming laptops like nvidia geforce laptops do.  And despite how popular these laptops are becoming (I know 3 people who own them), there is no support for single click mouse for may games. Which is really weird considering how many people really use these kinds of laptops.

In a world of video games being ordained by people entirely removed and utterly irrelevant to the artistic process, made by code monkeys chained to their desks with the light of humanity beaten from their eyes, there is always going to be some kind of actual counter-culture or artistic movement to go against the industrialization and over-processing of production. Untold generations have gone by, we no longer need blacksmiths, yet a man who makes something beautiful with his hands is still cherished, the item he made still considered exceptional in quality even stacked against the machine-perfection of a highly engineered line.

Kenshi is, in essence, that one exceptional item made by hand. Driven forward by one guy who had a vision and the desire to see that vision fulfilled rather than try to play it safe. For all of the jank or potential flaws, I think that alone would make this a game worth playing. As it turns out though? When someone cares about their game, it usually turns out pretty good and with enough redeeming qualities to make it worth playing even without respect as to the difficulty of it's creation.

Kenshi's that game, again. It's worth it.

Axel was a former slave. Having managed to escape his fate through sheer good fortune, he vowed to free others from slavery. But that was no easy task when he struggled to even simply feed himself. He had no space for pride; he did what he had to to survive, to support and arm himself and, soon, his allies. He gathered those who were outsiders. Shamed warriors, exiled hivers, former bandits, and sought to build them a home. Through great hardship he built a camp, then a village, then a city. 'Freedom', a home to all, safe and fortified, with food, water and shelter aplenty, even amidst an arid wasteland.

For a while, he was proud and satisfied, but one day, he realised he had lost sight of what he had once set out to do. He had made a safe place for people like him, yes, but there were so many still in captivity. So he left his city in the hands of Logan, his first companion, and took off into the deserts. Under the veil of night, he snuck into one of the slaver camps. With half the guard distracted by attacking Skimmers, he stalked the other half, taking them out one at a time and locking them in their own cages. He freed the slaves and had intended to go after the slave master, but found her guards to be too wary and too powerful. When a wandering patrol passed through the camp as well, he was forced into retreat, but even in that defeat, he brought almost twenty men a newfound freedom. Six of them remained by his side, motivated by honour, vengeance, bravery, security or adventure. He looked over these gathered six - their bodies worn, their muscles weakened, their stomachs empty. He had been just like them once. There, he made a decision. 

They would be his Chainbreakers. 

He would stop building cities and start building armies. He took these six to the edge of the desert, finding refuge with the Tech Hunters and started to train them. They would strike out at bandits and slavers patrols and take their equipment. With little to no experience in combat, they struggled, but Axel always ensured they'd all return home safely, even if not always whole. When they gained in power, they set out to build a camp in the middle of the desert to strike out from. Now out on their own, however, they found themselves beset on all sides. Raids by the slavers that learned to hate them. Attacks organised by the Trader's Guild when they refused to pay for 'protection'. When they almost lost the outpost itself to Reavers, Axel had them retreat, to build a safe place on the edge again.

But even as his Chainbreakers started to build a new community, he realised that he was doing it again. He'd wanted to keep the people who trusted him safe, but that wasn't even what many of them wanted. He stopped them in the middle of their work and brought them back to the camp they had been building with a simple declaration.

They were going to war.

He left for Freedom, the safe place he had once made, to seek recruits for his new war. He returned with an army. The small camp became his second city, Liberation, a citadel built for war. Inspired by his newfound fire, his Chainbreakers pushed themselves. Brave Metaru sacrificed his own limbs, replacing them with steel, so he could better protect others. Vengeful Hew built a prison for their enemies and an arena for training - and to make them bleed. Honourable Harp built a home and a hospital, to keep their own safe. Once fearful Hengu took the animals under his wing, leading his pack into battle. Scheming Maggie saved the bandits that had once attacked them from starvation by trading their cell for one in the United Cities, letting the slavers fund their own downfall. And manic Dirt ensured that none could approach their citadel, setting traps and defences that annihilated almost anyone before they could breach the gates.

When the United City taxmen next came, they were faced with walls that were bristling with turrets and Axel waiting for them by the gate. There would be no more hiding, no more cowering. He would no longer appease them to stay safe, hoping that "one day" he would finally strike back. Nothing more would be given. Not one cent. Not one inch.

Until all were free, the desert sands would run red.

---

This is the story I have written - and am still writing - in Kenshi. I didn't go in intending to do so and I don't normally do so, it just... Happened. Because while many games like to tout that you can 'do anything' and 'play it your way', Kenshi makes true on it. It will not be for everyone. It is best played by accepting loss, because you will see a lot of it, but the more hardship you face, the more you will grow. Your characters will be beaten and robbed, will have their limbs chewed off by wild animals, find themselves captured and enslaved and yet in Kenshi it is not just possible, but basically expected that you will recover from all of that.

The game is buggy and slow to load, many of the aesthetics aren't pretty (often deliberately, I think) and the balance in the game is all over the place. Yet I keep finding myself returning. Because there really is nothing like it.

[You will not like this game if you do not allow yourself to appreciate things you didn't think you would. If you cannot let your experience dictate your assumptions, and instead let your assumptions dictate your experience, this and many games like it are not for you. Not gatekeeping gates open ily come in, but if you are looking for a "Is this a real game game, or a stupid game that makes you work" review you won't find it.]

There are very few of these kind of games. You know what kind I'm talking about, Skyrim, Half-Life1/2, Fallout, Minecraft, GTAV. Games that completely annihilate your expectations of how many hours of enjoyment you should be getting out of them.

And then, they take on newer, near immortal life in the name of modding and complete overhauls.
Enjoy the game, then enjoy another one thanks to the amazing and dedicated community. I don't know any names to name, but if you have created and been a part of the modding community around this game then please know I am specifically talking to you when I say thank you, as pure as a thank you can be.

The best hack and slash platformer RPG of our generation. Taking inspiration from Metal Gear Solid and Ninja Gaiden to create a robust yet beautifully simple experience. You play as Joe Kenshi, a former Christian, on a deliberately vague mission to find the "truth". Joe Kenshi is a very well developed all-round character, his mastery of Kung-Fu-Kickboxing and ability to speak to plants often come into play as you roam around seemingly aimlessly on the moon looking to find "the truth". The local moon people are distrusting of Joe at first, as humans were responsible for the sun's disappearance, but are soon won over when they realise he is just a man on a mission to "find the truth".  Joe's character is revealed to be traumatised from his past however, and actively hinders his quest when he begins to struggle with it much more greatly. Joe stroked a guide dog as a child, which ultimately led to it being put down as it reverted back to a normal dog (It was very good of the developers to mention this little detail as it applies to real life on a daily basis). The underwater fishtank level as well as the tower of bricks were some of the most enjoyable yet challenging gaming experiences I have ever experienced while gaming.

I won't spoil much more as I fear I might have said to much on this new release. What I will say is this: if you purchase and play this game be prepared to have every morsel of your being fully invested into Joe Kenshi's story. You'll come to love and respect this man who is simply on a "mission to find the ""truth"".

Man, what to say about this game. It took me several tries to get into it. I dropped it more than my pants when going to do number 2. I struggled with UI and basic premise. Why is my guy so useless and weak? What am I supposed to do? Do timelapse of ore mining?

I watched a lot of meme Kenshi videos to try to appreciate it from different perspective. Then I sat down and watched basic tutorial which taught me that I can use few keys to make manial labour more tolerable. Then I recruited my first guy, then I made enough money to be admited to guild then I made a small outpost then I made a farm, build defences, etc... Suddenly what was at the start "too much time" now changed with me stopping the game every third second because something needed to be managed by me. It was like new game was hidden under the previous one.
Suddenly a spark awakened inside of me. I started reading Kenshi wiki, reading about ancient books, locations, bosses, weird animals and I started to be pulled in and spending hours playing. It was a long time when some game managed to entertain me like this. Now I am playing and roleplaying and enjoying myself even though I am sometimes getting f***ed by multiple raids that are from different gangs but happen at the exact same moment. Truly a blessing.

TLDR: Bigger learing curve but worth it. It feels like RimWorld 3D to me.
For the love of Okran, make Kenshi 2 and take all my money.

Kenshi is a visually ugly game that is beautiful beyond words in its mechanics, not for everyone but those who get drawn in are bound for it to become a borderline unhealthy addiction.

The game is a sandbox through and through and you are no heroic Nerevarine or Grey Warden, no chosen one of any flavour. You start out as just some random pauper and unless you do everything you can that's exactly where you will stay, since climbing your way out of insignificance is a brutal and deeply fulfilling challenge in the world of Kenshi.

Brutally fun...literally. It has a fairly simple but brutal and steep learning curve at the start. Once you find a way and get your feet under you it is something of a snowball effect albeit very slowly for quite awhile until you get more people and they all get stronger. You can play however you want and can be as morally corrupt or sound as you like and can profit and grow either way in many different ways. It will be tough as you start as the prey and basically everything wants to enslave, kill, or eat you but eventually you will become the predator.
So if you like or enjoy an open sandbox that initially will have you flinching and running for your life every time you see someone or something all the way up to becoming an unstoppable force...then Kenshi may be for you...

Still a fun game even after years. i keen coming back to replay the game and try out different things, sometimes that i didnt even know it was possible

Kenshi is, for all it's faults, a masterclass in open world RPGs and player driven narrative. You suck, your character sucks, and you will die. At least until you figure out how to survive, and develop your skills. Sometimes it's your fault and sometimes it isn't, the world of Kenshi has never claimed to be a fair one, and you will be brutally punished if you treat it as anything of the sort. 

You could ask any longtime Kenshi enjoyer for their story in this world and while elements may be shared between them, no two stories would be the same. Rebel against a nation of fanatical human supremacist cultists alongside those working to take them down in the shadows, aid the Anti-Slavers in taking down the United Cities and their slave economy, build a faction of your own from nothing and wage war against the mighty Shek empire, the choice is yours. The catch, of course, is that you have to survive to do these things, alone or with a group of recruits all your own, who fight and bleed alongside you.

Ultimately, I don't believe that the gameplay matters much to this review. If this description caught your attention, just know that the game is slow and janky as hell in a lot of ways, but between discovering the world and forging your own storyline, I don't expect you'll be put off by it if that's your reason to be here.

Best game in its genre, hands down. This is how sandbox openworld games should be. 
-No scripts for you to follow, no quests. You kinda make your own story as you go along.
-The game doesnt revolve around your characters. You can get beaten up, enslaved or eaten alive, and the game will continue on. 
-The gameplay is unforgiving. You will lose... ALOT, but thats what I personally like about it, it makes leveling up and eventually winning your fights much more satisfying. No handholding, no tutorials (execpt for helpful popups every now and then) the game just drops you in and lets you go do whatever you want.
-Replayablity 11/10. I think this is what separates it from other games in its genre. You could start and end games differently depending on what factions you're with, and the corresponding world states. There's literally an endless amount of ways to playand enjoy the game. Together with some amazing mods from the community, you will find yourself hours deep in Kenshi.

Big developers should take notes from Kenshi.

The major factions with mods can be way more dynamic and reactive, making you more of a somebody from a nobody.

Has a slightly complex stats system for every character,  a slightly complex health and limb health system, hunger needs for characters, Clothing and weapons give buffs and debuffs making it very dynamic.

Just be wary, your pc may crash, you may need to install graphic reducing mods, to play this game without lag waves, or even crashes.

This is, without a doubt, one of the best games on Steam, possibly one of the best games EVER MADE. No, I'm not kidding.

There isn't much of a story to it. It really is a sandbox, you just sorta make your story as you play.

The Game can be brutally hard in some respects and yet hilariously easy to exploit in others. In a way the games difficulty is dynamic depending on how much you want to cheese the systems or ... If you choose to play is straight. Either way, the game is gonna throw curve balls your way. You'll take your lumps and don't even THINK about hitting that Quickload button, taking your lumps and getting stronger from failure as well as the drama of things not always working out, that's part of the beauty of Kenshi's design.

Yet in the end, most of the time I've spent with the game has been a joy... Whether it was camping just outside of a long ruined Skyscraper on the edge of a great desert, only to be attacked by giant insects.

Or having my Bone-Wolf puppy whom I'd recently bought eaten by Starving bandits after they beat me unconcious. Only to get revenge later by luring said starving bandits into a pack of fully grown, vicious and wild Bone-Wolves, seeing them torn to pieces by said wolves who then gleefully begin ripping the limbs of their corpses and eating them.

Or getting knocked out by slavers and carried to a workers camp in Holy Nation territory only to manufacture a daring escape after spending two days working as a Slave.

This game is special. I used to think it was ugly, but the more I played... The more beautiful the world and the graphics became to me... I had my band walking through the Bonelands by the beach one day as the sun was peaking over the Mountains to the East and it was just, gorgeous... The game is possessed of incredible story-weaving possibilities that just... Manifest, as you play. I've never played a game that said as little as Kenshi yet conveyed so much.

That had so little in the way of dedicated "Story" or Questing yet had so much going on.

Kenshi should literally be studied by upcoming Game Developers. That's how good this game is.

This is the game that other games should be LEARNING from.

Fun base/squad building survival game.

This game is not for the faint of heart. It's hard as hell, frequently counter-intuitive, a little buggy, and it is often truly ridiculous.

During my first major base build, I underestimated the amount of resources I would need to fully construct my defenses. I had built a long oval of defensive walls with rock mines and material crafting elements on one side with an open half on the other side of the "oval". There were not enough materials to create a gate or finish the walls as I had used the remaining materials to build a small building for housing and storing resources near the open half.

After the first few days, a group of bandits showed up demanding tribute. Instead of talking to them, I had my boys sit on the other side of the base in stealth mode behind the rock mines. The bandits charged into the base and took up residence in my small storage building. Meanwhile, I kept mining while trying to plot a way to remove them, but I couldn't think on it long before a second group of bandits showed up. The same thing happened. I kept my worker bees in stealth while this second group plunged into the storage shed. Nothing happened. All quiet.

Now, I'm really in a pickle now. Small bandit groups aren't that tough, but my workers were laborers with mediocre weapons and armor. Not much good in a serious fight, and there were two separate groups of sweaty desert bandits standing shoulder to shoulder in my storage building. There must have been several dozen of them at least. I'm about to run to the nearest fishing town to hire some mercenaries when the third group shows up. These new guys are rude and hella nude. They're also hungry as hell for human flesh, and there had to be around 50 of them.

The cannibals stood at the open half of the base for a hot minute before they too plunged into the storage building. It was absolute pandemonium. The bandits are screaming, the cannibals are yelling, and there's blood everywhere. Earlier, I had my boys build some internal walls with crossbows on them, and we're sniping the all out brawl that's occurring. The moment one of the bandits goes down a cannibal will scoop him up and take him to some far away dinner table. It's like a self cleaning mess.

After about 30 minutes, nothing and no one remains except for some bodies, arms, legs, and a massive amount of blood. The cannibals aren't even interested in eating my guys, and the few remaining bandits are simply hobbling away. I then built the remainder of the base so that the front gate was partially submerged in the ocean. Any would be hostiles would have to swim to it in full armor just to knock, and this never happened again.

God help me, I can't stop playing this stupid shit.

I've played Kenshi for over 250 hours now. I finally feel like I have seen enough of the game to really talk about it, however, I still have not seen everything this game has to offer.

Kenshi's game play is tedious; the combat is point and click. The difficulty starts off on one side of the spectrum, being very hard and stays that why until the endgame where the game becomes extremely easy. Overall the game play is not impressive and has next to no player skill involved. That being said, its addictive. After 250 hours of playing this game I still find myself entranced with just watching my characters fight after clicking the "Attack all" option.

Where this game really shines is exploration, and the vast amount of freedom and randomness you can encounter. If you want to stay a low level and become a trader, fearing bandits and monsters, you can. If you want to be a lone warrior and train up to being able to kill dozens of enemies all by yourself, you can. Do you want to destroy one of the major faction and kill world leaders? Well, you can. There is no end to the possibilities, and with player created mods, the choices only expand.

Exploration is the main focus for me personally. Each area is vastly different from the next giving the player a lot of eye candy to find. If you enjoy post apocalyptic art styles and question with no answers, you'll love the world of Kenshi. My main disappointments with exploration is the lack of unique monsters roaming the world. There are only a handful of monsters that stick out in the mind; most of which being almost identical to real life animals. Also, many minor factions feel the same or so similar they might as well be the same. This is very much the case when exploring Old Empire structures, only two or three enemy variations are ever seen inside them.

Overall this game is absolutely and positively amazing, especially if you take into account that a single person did the overwhelming majority of the work. I cannot accurately describe why I love this game as much as I do, so you'll have to experience it for yourself. 

Please, play this game and give it a chance. It might look confusing but if an idiot like me can figure it out there is no possibility you can't as well.

Legitimately one of the best story-generating games ever made. The sheer randomness of events and vastness of the world and its inhabitants ensures that no playthrough will ever be identical. Truly deserving of every bit of praise it has earned.

I decided to go with "A man and his dog" start. It was going well, I found 2 separate people on the road that decided to join me because of my beliefs. 

I entered the swamps, and we get attacked by a group of people, they knock us all out, and butcher my dog for meat. After a while they eventually leave and the 3 of us make it to the nearby town after patching up. I recruit 3 people, and now there's 6 of us, we should do really well!

Let's just say.. 6 people left town that day, and only a limping man carrying a person in a coma on his shoulder returned. Everyone else was eaten alive.

My remaining 2 people eventually recover, and I decide I want to make them drug smugglers, so now we run drugs back and forth from various towns making a profit. We find a guy at a bar who gives a sob story about his sister, and says he wants to join us to get revenge. I say sure.

Our first trip outside of town, all hell breaks lose. Beak Things, Gorillo Bandits, Blood Spiders, all in one chaotic fight, the new guy goes down, as well as one of my drug smugglers. I pick up my fallen smuggler, and run them off to a small island in a river, for safety, as I go back for the new guy. 

Hmm new guy isn't there? I click on his portrait, I see him being kidnapped by a robot! I chase after them, but the robot is too fast. This whole time I am thinking "where is he taking him?". We eventually end up at a tower, red lights all inside, and filled with "peeler" machines! They place him in one, and it slowly rips limb from limb from his body, until they eventually chuck him in a meat grinder. Not the best revenge arc for him, but he gave it a good go. 

So now I'm back to running drugs, and in the process of learning how to start my own drug farm/base. 

This is the beauty of Kenshi. None of this is scripted, it just happens. Play a few hours and you'll have your own crazy stories to tell!

Summary: Kenshi is hardcore; Kenshi is one of the most brutal survival games. On first looks the game may look like a RPG and even though the game is a lot better when you RP and get into the lore of the world and the people around you, The first thing you may notice from other RPGs is that you are not the hero, even on some of the best starts you start off on the lowest teir of survivor. I went though 10 different characters just trying to figure out how to leave the starting zone and set up a base. That's the other feature that makes this game feel like a survival game. When I had built my base I thought it would be just that ; I built a giant beacon for all my haters to attack me + making sure I had enough food for my little town. After you have a decent base and survived a few waves you can finally wage war with the Other factions (Yes kenshi has now become a strategy game). 



PROS : 
Deep Lore with many characters and in game pay off for reading and checking things out

Very rewarding imagine being a loser and then becoming the ruler of your own small kingdom 

Skill system. each skill can be effected by weather, weight, armor, and race. 

Fighting looks nice, you don't fight directly but you watch your little guy and their crew fight and once they rank up it looks nice



CONS :
You will die alot. your fav character might die, you might be out with one squad when your town gets raided 
and you comeback to nothing but bodies. 

The loading in some parts can take a minute and if you have a bunch of squads running around the game can get slow at that point.

Building can be buggy, auto store and building clipping at times can be buggy nothing major just dismantle and place again if needed.




OVERALL SCORES 
 
FUN: 8/10 I enjoy this game l lot and recommend it for anyone that loves a challenge and strategy games 

REPLAY VALUE : 9/10 Once you can build bases and fight off ppl the game gets soo much more replay value 

PRICE: 30$ 5/10 Not the 60-70$ a triple A game is but still a bit too high for an Indie game.

GRAPHICS : 7/10 The game does not look pretty, with a lot of mesh work needing to be done but its not ugly 

GAMEPLAY MECHANICS: 8/10 I the way everything works together in this game and the way combat flows and feels. Example for combat, the factors that go into play are Weather,Armor, Skill, Hunger , Day/Night , Race , Dodge, Stealth, Limbs, Weapon grade, weapon type, NPC attributes.
I think about this game when I'm falling asleep and it makes me happy.
very fun torture

Really enjoyable open world sandbox game. Become whatever you want. Well most likely a warlord with warriors and slaves building a base. Or become a lone wanderer collecting bounties, not to mention what kind of character, heavy armor with a giant two handed sword, or martial artist that dodges everything and becomes one punch man. It still has tons of bugs and crashes often but still keep coming back to explore and each playthrough decide differently on which factions i ally and make enemies with.

Kenshi is a tough game to review, because it's massive and the potential is enormous. The selling point of the game is that you can do anything, and that seems to be true, but I can't really recommend it for a few reasons:

1.) You NEED a guide to play. (This game does whatever the opposite of "holding the gamer's hand" is. Guides provided in-game are vague, brief, and largely unhelpful. Especially to get going, you need to look up a guide of some kind pertaining to your starting point, which varies based on your background and race selection. It is my opinion that a game should be self-contained and should not require other materials to be playable. This game cannot reasonably be considered as self-reliant. Perhaps if you are extremely out-of-the-box with your thinking, you'll do okay, but it's not guarenteed.)

2.) Boredom & Realism to a Fault. (This game relies HEAVILY on waiting. Waiting for animals to pass by, waiting for followers to mine materials, waiting for characters to walk on the map, etc. It's incredibly boring. After awhile I got to a point where I realized that the game had turned into 95% waiting, 5% other that I stopped and thought about why I was playing this at all. In most basic starts, you have virtually nothing to your name and must start from scratch. Most NPCs are either designed to trade with you, sell you themselves, kill you, or spout off a line or two of dialouge. This game is not quite completely stripped of interaction, but its close. It might be realistic to have to build everything from scratch, but it's not fun gameplay. Multiple irl hours must be spent to even create a shitty outpost with virtually nothing in it. It really gets to a point where you wonder when/if things will pick up. You need to be grinding to make money to survive, but that basically turns the game into a less fun version of the Sims set in the apocalypse. Combat is merciless. You have no chance of killing anything on your own and will get mauled by low tier enemies. You need to train a character intensively for them to even have a chance of hitting the wide side of a house and armor often slightly protects you will drastically lowering your attack score. I understand wanting the player to take combat seriously and even make them afraid of it, but there is a ridiculously high barrier to entry in so many ways for this game)

3.) No Story (The game leaves it up to the player to create their own story, which sounds more fun than it is, and requires alot of "headcanon" to work. Having no direction is worse than being railroaded in some cases. It is more fun to watch a video of someone explaining a playthrough they had in Kenshi than to make one yourself, and that's not how games should work. In concept, this game sounds really fun, but it just does not translate well, unless your goal is to explore and you are alright with dying multiple times via trial-and-error, monotonamy quickly settles in.)

4.) Who is this for? (This game seems to be only for people with these overlapping characteristics: they enjoy brutally difficult games, and they enjoy almost limitless freedom, with the caveat that freedom comes at the cost of interesting things occuring. If you dislike one of these, or both, I would recommend not buying this.)

If you want a game that does the concept of a post-apocalypse with brutal realism that has multiple choices and an actual narrative, I recommend Age of Decadence whole-heartedly. Kenshi is made for a specific niche of people, and if you don't want to waste hours of your life for extremely pitiful gains in a videogame, don't bother.

I first bought this game years ago looking for an open world RPG. I mined some rocks, got murdered by bandits, and refunded the game. 

Fast forward a few years and I saw a play-through of this game and I was immediately interested again - I saw that you can escape slavery, explore ancient ruins for great equipment, and the worldbuilding seemed incredibly unique. 

So I booted up the game. There was no opening, just some buttons on a screen. Picked the UC start. There was a battle going on, so I decided to loot a corpse. I got attacked by guards and was immediately downed, picked up, and put down - then launched 500 feet in the air and outside of the city, left to bleed out. I decided to close the game, but in the menu there is an option to create a new game - likely a design decision knowing that dying (a game over) is commonplace. 

I started the Hub run. I quickly learned that saving often is a must. Mined rocks, bought some friends, looted things. We chose our battles carefully as we explored the wastes. Finding ourselves stronger through many battles (and save reloads) we tried our hand at bounty hunting. With lots of money, we got equipment and made a base near Squin and recruited some farmers from the Swamp. Tired of taxes, we went to the Cannibal Plains in search of freedom and ancient knowledge. Now having lots of wealth and experience, we decided to take over the fishman islands so that we can all live in peace. We decided to venture even more, going southeast to investigate rumors of incredible wealth and technology. 

Before I knew it, I had a 100 hours in the game. With a little patience and RP-ing, you can have alot of fun in this game. Afterwards, I played several runs with many different mods - hivers only with Genesis, holy nation with lots of animal mods, skeletons only with tons of different weapons, and more. Mods in this game are fairly limited due to engine limitations - I recommend researching and testing mods to eventually build up your mod list. 

In conclusion - this game is not for everyone - it's unfriendly and clunky. With some knowledge about the game and some patience: you will eventually find yourself immersed in the incredibly unique world with lots of room for RP-ing, complex decision making in equipment/combat/wealth, and a massive world for adventure augmented with tons of mods.

In this game you can be ...

... a carpenter living in a tight religious society that, with the help of 12 others started to challenge the powers that be, leading to his own eventual demise and his followers toppling rulers of nations in his name.
... a vagrant drunk assembling a colorful heist movie-esque crew consisting of mutants and outcasts robbing warlords and tyrants.
... an all female warrior mutant tribe with a war chest full of ill-gotten gains from drug smuggling and raiding the camps of other tribes.
... a crazy scientist with his katana-wielding robot entourage or a feral man living with wild dogs waging war on bug people.
... an old warrior trying to right his ways but due to money and food being scarce turning to looting battle fields and eventually dying in a bar fight trying to drown his memories in cheap moonshine.
... a fist-fighting bug-man duo with your sidekick named Beep stealing eggs from flesh-eating giraffes in the Bonefields.
... the leader of a trade caravan selling precious goods in the most exotic locations, as long as you can afford the mercenaries to protect you from the bandits trying to steal your skin. Oh, and you also should avoid the space lasers and acid rain.
... a freed slave receiving training as a master assassin, eventually infiltrating the racist cult that has formerly oppressed you and finally putting an end to their evil schemes.
... a group of half-naked dudes with sticks that just hit everything they come across with their sticks as long as it has food or can be used as food, eventually getting lost in the swamps and being eaten by giant spiders.
... a robot taking care of his arm-less, leg-less human best friend, making ends meet as a bounty hunter until he can afford to buy his friend the much needed, yet expensive, prosthetic limbs.
... whatever else you can imagine.
