The graphics are simple and at times the game comes to a halt when loading new areas, but there is no denying that this game is fun, challenging, and unique. I am sure there are other reviews going into much greater detail, but I recommend this game to anyone that loves exploring open worlds, learning about lore and secrets, and enjoys deep rpg mechanics. The greatest open world rpg made to date. There's a bit of a learning curve, but once you get used to the UI and game mechanics it's incredibly deep. Great lore revealed through in-game items and NPCs. There is a vast wealth of information available through the community and wiki to get you started all the way through to the endgame. 
I purchased this game when it was still a WIP. It's simply amazing to see how it has evolved. Admittedly, it has bugs and glitches that have somewhat been addressed through updates and mods but since it's a single-player game I have no ill feelings toward reloading. That being said, keep auto-save turned on. Hope this helps you make your decision on this game. Cheers.

This game is unbelievably good I love games that really challenged you to do simple things, like if you want to be a bounty hunter you have to be ready to heal your hunter and be adept at fighting or assassination. Believe me when i say that this game will beat you while you are down you will never get an experience where you are the best at everything doing anything with almost no repercussions (Its super boring being really strong) i love how many options you have for example being a wandering trader selling goods to various places or doing a full 180 and playing a smuggler who sneaks hashish into slave camps in the United Cities. the opportunities dont stop at what they give you base game being always able to alter the game with mods means the saves you play will almost always be different. despite that i believe kenshi should atleast for just your first play through be absolutely unmodded this game is a blessing dont spoil it with mods and if you feel otherwise after playing your first start save then give mods a shot i guarantee they will make the game more fun but always leave the best till last.

its fun. there no end game so you can do whatever you want. if you start solo, most of the time its hard and easy at the same time since you only manage one character, but its the best way to get to know the game. once you do that, having a a team or a group is an option. base building is decent but somewhat satisfying. making money is easy once you know what to do. if vanilla kenshi is not enough to satisfy you, there are plenty of mods to choose from.  However I don't think you can keep playing this game all the time. it will burn you out, trust me. When I try to play it for at least 3 days, it gets pretty boring and hollow as there are no actual goal or fixed quest made for you to do, since you are the ones making it. play the game from time to time, enjoy it and don't play it as if you are playing a FPS game campaign, eagerly to finish everything in one go. Overall its a good game to pass the time, even though the graphics a little outdated there's a weird charm to it.

If your like me, constantly looking for Open-World RPGS to play, always looking for 'the game', this is that game. First impressions of the game will often be negative, with the cluttered UI and dated graphics, but the immersion and connection you will feel with your alien characters is like no other game. 
     Kenshi is a post-post-apocalyptic squad-based RPG that takes place on an alien tidal-locked moon. There is multiple factions you can chose to support or destroy, or you can create your own. You can be the best blacksmith who creates the best weapons in the land, and the swordsman who uses them. I'll never got bored of making a new character, and watching them explore the world, picking up new recruits and finding new enemies. The endless freedom Kenshi offers is like no other.

Kenshi is boring because it violates one of the most important rules of gaming: don’t waste my time.  There is very little content to this game, and none of your choices appear to have any real consequences. It's a whole lot of nothing.

-It’s a vast open world, but there’s nothing in it.  No hidden bosses, locales, or loot.
-There’s some world building, but no plot or characters to care about.
-There’s level/skill progression, but it’s tedious and grinding.
-I also find the aesthetics ugly as sin.

The counterargument is that we need to “use our imagination” to make the game fun.  What a scam.  What are we paying money for then? They said the same thing about Sea Of Thieves, and I’m so tired of hearing this lame excuse.  Kenshi isn't the only offender.

You know what?  I’m going to start selling people empty shoe boxes and charge them $30 for an amazing game.  If people open the box and complain it’s empty, I will just tell them to use their imagination.  It’s their fault they paid for nothing.  

My imagination is free.  If I play one more video game which charges me money for a game with nothing in it, I’m going to stop paying for video games.  This is just getting absurd.

Edit:  "B-b-but you only have 14 hours!"  Listen:  I have adult shit to do.  If, after more than 14 hours total of playing, I feel like going to the office is more fun than the game, there's a design problem.

500 hours and I still don't know how to describe this game.

It's a squad-based game, but you can go solo. It's combat intensive, yet also sometimes similar to the sims. It's a business manager, it's a tower defense, it's stealth-based ninja infiltration, it's prison break, it's a prison manager. It's a game where you can sit back and play while you snack, or create a situation where your eyes are tethered to every pixel on the screen. It's a game where you start off not only as equal to those around you, but less than. 

This game will make you feel like a nobody, in order to make you feel like a god. This game will frustrate you, even when you've figured out how it works. It will humble you when you think you've made it. You'll anger the wrong people and find your overpowered clan suddenly overwhelmed. You will find yourself gathering your men to rescue one of your crew before they bleed out or are eaten by cannibals. You'll spend hours planning to break into an ancient ruin with invaluable treasure. You will do this all without being told, but because you discovered these things were there for the doing and the taking. And even when you're on the top of the world, you'll stand on your ramparts staring into the wilds, wondering what the world has next to throw your way.

Oh, and it has base building.

It's day 26 of the campaign to free all the enslaved Hivers in the United Cities, and things are not going well. 

An outpost is being established in Darkfinger; close enough to the Great Desert to send out raids against slave camps, but not so close that wandering patrols will be able to find it easily. However, due to the remote location, shipping in supplies is difficult. The decision was made to just bring a small amount of seed material to set up stone mining and processing on site. What this means in practical terms is that there are no defenses whatsoever, just a stone quarry, a single storm house filled with camp beds, and a basic lab bench that the chief (and only) scientist is using to try and figure out windmills.

All of a sudden - bad news. One of the workers spots a large group on the horizon. It's cannibals, at least fifty of them, headed straight for the outpost. The seasoned warriors are all busy robbing the bank in Heng, days of travel away. The malnourished former slaves won't be able to come out on top in a head-on conflict, so a new plan is formulated. Jakku, the fastest runner, is sent with the meager on-site funds to the relatively nearby Bastion, headquarters of the Cannibal Hunters, in order to hire as many soldiers as can be afforded. Unfortunately, there's no chance that the hunters will arrive in time to intercept the assault; those at the base will have to survive as long as they can in hopes that help will come before it's too late.

Simply running away won't work, the rescued slaves have yet to fully recover from their lack of food, and several are even missing a leg or two. Instead, they decide to hole up inside the storm house with their stocks of building material to reinforce the door and windows. As the cannibals are closing in on the outpost, the last of the workers hurries into the storm house, locking the door behind them.

Outside, a voice bellows; "Meat for Canhead!" The morale of the workers lowers even further. Mighty Canhead is a cannibal war leader so feared that the United Cities had placed a 20,000 cat bounty on his head - more than a peasant might see in their entire life. The workers are all hunkering down inside, trying to keep quiet. Maybe if they don't find anyone, the cannibals will just leave. However, this theory never gets tested. 

Voth had been working at a far-off iron node and hadn't heard the alarm going out. As he rounded a hill, loaded down with iron ore, the cannibals spot him. He quickly shrug off their backpack and start running, but Mighty Canhead, joined by several of his fellows, are gaining on him. He won't be able to outrun them. Thinking quickly, one the workers in the house yells out a plan: they'll open the door so that he can run in, and then they'll shut it behind him. The better-fed workers armed with rusty staves should be able to keep the doorway clear for long enough to keep all the cannibals out.

With the cleavers of cannibals on his heels, Voth sprints for the storm house, practically diving through the open doorway. Unfortunately for the workers, Mighty Canhead isn't a war leader for nothing - he easily pushes past the poorly-armed guards, and three more cannibals also force their way inside before the door is wrestled shut. Seeing combat as their only chance of survival, the workers attack the cannibals with all their might. Luckily, interior walls have yet to be installed, preventing their numerical advantage from being negated. As mighty as Mighty Canhead is, there’s only so much he can do against forty staff-armed Hivers, and he eventually goes down, head ringing from the impacts to his namesake can-style helmet.

While the situation is still dire - the rest of the cannibals are still trying to beat down the door, and Mu, one of the farmers, is still out cold after taking a nasty blow to the chest that caused a lot of blood loss- the mood is almost ecstatic. They, who had just days earlier been toiling away in slave camps, had taken down a cannibal war leader all on their own. 

The statemate between the cannibals’ stamina and the workers’ suppy of materials to reinforce the door ends several hours later as Jakku arrives with twenty heavily armed cannibal hunters. They make short work of the cannibal raid, and the crisis is resolved without a single casualty.

—

All of this happened within about twenty real-life minutes. I was on the edge of my seat the whole time; I had no idea how successful my mob of rescued hive workers would be. 10/10 game.

This game is proof that graphics come second when it comes to good games. It is all about tone and atmosphere and freedom of action. And Kenshi nails it. If you ever wanted to play a true sandbox survival RPG in a post-apocalyptic world. Kenshi is your best option.

The world in Kenshi just exists. The world does not care if you are there or not. You are not the star of the show, you are a weak pleb just somewhere in this gigantic unforgiving land full of danger. The lore is told by the environment and the inhabitants instead of being shoved into your face through linear quests. In fact its a world that has history that can be discovered or ignored and the true story of the game is created through your actions and decisions and encounters inside this world. If you need handholding and the game telling you what to do, you will not be happy with it. If not you will be the happiest.

This game is the ultimate "become whatever you like to be" game. You might be a weak pleb when you start and the road is long and full of hurdles to overcome. But when you have a goal and stick with it, you can get there. You want to focus on your character and become a master thief roaming the lands solo to survive? Why not? You want to build your own city? Sure, no problem (Just don't forget prayer day)... You want to be a slave trader, a relic hunter association, make your own drug cartell or even just kidnap people and replace their limbs with robotic ones for the fun of it? Its all possible but the way to your goal will be full of hardships and horrible incidents for your character(s) you can't really prepare for.

The combat is addicitve and always fun to watch because of the detailed health system and dire consequences it can have. The combat is semi-active, it is a real time simulated battle, decided by the individual character stats and equipment of the participants, while you can still move your character to get into better positions. Being struck down will only make you tougher (if you survive) and every fight will train you for the next one. That way you will slowly become a strong fighter.

The game might have its technical flaws but the whole experience of it makes up for it 1000x. It is a true "one of a kind" game and I highly recommend it if you are interested in sandbox rpgs and/or colony simulation.

[b][u]Buyers beware:[/u][/b] You may like what you see, but dislike what you'll get.

The primary aspect that is touted anytime Kenshi is mentioned is freedom.
Freedom to trade, to kill, to explore, to build, to (ironically) become a slave, to escape from slavery... You can "do anything" and "be anyone" in this game. And in many regards, it is true.

You see, there are no inherent goals in Kenshi. it is a subjective notion.
The world is your oyster, but good luck stirring things up on your first playthrough.

Kenshi only starts revealing itself after you invest time in it, because what Kenshi is not is a casual experience that you can just load up, play, and extract some enjoyment out of. You will get bored at first. You will feel lost and wonder what to do. And to be quite honest, depending on what you like, you may still feel like that after hours of gameplay.

Because therein lies the issue with all pure sandbox games: you can distract yourself for a while, enjoying the systems of the game, up to a point. With no overarching goal to direct you, only the most avid fans who can fill the void with their imagination will truly enjoy Kenshi.

For now, I appreciate what Kenshi is about. I enjoy the exploration for the sake of exploration, I enjoy recruiting and training people, I enjoy meticulously building my base of operation and expanding it.
What I appreciate less is the micromanagement that is sometimes involved, the different non-gamebreaking but still annoying bugs that inevitably come with sandboxes, the lack of a feedback loop and of a gamification of exploration.

All in all, I have spent 48h in Kenshi's world so far, some good, some just... Grinding, a few bad. Am I enjoying it? Heck yeah! But I wish the game felt less like a blank canvas you can only paint with 2 colors. It relies too much on this "freedom to do anything", but even said freedom is restricted. It hides the game's lack of depth. Or maybe said depth is too well hidden? Who knows... Will update if I see anything.

This game is incredibly charming and incredibly scuffed in equal measure. Definitely feels like it had 10 years in development, you can see the early 2000's style design ideas.

The game presents on the surface a very clunky gameplay experience, on par with a lot of CRPGs, with a combat system that you don't have a lot of control over. It's physics-based attack system sounds interesting on the surface until you realize that it causes a lot of problems when it comes to guarding specific body parts. You can't control what limbs a character will defend on-the-fly, you can't target specific limbs on enemies either, effectively meaning that a lot of combat is dice rolling on of jank AI interactions. Fighting the same battle 5 times will result in 5 different outcomes, some drastically different.

Despite the base gameplay being so....atrocious, the outpost management and the exploration are very well handled. The world of Kenshi is vibrant and interesting, if ugly as sin to look at. That's not a dig on the graphics being far below average, that's a dig on the game's art direction being atrocious. The animals all look like they had 30 times more effort put into them than any of the environments.

Do I enjoy Kenshi? Yes. A lot. However, I cannot recommend it in good faith to other gamers. It is REAL rough to get into.

There's really nothing else like Kenshi out there, which is insane given the sheer number of games available these days. Kenshi is the type of game I've wanted forever; a true romance between RPG and RTS. The world is fantastically detailed, the monsters are relentless, and the game is brutal. There is a slight learning curve, but any 20-30 minute starter YouTube video will give you the basics. I implore people not to dive into the wiki and instead to learn the game for yourself. So much of the fun comes from exploring, failing, and picking yourself back up. I have almost 500 hours so far and there's still so much for me to explore. The fun:cost ratio of this game is surpassed by very few others. I highly recommend it.

It's not a bad game. But no one is really playing it. Why should that be the case? After all, It's an outstanding one-man effort, which has seen solid scores and solid reviews. 

The problem is this: it's a niche game full of bad choices, a horrible GUI, numerous eternal bugs, and a command structure that will leave you wondering if the developer was allowed to interact with other people growing up. Fortunately, the community is very supportive. Whatever the issue is, it seems there is always someone on duty to provide an excuse, or else a convoluted answer that someone else will disagree with... usually with yet another excuse or convoluted answer. Steam Charts tells the story of a game a good number of people purchased, but also of a game no one is really playing. Essentially, I would consider it to be THE defining game for a generation of militant hikikomori. And that's about it. 

I can't recommend it to my friends, because they will start texting me daily to see if I'm okay.

Kenshi is everything I love in video games all baked into a giant chaotic orgy.  Rts, rpg, customization, interesting lore, atmosphere, cool map, open-world, sandbox, choices and most important CONSEQUENCES. You are always one bad fight away from getting wrecked, you have to plan out your every move if you want to survive and prosper in this unforgiving world. You aren't a superhero main character from the start, this world does not care about you and actively tries to mop the floor with you and your squad. But even when things go wrong you can crawl (literally) your way out of it. The skill based sksytem works really well and everytime you do something, like fight, you can see your stats go up more and more. With each fight you get in your squad will get stronger. Even the building mechanic is great, you dont need 100 resources to build stuff and most are pretty easy to come by, or you can even make your own. I love Kenshi.

If you build walls, bandits will just phase through them. the initial hurdle for base building is also insane, thus i would imagine everyone running this game at triple speed half the time. not enough time and not nerdy enough for this crap. unless you are prepared to spend hours and hours just learning the UI, quirks and mechanics you cannot even start playing. There is probably some payoff with the complexity but its just too jank and slow for me.

I hate how much I love this game.  I'm sure you can tell by how many hours I've logged, but it's a very deep and engrossing game that can easily monopolize your time if you let it, which I consider a mark of its quality.  

The only caveats I want to mention:

- Though the graphics are a bit dated, you still need a decent system to run it.  I suspect that this is due to the engine they used when they developed it, which had some issues and I believe they said they are using UE for Kenshi 2 to avoid similar issues.  So, on my relatively old laptop (w/ dedicated graphics card), The Forest runs fine if you lower the quality a bit, but this game has difficulties at its lowest settings, which by itself lowers the play quality as you need to be able to see enemies from a distance to react accordingly.  Thus, I play on my desktop with a good (if slightly dated) graphics card.  

- It's buggy, same reason.  If walls are angled wrong/weird, enemies will get in, so check them after you build, and account for errors.  Save often, and maybe keep a rotation of 10-20 recent saves.  But be forewarned that these saves are much bigger than for most games, so don't save-spam unless you have lots of room.  

- Read a guide.  This game has so many nuances that you might end up ragequitting if you don't avoid some pitfalls, and there are many, but they're the spice that makes it so great, which leads me to:

- You will get your ass kicked.  Lots.  Sometimes irreparably.  Don't be afraid to load a save to protect your hours of progress, or just be prepared to spend some time adjusting your strategy to account for the permanent changes.  Loss is part of life, but it's okay to be a perfectionist too.

There are games design with mass appeal in mind. Kenshi is not one of these games it is very much in the niche category.

The game is a sandbox. There is no main quest or side quests there is just you and the world that you can interact with.

The game allows you to do quite a few things. Would you like to become the greatest swordsman in the land that can take on entire armies? Or maybe you would like to create a giant army and destroy some of the world factions. Or maybe you would merely like to create a small city where you craft items and farm food to sell to travellers. All of those things are possible. Of course the first few times, your story will be more close to spawning in a city, gatting ganged by hungry bandits and then captured by slave traders.

In some games that might sound like game over but in Kenshi being enslaved is a free trip to train your lockpicking, stealth and assassination skills. Unlike you the guards cannot leave. Free other slaves arm them with stolen weapons and destroy the slave camp. Become the greatest freedom fighter and destroy the empire. Or you know, capture the escaped slaves and sell them back to slavery and use the funds to buy slaves and have them mine for you. Join the empire and became its greatest ally.

Kenshi allows you to do quite a few things.

The actual game itself plays similar to many older RPGs where you control one or multiple characters. The characters can focus on the individual tasks and with task assignment you can create entire supply chains in which your characters will farm or mine resources carry them to storage boxes from wich other characters will take them for crafting of anything you might need. All while different group of characters plunder the ancient sites for research materials, which you will need to unlock better stuff.

Sadly the game runs on an ancient engine that is being push to its limit. This will lead to a few problems mostly with performances and some crashes especially if you add mods to the mix (the game supports Steam Workshop). The game can be quite atmospheric at the right time with the right camera angle but overall the graphics are quite "dated".

If the idea of taking a character from the absolute rock bottom and molding them to become the absolute most powerful thing on the entire continent. This game might just be for you.

kinda like hardcore sims. there's factions and if you do bad to them they hate you and if you heal them after a battle they like you a little better each time until you become bff's but takes quite a while. you can hunt animals for skins and food, grow crops, make enemies, make allies, fight wars likely started by stealing a greenfruit or something, destroy cities for the lolz, make your own city that will even show as a city on the map if you make it big enough with buildings and stuff, sell stuff to other npcs (i haven't figured it out yet but wiki says you can), explore ancient ruins (don't go alone, bring healing, splints and at least 1 bed per 2 characters), kill slavers and free their slaves, build your own army recruiting slaves or just random npcs you rescue from cannivals or similar and equip them with weapons you crafted yourself. there's hours worth of stuff to do and its not a complex game. make sure to have at least 6gb of ram and 3 or 4gb of vram so the game doesn't crash. requires a decent cpu like a i5 2500k and some gpu i guess. the game is cpu intensive and loads lots of stuff so you also need an ssd. a hard drive is fine too but every time the game loads something it either stutters, pauses, or you slow down on purpose so it doesn't pause or stutter. this becomes annoying eventually but i played for 270 hours like that so its not too big of a deal unless you're a crybaby.
wow

Kenshi is one of the hardest games to learn and stay motivated while playing. Its not for everyone and I wouldn't recommend it to some people. Despite the difficulties Kenshi is one of the most unique and fun games i've ever played. The moments in Kenshi are truly unique and something few games can accomplish. The game is grindy and you do have to put in the hours and effort to see your characters and base progress. The graphics are not the best but the art style and world is truly unique and immersive. The cities and scenery are amazing and really immerse you in this dystopian old world. The RPG elements are simple and easy to learn but it does require you to fail and die to learn this which can be frustrating to some players. The base building mechanics are clunky but fun once you get used to it. 

Kenshi may not be the easiest game to learn or play, but it offers a unique and immersive experience that is hard to find in other games. Despite its flaws, Kenshi's art style and world-building are impressive, and the RPG and base-building elements add depth and replayability. Sure, the game requires a considerable amount of time and effort, but the moments of triumph and discovery make it all worth it. If you're looking for a game that challenges your survival skills, your strategic thinking, and your patience, then Kenshi is definitely worth checking out. It may not be for everyone, but for those who are willing to dive into its world, Kenshi can be a rewarding and unforgettable experience.

Kenshi: survive a post-apocalyptic wasteland, with no rules and no mercy. It's like playing Mad Max, but with more limb amputations and less gasoline.

In Kenshi, you'll encounter all kinds of horrors - from ruthless bandits to bloodthirsty robots. But fear not, for you have a secret weapon: the power of bad life choices. Will you become a ruthless warlord, or a peaceful farmer? The choice is yours, but beware - every decision has consequences. So, strap on your prosthetic limbs and get ready for the ride of your life in Kenshi.

It is literally perfect but I feel like this game cannot be more perfect yet I want it to. Im saying this game feels empty once you have overpowered characters and gear. There are some pretty powerful enemies but even then all they do is give you a weapon thats like 30% better and a bunch of money which is already easy to get. I think the game tries to be as hard as possible but it manages to some how be easy. I am hoping kenshin 2 is the same game but much much harder. I mean in this game you can literally sneak into the skin hunters HQ kidnap the leader and make 80k credits and a weapon in less then 30 minutes from your spawn. That feels way to easy in my opinion. The base building is fun and I see why people can put thousands of hours into this game. But for me I probably will not be putting in any more. Though I have yet to try mods, which I will, this game is a 7/10 for me. The grind is fun and satisfying. Theres a lot to do. Its harsh sometimes and other times it makes me laugh how easy it was. Overall my favorite playstyle is just one character and go around assassinating leaders. I think this game has a lot of potential and this game is honestly amazing. I can see the idea that the goal is to try and eat and survive but im going to be honest surviving isnt that hard. Once your base is made there isnt much to do. I really hope kenshi 2 will expand on everything and get rid of most cheeses and give you more reasons to get powerful. But even if kenshi 2 is the same game with just more content and better graphics, i'll still be purchasing it. I really do love this game and I want to give it a 10/10 but it really is repetitive. Yes theres probably 100s of ways to play the game but it still feels repetitive, just trying to survive. I would like to see a story in kenshi 2, I would like to see much harder bosses, maybe dungeons.

Kenshi is one of my favorite games of all time. I have had countless adventures and failures, trying different play styles each time. Once i was Trades Chadly who owned a massive brewing and trading guild, providing for every faction I could reach all the while fighting off cannibals left and right. In another Warboss Rock Cracka and his 'Ardy boyz went across the land pillaging and maiming before a horde of beak things left us as a pile of bones and torn flesh. And each of these runs were fun. I think this is mostly because the world. The world is, and more importantly, FEELS big. Living and traversing areas like the Border Zone feels miles different from living in The Pits, or Shem, or The Swamp. Along with these lands are a large amount of factions that act and feel very different. From major government bodies, to bandit gangs, thieve guilds, and CRAB RAIDERS. Even if you've seen it all, from traversing every land, to beating and wiping out every faction in the game, you have a massive modding scene that adds so much content I have barley dived into it yet.

This game is also broken as all hell and held together with gum, duct tape, and a dream. If it doesn't crash, it might just lag to near non-functionality, or something like characters glitching into terrain, or their pathing all together might break. You need to be a very patient person or download counter measures for these. I've personally played worse but that worse are games made in hyper crunch and Postal 2. Some features in the game also really need mods to not feel at best bare bones. Building is very jank and feels like i have to build a whole mile away from a wall if I want to place down a building. Also a 5% incline can mean building there is not allowed. Playing for the first few times without mods felt fine but now looking back I'm just left wondering why this stuff isn't in the base game. 

TL;DR
The game is fantastic, just please take a trip to the workshop after your first couple of runs.

Overall, this is a game I really wanted to enjoy, but unfortunately the bugs and limitations of a game that's been out for 10 years definitely undermines my ability to enjoy my time with it. The game has the potential to be very fun, but needs a lot more time in development to be worth its price imo. The amount of game-breaking bugs makes the game very difficult to enjoy for me, and the gameplay itself is not extremely conducive to all playstyles.

For example, if you want to become a shopkeeper/tradesman, you have an extremely limited list of items you can actually consistently sell from your base (you can't be a blacksmith, armorsmith, or mechanic, you must sell common trade goods like food, drink, and medicine). If you want to be a martial artist, you must train with things like heavy weapons and intentionally lose fights over and over, there's no easy way to train it that is conducive to roleplay. There are plenty of other examples, but these are just a couple that I've seen so far.

Overall, the game has great potential conceptually, but until the most prevalent bugs have been fixed and the rpg and trading features are reworked, I wouldn't recommend buying the game unless it is on sale.

Kenshi is unlike anything I've ever played. The variety of possible experiences and playstyles is vast and the world map is varied and heavily populated without feeling crowded or claustrophobic. Progressing through the game is a slow but generally satisfying process, and easy access to mods with workshop integration can help tweak the experience as you prefer (as well as adding lots of content if you want to change more than just the lategame pacing or the balance). Starting your own town and never seeing 90% of the map or living an entirely nomadic existence are both viable and have their fun moments. I have pretty much nothing but good things to say about the "ideas" end of this game. Pretty much everything that was done intentionally as a feature by the devs, I enjoy.

That said, this game has issues. The controls are just a nightmare after the first hour. Inventory management is more tedious than organizing in real life. There's no way to mass sort your inventory, every single thing has to be moved individually. I'll give an example from the save I'm playing on now- I have an outpost reasonably close to the nearest town and have an excess of copper, so I decide to load up my pack animal and make a quick trade run. 

Here's how this should go- I bring my pack animal (garru) next to my copper storage, bring my character next to both the garru and the storage, open their inventories, type in how much copper I want to transfer (or click and drag to select multiple items at once, or hit one button to fill inventory to max, or shift click or something to transfer like 10 at a time, or anything else you could think of and incredibly easily implement to make this process less of a chore that leaches all enjoyment and entertainment from the experience). 2-4 clicks and I'm good to go, then run to town, hit one button to transfer as much copper as I can carry from my garru to my character, talk to the merchant and sell it, then refill my inventory with one button click as many times as needed until I've sold it all.

Here's how it actually goes- I bring my garru and character next to the copper storage. I open the storage, then click the stack of copper literally 40 times to fill my inventory. I close the copper storage and open my garru's backpack, then mouse through my inventory and click each individual piece of copper separately because they don't stack in my inventory and there is no way of transferring more than one item at a time. Go back to the copper storage and click 40 more times to fill up my pack again. Back to the garru, click each and every pixel of my inventory to transfer the copper. That's 164 clicks where it could have been 3 and I'm ready to go. Run to town, open the garru backpack, click 40 more times, go inside, 40 more clicks to sell my inventory, back to the garru, 40, shopkeeper, 40. Nearly 350 clicks to do what could have been done in 10 with half decent controls.

The pathfinding is just downright terrible. On that trade run into town, my characters have to cross a valley. If I send a character to town on their own while I watch over the rest of my base, they will run to the same cliff, realize it's too steep to walk down, turn back towards the road to take the "long way" (which is actually the only way, the pathfinding AI just thinks it's faster to walk down a vertical rock face at a 90 degree angle, which is technically true I guess but also not possible), then halfway there forget that the cliff was a no go, turn around and try to go down the cliff again. They will do this for days on end if I don't interfere and force path them down the road, or babysit the one character their entire trip while ignoring a dozen others back at base who are actually doing things. At one point there was an invisible wall right in front of my storage room that characters would spend hours trapped on that I eventually found out appeared when I put down a barrel at least 15 feet away. When building around rough terrain (which you will probably do a lot) your characters will sometimes trap themselves requiring you to take apart your brand new building to free them, but usually they can't actually path to the point where they need to get in order to demolish the building from their trapped position, so you have to commit another character to fixing a problem that should have never existed in the first place, not to mention the lost resources.

There's little bugs too, the interior of buildings won't load sometimes until you open the build menu and go to place something down in there. Characters will arbitrarily decide they are going to stop eating from the food storage like they are supposed to do automatically, so you will just be scrolling through your tasks to see if anyone is idle and realize one of your miners is starving to death while you watch the person right next to them go get food no problem. I've placed furniture too close to the interior walls of the building it was supposed to go in, which resulted in the blueprint for the build permanently taking up space inside because it won't show the build icon for me to order someone to finish the construction, but I also can't click on it to cancel it. My favorite was when I had just finished bandaging up from a fight against a ton of dust bandits, then got raided by a dozen ninjas whose worst fighter was twice as strong as my best while the holy nation showed up for prayer day. "Thank god!" I thought, thinking the paladins with the holy nation who were much stronger than the ninjas and had come here on my behalf would help defend our settlement. Imagine my frustration when they just stood there in the middle of the carnage, literally bumping shoulders with combatants on both sides while doing nothing but telling us how missing prayer is sacrilege. We're in a losing fight for our lives and they're scolding us for not stopping defending ourselves to talk to them, while they're more than capable of resolving this in no time. Now dear readers who are somehow still reading, imagine my frustration when I pull someone from the fight to talk to them so they don't get angry and eventually turn hostile, just to get caught in a bug where my only dialog option is "1. [...]", I cannot exit this dialog window no matter what I try, and every time I select my only option their idle dialog progresses one more line until they hit the "alright since you won't talk to us we're gonna go tattle" point, when they refuse to talk to you and run off to go tell their town full of dozens of those guys who are way stronger than the ninjas who were absolutely demolishing us about how terrible we are.

I originally reviewed Kenshi negatively, and my reason for that still stands: The onboarding is terrible. The game is unlike any other and quite unforgiving early on. You need a lot of patience to figure out what to actually do, other than getting pummeled by everyone and everything, starving, being sold into slavery or similar assorted past-times. You start at the bottom of the food chain, sometimes literally.

If you can muster the patience to get past the initial frustrations, you are rewarded with an incredibly deep and dynamic world and endless character building opportunities supported by a large mix of game mechanics. As you discover all this, you will often come to a point where you think you know the game, because surely it can't offer even more than that, just for it to keep surprising you.

I strongly advise against reading any spoilers beyond maybe a shallow getting started guide or looking into very specific things you already know and want to learn more about. Exploring the vast opportunities Kenshi offers is a very rewarding experience.

There are some great mods out there, which address some of the Kenshi's shortcomings, e.g. the UI. Also some which add a lot to the game without spoiling the lore. You will want a handful of them, but there's no reason to go overboard.

Embracing the Unforgiving World of Kenshi – A Love Letter to a Brutal Masterpiece

Kenshi, developed by Lo-Fi Games, is an open-world, sandbox role-playing game that stole my heart and consumed countless hours of my life. Set in a post-apocalyptic wasteland teeming with danger, Kenshi offers a unique blend of survival, strategy, and role-playing elements that make it both challenging and addictive.

At first glance, the game's unforgiving nature can be off-putting. Permadeath, brutal enemies, and a steep learning curve are just a few obstacles players face in Kenshi. However, these very elements are what make the game so enthralling.

In Kenshi, you start with nothing. Your character is weak, ill-equipped, and the world is out to get you. Survival is not guaranteed, and every decision matters. This raw and visceral sense of danger creates a level of immersion that few games can match. You're not just playing a game; you're living the struggle of your character, making each victory and setback intensely personal.

Kenshi's open-ended nature allows players to forge their own paths. There is no linear storyline to follow, which means you can choose your own goals and playstyle. You can be a lone wanderer, a bandit, a trader, or even build your own city. The possibilities are endless, and this freedom is intoxicating. The world feels alive, with dynamic factions, economies, and ecosystems that react to your actions.

The game's complex mechanics and deep systems also contribute to its addictive nature. The research and crafting systems enable players to build their technology and gear from scratch, while the squad-based combat and training mechanics make each character feel unique and valuable. The world of Kenshi is unforgiving, but as you learn its intricacies and develop your skills, the sense of accomplishment is unparalleled.

Graphically, Kenshi may not be the most stunning game, but its art style perfectly complements the desolate and harsh world. The game's soundtrack, composed by Kole Audio Solutions, is hauntingly beautiful, and it sets the tone for your journey through this unforgiving landscape.

Kenshi's modding community deserves a special mention as well. Countless mods expand upon the base game, offering new content and customization options that breathe even more life into the world of Kenshi. The game's replayability is further enhanced by these mods, which cater to a wide variety of playstyles and preferences.

In conclusion, Kenshi is a game that is both brutal and beautiful in its own way. The unforgiving world, deep mechanics, and open-ended nature make it an addictive experience that is difficult to put down. This game is a love letter to those who crave challenge and freedom in their gaming experiences, and it has undoubtedly left a lasting impression on my heart.

I usually don't like overly challenging and punishing games, I've a casual gamer mindset, meaning that I mostly play to relax and evade a little bit, yet Kenshi sucked me in, within its unforgiving and ruthless world. My characters have been beaten to a pulp, robbed and left on a side of the road bleeding out, captured, sold into slavery... but then I got the hang of it and finally I learned to survive and in the end my team became a force to be recon with.

I dispatched bands of bandits, created a flourishing village, erased states from the world... no game made me feel such sense of accomplishment before. If you decide to give Kenshi a try, do it with a different approach from the usual RpG: in this game you are not a hero or the choosen one; you are merely a desperate nobody trying to get by in this harsh environment just like anyone else, and no one cares about you. You'll write your own history. Be a conqueror, a bandit, a merchant, a farmer, the leader of a small army, a barkeeper, a blacksmith, an explorer, a relic hunter, a mayor... don't surrender and you'll get there.

A wonderful and original game.

I've played off and on for a handful of years. While I do recommend this game because it's a technically impressive game that evolves from an RPG into more of a management/RTS game, it's got some pretty big flaws (or "features," depending on who you ask) that would prevent me from, say, buying this game as a gift for a friend.

As far as what the game does right, you've got a surprisingly unique and interesting world that you are drip-fed lore about through character interactions, text boxes for items, books... and there's a lot of places to visit, lots of people to meet and things to acquire, all of which adds more pieces to the puzzle for you to work with. The races are varied but balanced and they have their own interesting lore that offers a break from the usual Tolkien lineup. The combat system is a thing of beauty, too, and I'm sure there's any number of YouTubers who could do a better job of explaining the bits and pieces. What I can explain, though, is there's plenty of gear to buy, steal, scavenge, craft, and train for. It scratches a very specific itch I have bordering on the 'tism that I can scarcely describe.

Unfortunately, this game really does feel like it's unfinished. Literally, there is no finish line. Even after you kill all the faction leaders and explore every inch of the continent, there's no "end state". Perhaps that's a feature, what with the game being a sandbox and all, but having a few rails, a few carrots on the stick, a few things to give *context,* would help. Most of my playthroughs involve getting a nice big colony or two going along and having a decent-sized number of people with masterwork gear and decent skills and it's like... well, the only thing left to really do now is kill faction leaders. Only, it's not that simple. 

The grind is *insane* in this game. You might say "Duh, it's an RPG" but it'll take you at least an IRL week of micro-management to train up a recruit to be on-par with some of the more mid-tier NPCs like manhunters, let alone Samurai or Paladins. And these guys come at you in packs ranging from 8 to 15 folks strong. Even if you manage to wipe out a whole squad, you've done nothing to impede the Computer. It's lost no progress, no resources, no time. Inversely, getting even one of your own guys killed is a massive loss in time spent grinding.

And the early-game is an absolute nightmare regardless of which starting scenario you pick. You're too weak to defend yourself from a single starving bandit, let alone a whole squad of them. You're gonna spend an IRL afternoon mining and selling copper so you can eat and save up enough money to join the Shinobi Thieves and use their training dummies. Then you're gonna spend your evening in sneak mode walking across town until you've got at least like 50 Stealth so you can Naruto run around the desert and practice your Assassination skill, rinse and repeat until you can knock out Bounty Hunters and Samurai to sell their swords. That's the early game. That's how you do it. Every. Single. Time. 

So, yeah. It's a great game. Amazing, even. But it's got problems. Problems that I wish the developers addressed instead of making a sequel so soon.

Kenshi's a brutal and quirky game. But it's amazing, building your characters from trash to an organized force to be reckoned with, causing world changes and instability(or stability), besides the usual assassination and thieving for getting rich fast with all the adrenaline it includes. Be a master thief, an eagle-eyed sharpshooter, a martial artist able to crack a dude's head with one punch and even an unbeatable mountain of meat wrapped in layers and layers of metal wielding a 72 Kg unpractical ridiculous and absolutely insane gargantuan sword. So wrap this gem in mods, don't stress if you get your ass kicked and you'll fall in love with kenshi's world and it's inhabitants.
One of the best games of all time

Sand

The greatest game of its time. Your little guys will take on the world and not all of the are going to make it. In fact most of them are probably not going to have a good time. This is the kind of game where your guys get stronger by losing. You balance on a knife edge all the time. 

Sometimes not a lot happens and you might be tempted to seek more risk. You will find it quickly. DO NOT LEAVE THE SAFE ZONE and expect to survive. When you see something move, your first response is to RUN AWAY and assess the risk. What are you seeing? What are you NOT seeing? You might be tempted to fight a group of guys that seems weak. Oh, one hit you in the leg. A pack of roaming wild animals charges both groups and since they are too fast for crippled you, they leave you broken and bloody. But hey, you got lucky! They're herbivores so they're not drinking your corpus like a milkshake. Now you're just bleeding out and unconscious. Your rescue/mining team has no fighting skills and pretty much no chance of getting you out before something far less friendly comes to eat your legs. Worry not, SLAVERY to the rescue! Hippety hoppety you're now someone's property and that's a GOOD THING because you won't starve or get eaten alive and that counts as a win!

For you this might sound horribly, in Kenshi this is a regular weekday.
